[h3][b]TL;DR[/b][/h3]
Two Point Hospital is the perfect 1990s & early-2000s Tycoon/Management game. 
[list]
[*] Square grid system⠀[i](none of that "freeform" modernity)[/i]
[*] Few but enjoyable gameplay mechanics⠀[i](not a job simulator)[/i]

[*] Simple and fun customization⠀[i](no choosing wood type for 10cm of your wall)[/i]
[/list]

This is my second time playing this game. the first time was through Microsoft and I logged over 60 hours. When I lost access to that version, I bought it on steam because I enjoy it so much.
Two Point Hospital is a hospital simulator game that adds just enough silliness to keep things interesting. The illnesses are all fictional so there is no worry of triggering content there. And even if you fail to cure a patient, they just turn into ghost and (rightfully) terrorize your staff until a janitor sucks it up in a vacuum cleaner. Each new hospital has three levels of challenges to complete and there are plenty of levels to play. Don't worry about being overwhelmed early on, as the different diseases are introduced slowly so you have time to collect money to build your treatment rooms.
There are additional game play modes with Co-op challenges to get special items, DLC locations, and an impressive Sandbox mode.
If you enjoy other Two Point games, you'll like this one as well.

Two Point Hospital drew me in with its nostalgic charm reminiscent of 'Theme Hospital,' but sadly, the excitement fizzled out as I delved deeper into the gameplay.

The repetitive nature of the game becomes apparent as you progress, with each level feeling like a rinse-and-repeat cycle of building the same rooms over and over again. Once you've optimized a GP office or a treatment room, there's little incentive to deviate from the formula, leading to a sense of monotony.

My biggest gripe with Two Point Hospital, however, is its lackluster solo experience. Many items are locked behind group projects, forcing players to either team up with strangers on Steam or pester friends to participate. Alternatively, some items are tied to social media groups, requiring additional sign-ups or logins.

This reliance on social interaction and daily tasks to unlock content feels more suited to mobile games than a PC title, especially considering the upfront cost. It's disheartening to see a game I've had for years become more about habit-building and fear of missing out than genuine enjoyment.

Despite its potential, the game's emphasis on social engagement and repetitive gameplay has left me feeling unmotivated to even launch it. For a game that promises a trip down memory lane, it's a disappointing realization.

You play as the hospital administrator. I love Sim games and I'm in the healthcare field. I wasn't expecting much from this game, either, but still, couldn't get into it. The graphics bog down my computer, and there isn't much to do other than build rooms, hire staff, and decorate the lobbies of your hospitals. Five bucks would be a fair price for the little game play that you get. It reminds me more of a dollar bin buy for the Switch. A lot of casual watching and occasional tasks for you to fulfill, nothing more.

In the whimsical realm of Two Point Hospital, where jest and malady dance hand in hand, the player assumes the guise of a sage healer. Tasked with curing ailments of fantastical nature, from luminous craniums to contagious mirth, one must navigate the labyrinth of care with both wisdom and wit. Here, amidst the chaos of management and the spectre of failure, laughter emerges as the truest balm, transforming each trial into a scene of comedic triumph. Thus stands Two Point Hospital, a testament to the merry alchemy of healing, where every cure is a verse in the grand comedy of life.

Two Point Hospital is a financial maestro's delight, offering a prescription for profitability that resonates with the astute financier in me. From a return-on-investment perspective, this game masterfully balances cost efficiency and revenue generation, creating a virtual healthcare empire that would make any shareholder swoon.

The financial dynamics at play here are nothing short of extraordinary. The revenue streams from patient treatments, coupled with strategic investment in state-of-the-art medical equipment, synergize to deliver a robust bottom line. The cost-to-income ratio is finely tuned, resembling the precision of a high-frequency trading algorithm.

The game's expansion packs are akin to diversified investment portfolios, providing additional revenue channels and shareholder value appreciation. Each new hospital is not just a medical facility but a lucrative asset in the portfolio of Two Point Corporation, delivering both immediate and long-term returns.

The personnel management aspect mirrors the delicate art of human capital optimization. Balancing staff salaries against their productivity, ensuring that the wage-to-output ratio aligns with market benchmarks, is a testament to Two Point Hospital's commitment to operational excellence and sustainable profitability.

While the whimsical ailments of the patients may tug at the heartstrings, the finance bro within remains laser-focused on the bottom line. The game offers a cathartic experience, where curing ailments is synonymous with maximizing revenue per patient visit, elevating the shareholder value proposition.

In conclusion, Two Point Hospital is not merely a healthcare simulation; it's a financial symphony orchestrating shareholder value maximization. For the finance bro seeking the thrill of strategic decision-making and fiscal prowess, this game is an exhilarating journey where every diagnosis leads to a healthier balance sheet. It's a financial rollercoaster, and in the world of Two Point Hospital, the only cure needed is the relentless pursuit of profit.

Great business simulation game which holds up to its spiritual predecessor, Theme Hospital.

This is the first simulation & management game I have played on Steam. I enjoyed it thoroughly.

Positives:
[list]
[*] The game is well optimised: it runs smoothly at full resolution on a Mac with M1, though I have to lower the graphics quality to reduce heat. It only lags a bit when I have a huge 20+ levels hospital.
[*] The graphics are great. The art style is funny and adorable.
[*] The soundtrack is impeccable. Relaxing and enjoyable after even 100+ hours.
[*] The illnesses, their visual and description, their treatment room, their curing, are all hilarious.
[*] Numerous items to design and decorate your dream hospital, ideal for those players who love building.
[*] For those who would rather focus on the management side, it will be reassuring to know that building and decorating effort is not strictly necessary to run a perfect hospital. This game allows you to create functional and highly optimised rooms without much ado. You can then use the same template in each of your hospital.
[*] Very well-designed levels, with an extremely smooth learning curve. You just need to play through the career mode to learn progressively different elements of the gameplay. I wish other simulation /management games have a similar learning curve! However, the game itself does not directly give you enough hints about how to optimise your hospital quantitatively. For that part, one should definitely refer to the greatest guide for TPH, written by Freiya: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1519429114. After mastering the concepts in this guide, the mechanics of the game basically becomes so transparent that one can easily obtain most of the achievements.
[/list]

Negatives:
[list]
[*] The management side of the game is somewhat shallow. So it becomes a little bit repetitive (needs tons of micromanagements) in the late game, especially if you have mastered the concepts in Freiya's guide: in each hospital, you follow basically the same routine.
[*] The DLCs are too expensive, consider that they mostly only add new items and new illnesses but not much new mechanics to the base game. Up till now, TPH has 6 major DLCs. These 6 DLCs in total have roughly the same amount of content as the base game itself, but they cost twice as much.
[*] The AI of patients and staff has some bugs. Occasionally, they don't go to the toilet, or eat, or drink, even when they are desperate.
[/list]

All in all, I strongly recommend this game. For casual players, maybe just get the base game, and buy the DLCs later if you want more of the same experience. However, if you are fans of Theme Hospital or if you are into simulation & management games, I recommend getting all the DLCs to have the most complete experience of this title, and to support Two Point Studios for their upcoming titles! Two Point Campus is also out now, perhaps Two Point Theme Park won't be too far away?

More info on game length:
[list]
[*] The base game has 15 hospitals, which takes around 30 hours to get at least one star from each hospital. To get all the achievements from the base game, it takes around 100 hours. The base game has a sandbox mode, which offers even more replayability.
[*] Each DLC has 3 new hospitals, with tons of new illness (part of which are visual illness; they are as hilarious as those in the base game), new items (mostly cosmetic, only several items are of good value in terms of strategy), and new objectives to complete (some are creative and enjoyable to accomplish, and some others are excruciatingly painful). For each DLC, it takes 15–20 hours to get all 5 related achievements.
[/list]
So, in total, it takes nearly 200 hours to get 100% achievements.

A very fun game, and one I (at the moment) prefer to Two Point Campus. Because the impacts of your choices, of placement of objects, amounts of doctors or rooms, are directly visible in the game play. It takes a bit of time figuring out on Wiki why happiness of staff or patients is important and how it affects the game, but once you spend a bit of time learning the basics, it goes uphill from there. (meaning it gets better).

The only 'beef' I have with this game, is that it does not clearly say what affects what or how. For example Two Point made a statement in not writing any numbers on any of the items. Which is annoying, but once you visit the Wiki enough, you will quickly find your favorites and will know what you are doing.

Copying items would be nice too, and I don't think they will implement it. But at least know that on the top left you have a "filter", so you can search for your items without having to scroll up and down to find it.

Overall, it is a very addicting game, with fun visuals and very funny 'diseases' and descriptions. But it is a good Sim as well, in a sense that it makes sense why certain things affect others and it is a great game for those who like to 'micro manage' their workers, as oppose to 'macro manage' (like two point campus).

If you like Sim games that are for fun but also make sense, then this game is for you!

After 250 hours playing and completing the game (no DLCs yet) I can say that this game is what any tycoon management lover would ask for. Fun, dynamic, plenty of missions to do and a sandbox. You can play this game for hours and you won't even notice. I like the funny sicknesses and the machines to cure them, very creative. Once you get into it, you know what to do for making a cool hospital. Even when each hospital comes with some new challenges, it's not something that you could manage once you learn how to deal with it.

If you want a game for having fun at your own pace and that you will be able to play whenever you want and come back to it, this is one great option to pick. Considering the competition or games that are in the same hospital management category, I don't think there's something better that Two Point Hospital. The OST is pretty cool, I love to play with it, but if you're into your own shit, you can play your music instead. That's a nice feature. There are collaborative tasks if you have friends with the game that unlock items very useful for your hospitals. 

I would totally recommend this game to any city builder's lovers, tycoon builder's lovers, management game's lovers, etc. And for the prize you can get this when there are offers, is a must.

At least in this game you can still delete the room if your machine explodes). There are varying difficulties between levels but once I started playing, I was hooked! I purchased all the expansion packs so my game is heavily fleshed out, but even the base game has a lot to offer. It's fun, quirky and quite addictive!

A super charming hospital management game that generally plays pretty well. The star of the show is the in-game radio, featuring the game's lovely soundtrack and some genuinely funny bits by the radio hosts. The Room Template feature is a real lifesaver, allowing you to refine your hospital-building skills between levels. The rest of the UI and management capabilities feel somewhat insufficient on the later levels when hospitals grow larger and staff setups become more complex. 

[i](Played on Amazon Games. All 45 Stars, All 6 REMIX Stars, 195kk Foundation Value)[/i]

[h1]Good[/h1]
– Charming graphics, animations, and theming that adds much-needed humor. 
– Wonderful soundtrack, presented through a delightful in-game radio, complete with hosts and commercials. 

[h1]Bad[/h1]
– UI and management capabilities feel Insufficient for later levels. 
– Keyboard shortcuts are very limited. 
– Staff and patient AI sometimes feel weak and frustrating. 
– Levels become a bit formulaic, rather than encouraging different approaches.

From whimsically-named illnesses (Jazz Hands, Floppy Discs, Grey Anatomy and Night Fever) to nifty medical gadgets (Jabmaster, Helixer and Clown Clinic), Two Points Hospital is oozing with fun!  The game requires a modest amount of strategy and has a decent amount of replay value, including R.E.M.I.X of certainly hospitals you can retry with completely different challenges.  After working in a hospital in real life, this was a refreshing break!
Fun game with a great sense of humor.
a witty game and a nice homage to Theme hospital.

Obviously a spiritual successor to Theme Hospital. And it nails it! The game basically introduces and challenges you in each of its internal systems for every level / hospital. And it does so in a way where I never really minded having to start over again and again. The only thing that bugged me was the constant need for decorating rooms to get them to an acceptable level. But that was fixed with a patch introducing the much needed "Copy room" button.

I love this game, and I feel really relaxed when playing it. Some might complain about the difficulty being too easy. I might agree to a small degree. But really, this game would get frustrating really quick if you constantly had to fight the systems to stay on top of things. I do agree however that it is really, really difficult to play this game so badly that you'd have to start a level over. But then again, I don't really want to. And the game does a good enough job at telling you where s*it is about to hit the fan so you can correct it before it does. I kind of like that.

The graphics, the humor, the music, the radio hosts. I love all of that.

Also check out Two Point Campus if you like this game. And be sure to leave it time to grow on you. Campus is not as immediately engaging as Hospital is. But I've grown to love both of them equally after having played both for about 45 hours.

Definitely a fun and challenging game that is far more in depth than I ever could have imagined. My wife really loves this game, as she has been a player of Theme Hospital since the 90's. You'll never be bored with this, I promise.

Two Point Hospital injects a healthy dose of humor into the simulation genre, offering players a prescription for laughter and strategic thinking. Developed by Two Point Studios, this medical marvel takes the chaos of managing a hospital to comedic heights, making it an absolute delight for fans of simulation games.

Visually, Two Point Hospital adopts a charming and quirky art style. The exaggerated character designs, coupled with vibrant and humorous animations, set the stage for a medical world that doesn't take itself too seriously. The attention to detail in the hospital layouts, complete with amusing illnesses and treatments, adds layers of comedic richness to the game.

The soundtrack is infectious, providing a lively and upbeat backdrop to your hospital management endeavors. The whimsical tunes capture the essence of the game, enhancing the overall playfulness. The sound effects, from the humorous patient interactions to the jingles accompanying successful treatments, contribute to the game's immersive and comedic atmosphere.

Gameplay in Two Point Hospital strikes a perfect balance between accessibility and depth. As you design, build, and manage your hospital empire, the game introduces a variety of hilarious ailments, each requiring its unique treatment. The strategic placement of rooms, hiring the right staff, and addressing the peculiar needs of your patients keep the gameplay engaging and entertaining.

The humor in Two Point Hospital is a standout feature. From the witty dialogue to the amusing announcements and the absurdity of treating ailments like "Lightheadedness" by replacing patients' heads with light bulbs, the game consistently delivers laughs. The writing is sharp, and the comedic tone permeates every aspect of the hospital management experience.

The community surrounding Two Point Hospital has embraced its comedic charm, sharing stories of their most bizarre medical cases and creative hospital layouts. The game's modding support further enhances its replayability, with players adding their own humorous touches to the already amusing world of Two Point County.

In conclusion, Two Point Hospital is a comedic triumph in the simulation genre. Its charming visuals, infectious soundtrack, and clever writing make it a standout title that's both accessible to newcomers and rewarding for simulation enthusiasts. If you're in need of a dose of laughter along with your strategic challenges, Two Point Hospital is the perfect prescription for a healthy and entertaining gaming experience.

[b] Achievements. A long game with multiple DLC required. [/b]

[h1] The Game [/h1]
Hospital simulator where you build and manage hospitals while completing different objectives and challenging scenarios.

[h1] The Achievements [/h1]
Be aware that there are several long and grindy achievements, which also require multiple DLC for completion. There are some guides and tips available but as you progress throughout the game you learn certain mechanics and strategies that will get you through most, if not all, of the hospitals. Estimated completion time depend somewhat on skill but you can expect well over 100-150+ hours.

[h1] Recommendation [/h1]
At its core, the game is pretty solid with good management, mechanics and scenarios. The problem lies within its length where you don't get much variation with every hospital and DLC. Due to the completion time required I wish I could give this game a neutral recommendation, but as it stands I will give it a positive recommendation.

If you're an achievement hunter, feel free to check out my curator for more reviews!

The NPC behavior can be somewhat confounding at times, but the difficulty increases as you progress, which is appreciated. However, a bit of warning as to level difficulty would have been nice to have. The only real complaint is how much content is paywalled behind DLCs and how little each DLC cumulatively adds to the game (usually 2 or 3 levels each) for a sticker price of about $8-10 per main DLC. While post-launch content isn’t always free, the DLC content at their normal prices represent poor value for money and I would only buy them on sale. This game has so many fun and interesting things to do and heal. The funny characters and the wacky diseases that you have to treat are absolutely adorable. When you add the DLCs to the mix, it becomes incredibly entertaining to try keeping everyone alive. It’s always fun playing this game and finding it an incredible challenge to win. I give this game a 9.5 out of 10.

Title: "The Hospital of Your Nightmares: Two Point Hospital Review"

Rating: ★★☆☆☆

When I first checked into Two Point Hospital, I was ready to scrub up for what I thought would be a whimsical jaunt through medicine's lighter side. I expected to perform complex surgeries and manage a team of quirky doctors. Instead, I found myself playing what felt like a never-ending game of whack-a-mole with bizarre illnesses and a hospital that runs with the efficiency of a sloth on sedatives.

Graphically, the game is like a cartoon come to life. The bright and exaggerated art style adds charm and makes the endless tide of patients with "Light-Headedness" (yes, their heads are actually lightbulbs) somewhat bearable. However, compared to the visual humor and detail of games like "Theme Hospital," the jokes here feel as recycled as the hospital magazines.

Gameplay-wise, the game promises to flatline your boredom, but the vital signs aren't strong. It's all fun and games until you realize that managing the hospital is as repetitive as the PA system's bad jokes. The game tries to inject humor into the management sim genre, but it's like laughing gas at a root canal – it helps, but you're still in pain.

As for the management mechanics, they are about as deep as a kiddie pool in a drought. You'll find more complexity and engagement in a game like "Planet Coaster," where every decision feels impactful. Here, you're left feeling like the hospital administrator who lost the manual.

In conclusion, Two Point Hospital might tickle your funny bone initially, but the humor is as superficial as a band-aid on a broken leg. It's a lighthearted take on hospital management that unfortunately doesn't quite reach the heights of its predecessors. It's not exactly malpractice, but it's not the peak of health either.

It was fun for the first several hours I played it, but not enough changes with each level to keep my interest, and there aren't enough decorations to make things feel fresh each time. I found myself spamming paintings in a room just to get the desired star level. Also, why so many wall objects and so few physical objects like plants? Even the workshop only lets you add in player-made paintings and rugs and no actual objects. 

Levels start to feel more copypasta with one new rule added in each time and not fast enough or varied enough to keep it interesting. I'm still giving it a thumbs-up, though, because for the several hours I played, I still had fun. Just get it on sale.

A very fun simulation game that reminds me of the old "Theme Hospital" game. While it still has its complexities that you expect from a simulation game when it comes to micro-managing and making sure everything runs smoothly, this game seems to be a lot more forgiving and simplistic than some of the other bigger simulations games like Cities, Sim games, and Tycoon games. That doesn't hurt the fun at all in the game and it's always a joy to build a hospital, outfit it with luxuries needed to make your patients comfortable, and all the rooms needed to help with whatever ails them.
Once you get a your hospital running efficiently, it's nice to kick back to the calming music (which you can add your own custom stuff to) and just chill out as the hospital kicks through the goals needed to become a 3-star.

After playing this game for 180 hours during the last two weeks, I have finally decided to leave a review.
First - if you are unsure, then just do it. It is a very fun game. It seems a lot of people compare this to Theme Hospital which I used to play as a teen. At first I thought it was a blatant rip off until I learned the original developers were involved with this. And it shows. The same exact quirkiness, humour and game play style is apparent, if not even more honed. I love that the same elements of the original game were kept, while adding many more new concepts and ideas. I also love the fact that alot of tings that just didn't function correctly in the original are now working as they should. I had to relearn some strategy as I assumed things worked as they had long ago, and I had to learn the hard way that these things function now. There are still issues of course. Nothing I feel is worth mentioning. I love this game. If I had to say anything negative, I would point out that the option to link amazon/hospital pass advertised on the main screen is outdated, the interface is a bit clunky - especially adding items and scrolling for ages, there seems to be a delay/freeze when opening menus and after month ends, and some things just are not well explained when you first encounter them. Besides these things, I love everything else.

A more complex remake of the old Theme Hospital, TPH is a tycoon simulation game in which you build a hospital. Actually you build many hospitals in the career mode and with all the DLCs which add diseases, rooms and animations to the base game.

I think the most important thing about this game is that it's very, very funny. That's a rare thing among video games nowadays. You can't not smile when you see a cheerful Elvis Presley walking in the hospital halls. Add to that a hundred more funny disorders and hilarious audio announcements and you can get an idea about how funny this game is.

Otherwise, TPH is a classic tycoon game, with research, money and staff management and, of course, patient care and coaxing. The complexity is variable through the missions, some are hard or grindy, some are simple. 

Pros:
- graphics
- humour all over the place, no spot left untouched
- very long game, especially with all the DLC's
- customizable rooms very easy to build with many, many hilarious decorations
- addictive: when you finish a mission, you can't wait to begin the next one
- relaxing and satisfying to see your hospital going about its business like an ant farm
- music (I love it, one of the best)

Cons:
- DLCs content is not integrated in the main game, i.e. it's available only in the DLC's missions.

To finish the game, it's relatively easy. But to get all stars on every level, the difficulty increases massively. Thus, I recommend this game, may you be a more casual player or a completionist, there's challenge for everyone.

Medical malpractice is a legal cause of action that occurs when a medical or health care professional, through a negligent act or omission, deviates from standards in their profession, thereby causing injury or death to a patient. The negligence might arise from errors in diagnosis, treatment, aftercare or health management.

Addictive. Good value for money. However, recently Sandbox mode is unplayable unless you sign up for 'hospital pass'. That no longer exists so there is part of the game which has been disabled by the developers.

OK, the elephant in the room: THEME HOSPITAL

Did they capture the spirit of Theme Hospital: Yes, this is rarely the case, but this game managed to do it.
Was Theme Hospital better: FUCK YES, because it was revolutionary, but it's incredibly hard to capture that at this age.
Am I gonna feel as good as I did playing Theme Hospital: No. You never will, and it's not this game's fault.
Are you stupid for speaking for a whole generation of gamers as if you know everyone from that generation is on the same page: Yes. I'm stupid even when I'm not speaking for a whole generation of gamers. My wife says so.
Is it worth buying: Yes, especially when it's on discount.

If you were waiting for an HD remake of Theme Hospital, then maybe keep waiting. This is a bare minimum hospital management sim that under delivers on gameplay to over deliver decoration.

Building the hospital is a tedious affair as you divide up the space and place the basic equipment, then you're introduced to the clutter - items the game categorises as 'decorations', most of which just exist to raise the hospitals 'attractiveness' and 'prestige' bars. They are largely gated behind a special currency that exists to drip feed you more clutter. Some of them give tiny bonuses to things but this is the only area any of the developer's innovation can be found as the rest of the game is pretty much identical to the 1997 release.

Gameplay gets old fast as you run into the usual management sim mechanics: balance your budget and wait to earn enough cash to expand your facilities to do more of the same. The game is littered with the same dad joke humour Bullfrog games were famous for which becomes tired by the 2nd of 15 levels, each of which follows the same formula of setting up the hospital and earning more than you spend.

Nothing special here sadly. The only substantive addition to this game is the aforementioned clutter system and when the developer's only innovation is on cosmetics that's a red flag. If you need proof look no further than the slew of cash grab DLC which can be sorted into three types: more of the same, reskins, and cosmetics. Sad to see another project with potential get phoned in and dumbed down.

This game is fine - no big bugs or issues like that. It just... isn't that fun. I feel like I'm grinding through a series of chores rather than playing a game. And once you figure out the progression for founding and running your hospital, it really isn't that different from one level to the next.

Chill, enjoyable, intuitive and a great homage to Theme Hospital. The training system is a bit tedious compared to how I remember it being in the original, but in all fairness there's probably some nostalgia in there, and I will definitely say the game is far smoother and less glitchy than Theme Hospital is.
Interesting idea for a management simulator, definitely try it if you like the genre.

Cons: 

- there are a few very tedious chores you have to do to 3 star every hospital, such as vaccinating epidemic patients (you basically have to stare at your screen waiting for someone to give off a rare symptom) or getting the hygiene rating up to 90% (one of the most difficult and boring tasks in the game).
- the vast majority of items in the game just increase attractiveness of the hospital. very few actually do anything else useful. would love to see a better mix of item uses.

Pros: (everything else)

- Balancing your economy and cure rate is fun once you have a working strategy for doing it.
- The radio stations and tannoy operator are hilarious
- Once the devs added room copy-pasting and templates the game went from tedious to fun
- The game does a great job of keeping the feel of the old Theme Hospital while updating the mechanics for today's audiences.

Overall a fantastic game but DOES take some getting used to. A lot of working strategies don't make a lot of sense, but once you figure them out it will be smooth sailing. That having been said, you basically won't run into any of the cons I mentioned if  you only want to 1-star the hospitals (which is all you need to unlock all the hospitals in the game).  You will only struggle (with both reasonable and unreasonable challenges) if you're a completionist and insist on 3-starring every hospital.

The main problem with this game is that someone doesn't understand accounting. I find myself in the red all the time because someone adds and subtracts wrong.  You are suppose to take what is coming in from what is going out to get the total. It's only suppose to be the total that is added or subtracted to or from the budget.  Income - expenses = profit or loss. It's only the profit or loss that is supposed to be added (profit) or subtracted (loss) to the existing budget. This game adds all the expenses to the existing budget. This needs to be  fixed and this game would be much better.

Honestly Two Point Hospital is very tedious and stressful at times, which is hilarious because I started playing this as my "chill" game. That being said it's extremely gratifying and addicting, I even rage quit at one point and just couldn't stay away from it. Theme Hospital was one of the games that got me started as a wee lad so the nostalgia factor was present in the beginning, but man this game is way more difficult. Eventually I did "git gud" and figured out how to raise treatment prices and spam pharmacies, start very slow and work your way up, how to teach and maximise staff efficiency ect and man it feels so good to say I finished the whole base game. I love all the sound effects and music and the DJ/voice over is really cute and hilarious at times. Definitely some missions with real "screw you" tedious af objectives that were very frustrating and required multiple restarts. Also if you listen to your little adviser dude or giving patients what they want as they request it you'll lose, so it's kinda stupid the game doesn't give you very good advise past the first few missions I had to watch some youtube videos to learn how some aspects work. The DLC also seems pretty greedy and I ended up not buying any seems like a lot of bloat, totally fine with just the base game plenty of content. Overall this is the type of game I use to love but I kinda lost touch with, but maybe this resparked my enjoyment of the genre. Great game with a few minor flaws. 8.8/10

This game is actually amazingly fun!  I have a doctor's appointment coming up and I'm going to bring it on my Steam Deck (yes, it plays on it, but I still use a bluetooth mouse with it in portable mode - can't speak to how to deck or a controller works on it as I use the mouse when I'm on PC too) but at my doc's appointment I'm going to bring it on my Deck, play it loud until they come check out what I am doing,  I'll be sure to point out how much better a little video game can run medically more efficiently than they do. :P  Then again if they didn't make me wait 3 hours after my scheduled appointment time I wouldn't have anything else to do except stare at other patients that are ahead of me and have been waiting since 1987.  Now I can play and set up a better medical experience than they offer; no patients bored waiting in my queue! ;P

It's a well done enjoyable and totally chill kind of sim.  Sit back and take your time, or rush through. It's your call and regardless of how you choose to play it, it's a lot of fun.  I wasn't sure about if I should get it, but snagged it on sale and can honestly say I would pay the full price for it knowing there's so much to it.  I'm only 9 hours in and know for a fact that this is a keeper that will long outlive a lot of my other games.  I didn't get any DLC yet but I like knowing it's there when I get through it.  That being said I know it will take awhile as I'm heavy into micro-managing in the game already so I can get every bit of fun and goodness out of it!

Good game, lots to enjoy with it - it's a game you can play however you want to without following a structured plan.  For me, it's in micro-managing (you don't have to, but I'm glad it's there), and getting attached to what I've created, the staff I've hired and I plan on being the top hospital company in all award categories there are out there in Two Point County.  Big tech, look out!  :D

I'd give it a solid 9 out of 10 in my book if you're really into simulation games and milking the game for every bit of fun you can get out of it.  That said, there's a lot to be had! Could be a perfect 10, but in this far I'm already happy with a 9 such a short time in.  Who knows, I could update my review after having spent more  time with it as I know there's so much ahead waiting for me to explore and crazy illnesses to cure ahead!

On a side note, I don't recommend getting it just for the Deck alone without using it docked in conjunction with a big screen or a larger monitor. It's just easier to set up the scenarios and hospitals on the  PC.  Once you get a hold of how it's set up and plays, the Deck is great and you can follow along well knowing about icons and stuff.  I must say I was tickled at how it is on the Deck, but the PC is better for initial setting up of your hospitals.  

No matter if you play it on PC or the little screen, (or enjoy on both like me),  it's a game of big fun - good times if fun and slightly silly sims are your thing.

I am pleasantly surprised by this game. I expected it to be fun at the start and then start to feel repetitive once I caught on to the gameplay loop, but that's not the case. Each new level I am excited to improve my hospital, and I don't feel like I am constrained from doing what I want to do by the map layout or the "meta". The game feels quite balanced, everything just seems to work well and the difficulty is perfect for my liking.

There is something that I don't like about the game though. Those Superbug Network projects require you to have a friend complete objectives for you to progress. There is no reason for that, they just want me to spam my friends with invites for free advertising. Those projects seem to be secondary to the main progression system, but it was still fun having other objectives to work towards.

If you've played Theme Hospital, it's a less fun clone, which is pretty damning given how long it's been.

Gets really samey really quickly. It's possible Theme Hospital would feel like that if I played it again today, but even if so that's the point- expectations move on. Theme Hospital was at least extremely tightly-designed and visually legible in ways that this isn't.

This sounds like a minor thing but the fact that all the decorations are Sonic and Sega themed makes it feel cheap. One Sonic decoration would be a cute gimic, but they're the only options!

Others are giving it great reviews. Maybe I'm missing something?

Two Point Hospital is a management simulation game that follows the footsteps of the classic Theme Hospital. While it has its moments of fun, it ultimately falls short in providing an engaging experience due to its lack of challenge. Money is not a true obstacle, as players can simply wait until they have enough money to progress. Additionally, the game does not present enough situations where players need to truly manage their staff, hospitals, and illnesses. As a result, the game can feel overly simplistic.

For example, having the ability to assign janitors to specific buildings would not only make the game more efficient, but it would also add a layer of realism. It's frustrating to see janitors running back and forth between buildings for small tasks when they could be assigned to a specific area to handle all the tasks.

Customizing each room in the game should be a major feature, but it falls short. While certain decorations give bonuses to a room, others don't provide any benefit. It's difficult to see the point of adding a decorative item like a plant that has no function, when you could instead place a medicine cabinet that improves the chances of a correct diagnosis. Although some players might argue that decor is important, I found that placing a picture behind the medicine cabinets achieves the same effect without sacrificing valuable space.

While Two Point Hospital is a decent enough management simulation game, it falls short in providing an engaging experience due to its lack of challenge and complexity. If you are looking for a game that truly tests your management skills, you may want to look elsewhere.

I went into Two Point Hospital, frankly, with low expectations. The art style and atmosphere prominently displayed in its marketing materials feature a parade of gurning sub-Aardman plasticine figures and a Facebook feed’s worth of dad jokes; a distinctly British kind of cringeworthy. I am also one of the seemingly few millennials not to have played Theme Hospital in my youth, meaning I come to this unapologetically nostalgia-fueled management sim with a skeptical eye. Then, opening up the game, it promptly spams you with Sega-branded ads for Sonic the Hedgehog© and the dev’s follow-up game. The opening trailer features an American drawl and ker-azy antics at odds with the rest of the game’s humour. To top it all, the ECG trace on the logo isn’t accurate. But if, like me, you have the intellectual fortitude to overlook such superficial blemishes, how does Two Point Hospital fare as a management game?

It's fantastic.

Two Point Hospital offers a series of satisfying nested micro-challenges that add up to a supremely satisfying whole. Patients will first trickle, then flood, into your hospital with an increasingly challenging array of ailments. These sickly human cash machines will need to be filtered through a series of GP appointments and investigations before a diagnosis is made and treatment is delivered for big bucks. At first, a few doctors and nurses can staff a handful of clinic rooms and a pharmacy to quash basic ailments. As both each level and the campaign progress, however, you’ll need to expand an array of diagnostics and specialised treatment rooms in order to keep financially afloat. Patients will cr- ah, defaecate, vomit and die inconsiderately unless their needs are met, covering the hospital in filth and – more importantly – depriving you of the payouts associated with treatment. This means you’ll need to employ assistants to keep patients happy, fed and watered, and janitors to scrub the decks. But they, in turn, will demand wages, break rooms and even decent working conditions. All of which costs more money. So far, so realistic.

Adding nuance are detailed systems of interior design, training, research and upgradable equipment. All involve interesting trade-offs. Training makes your staff more effective, for instance, and allows you to cultivate the specialist diagnosticians, psychiatrists, surgeons and radiologists needed to keep your machine operating efficiently in the latter levels, but also pulls both teacher and student out of the workforce for the duration of the class. To increase efficiency, you can train multiple staff in the same field, provided they all need to study the same course, but this will deplete your workforce more acutely. Call in an external tutor to take off some pressure, or learn a new skill, and you’ll need to cough up a quite chuck of change. Each of Two Point Hospital’s systems likewise offers an array of balanced options to juggle, and while the game will rarely punish you irrevocably for failure, disaster can spiral outward in fun and unpredictable ways. A horde of prematurely mummified patients descending but nowhere to treat them? No worries, take out a loan, throw up a couple of decrypters, hire some skilled nurses and get to it. Ah, but your janitors were busy cleaning up ectoplasm on the other side of the building and can’t maintain the machines; now one is on fire. That’s okay, build an extinguisher and hire more janitors. Ah, but now you’re in debt again and your only surgeon is threatening to quit because his promotion hasn’t been matched by a salary rise. Best sell the research lab (just for now) and fire your researcher. What’s this mysterious new illness and what do we need to treat it? Oh…

Every session of Two Point Hospital offers a buffet of addictive, I’ll-just-fix-this management challenges, nested within a generous and varied campaign. The UI is wonderfully-designed, drawing your attention seamlessly to any impending crises, offering buckets of data to drill down into or ignore as you wish, and with a refined suite of quality of life features like room template saving and copy-pasting. What makes the game sing is its atmosphere, which is a far cry from its cringeworthy marketing. The visual style is clean and almost restrained, though with thoughtful animation and a dedication to visual puns that suggest it was something of a labour of love. The jazzy, upbeat soundtrack perfectly matches the good-humoured gameplay and can really get stuck in your head. It’s interspersed with radio DJ voiceovers and spoof ads that barely repeated for me, more than seventy hours in, and often raised a smile. There are lots of running jokes that reward close attention, but could be happily overlooked. Two Point Hospital, in short, leans into an understated and convivial kind of humour that’s distinctly British, with notes of both Monty Python’s absurdity and Peep Show’s nihilistic self-deprecation. Wonderful stuff.

Add a generous dessert of DLC for afficianados and well-integrated Steam Workshop support, and Two Point Hospital offers a huge sandbox in which to optimise systems, muck about or watch your ant farm bustle. It’s the most fun I’ve had with a traditional management game in ages. Beyond its offputting first glance, my only real criticism is that the core gameplay loop can become repetitive, and with challenge that tends to decrease once you’ve vaulted the early game’s hurdles. It can become a battle of attrition on even the most challenging levels. Yet watching the game’s hundred moving parts tick – with obvious care and attention gone into realising every one – offers its own, meditative pleasure. A wonderful jumping-on point for the genre as well as a feast for veterans nostalgic for the “tycoon” games of the 90s, don’t miss this gem. Highly recommended.

Two Point is the ultimate in re-playable games -- it's slightly easier after the first win, since you have immediate access to more items, but subsequent games are never exactly the same because it's fairly non-linear -- you're likely to come at the levels from different "angles" by playing hospitals in a slightly different order (which you'll probably do unintentionally anyway, because who can remember the exact order, especially if you have all the optional DLCs.)  This will impact what new tech (if any) you'll need to research at any given point.  I've replayed the game many times already and no doubt will many times more in the future.  I originally bought the game because I had been a big fan of Theme Hospital, which it resembles superficially, but this new take on the concept is superior in every way.

Players are reminded: they will not have a life whilst addicted to this game.

Fun and engaging simulation game that challenges players to build and manage their own hospital. The game offers a unique blend of strategy, humor, and creativity that makes it stand out from other management games.

The game starts with a tutorial that guides players through the basics of hospital management, including building rooms, hiring staff, and treating patients. As the game progresses, players must handle a variety of challenges, such as managing staff morale, treating complex illnesses, and upgrading their facilities.

One of the strengths of Two Point Hospital is its sense of humor. The game features wacky illnesses, such as lightheadedness (where patients have a lightbulb for a head) and cubism (where patients have turned into cubes). The quirky humor helps keep the game lighthearted and fun, even when the challenges become more difficult.

The game also has a lot of replay value, as players can continue to expand their hospital, unlock new facilities and equipment, and take on new challenges. In addition, the game offers a sandbox mode, where players can build and manage their hospital without any specific goals or objectives.

Overall, Two Point Hospital is a highly entertaining and addictive game that offers a unique blend of strategy, humor, and creativity. It's a great choice for anyone who enjoys simulation games or wants to experience a lighthearted take on hospital management.

Really enjoying the game. It gives me a lot of nostalgia for Theme Hospital, which is one I really used to love playing. Highly recommend, although I'm not happy about the Superbug projects forcing multiplayer.

First and foremost, the game's graphics are downright hilarious. The cartoonish, over-exaggerated style of the characters and the medical equipment makes for a great viewing experience. You'll never get bored watching your patients' hilarious animations and the doctors' silly expressions. It's just as entertaining to watch as it is to play.

The gameplay is addictive, to say the least. You're in charge of managing a hospital and taking care of your patients. From diagnosing their diseases to performing surgeries, you have a lot on your plate. The game does an excellent job of gradually introducing you to new elements and mechanics, so you won't feel overwhelmed. But, as you progress, the game does get progressively challenging, so you'll have to put your thinking cap on. One of the most impressive features of Two Point Hospital is the vast array of diseases that your patients can have. You'll encounter a wide range of strange and bizarre illnesses, such as Mock Star, which makes your patients believe they're rock stars, and Turtle Head, which gives them a turtle's head. The list of diseases is endless, and it's always entertaining to see what the next patient will come in with.

Overall, Two Point Hospital is an excellent game. It's funny, entertaining, and challenging all at the same time. The graphics are top-notch, the gameplay is engaging, and the variety of illnesses is simply hilarious. If you're looking for a game that will make you laugh and keep you entertained for hours, then Two Point Hospital is definitely worth checking out.

Two Point Hospital is by all accounts a modernised Theme Hospital and has actually managed to make it work without disgracing the original inspiration. The original to this day still stands the test of time and this game will likely follow suit. While relatively simple and easy there's a good amount of depth if you're willing to dig into it although it's not needed to stomp the challenges. The beginning of the game plays similar to the end as you'd expect with nice variation on illnesses and problems presented. Plenty of customisation and decoration and many platforms such as Twitch throwing free decor at you. I'm not a fan of the DLC really as it doesn't add much and costs as much as many games that will give you 200+ hours playtime for a couple of hospitals. It's also on the base game map so you think you have another hospital to play, but actually when you click it that will be $$$ thanks. Guess I finished the game then, with 8+ hospitals to go... I think this is quite a dishonest and dissatisfying practice, why show it if I don't own it? ($$$). Overall a great upgrade on the original, hitting the same feeling and vibe that I'm sure old and new generations alike will cherish.

Two Point Hospital is a very much improved and updated version of the classic game called Theme Hospital. Fans of that game will enjoy this one!

The player is put in charge of running a hospital from the ground up. There are rooms to build, staff to hire and manage. There are also a whole range of items to place around the Hospital. A set amount of funds is given at the start of the game. It's up to the player to manage this money and, hopefully, make a profit!

Sometimes you need to eat or sleep, but those things are really just irrelevant with this game. Just stick a coffee machine in every room and hope for the best! xD

Really though, it's a lot of fun. I find it best for when I just want to disassociate and not use a lot of brain power. I'll play it for a stint, go away, come back, go away - it's one of those games that I sort of crave to play around with at times. It can definitely get a little mundane and repetitive once you've played it for awhile, but it's really one of those games (to me) that I can always come back to after a break when I just want to have fun. I don't find it to be super punishing - you can decorate, only use multiple of useful items, slack around, or get competitive with yourself. Tear everything down and start over, challenge yourself in different ways, change up your play style. It's really easy to do whatever you really want with it. 

I wouldn't recommend it as a super brain teaser or a spectacular challenge, just what I said above - a fun(ny) little time waster that has good repeatability and can keep you entertained for hours. Cute, snarky, and fun.

oddly satisfying and addictive game. I normally not go into management games like that, but 2 point Hospital is really in league of its own. Does require some planning in making your hospital efficient, and can be very unforgiving if you built it wrong. At the first impression it feels like relatively simple game with simple mechanics, but dont be fooled, there are layers beneath the layers. You can kinda leave your hospital manage itself or you can micromanage it to fine detail. 

Also the illnesses in game are absolutely hilarious. 

Graphics are bit candy-ish but pleasant for the eye, not some AAA cryengine raytracing madness, but it dont need it. 

also very well optimized, little to no bugs (I haven't encountered a single game breaking bug or glitch so far) Big hospitals can be bit heavy on CPU but game seems to recognize multicore quite well so it still remain playable. 

only cons I could so far mention is that sandbox options are quite limited, especially in chosing which diseases you want or not, so kiss goodbye on making small GP clinic in starting map, as 1 hour into play you will cover it just with GP's alone. 

also DLCs prices and number are criminal, only buy on discount as its relatively just few new diseases, new map and some visual stuff, just more of the same in different color basically.

As a big Theme Hospital fan in the late 90s, I bought this game presale in 2018. Although I don't want to compare since it is a different game in a completely different time, but it has the same addictiveness and humor as I hoped for.

The base game contains 15 levels, which can keep you busy for many hours. It is funny, has a good management part and very addictive.

I would highly recommend Two Point Hospital to any management game fans out there and for those who played Theme Hospital many years ago.
Working and paying healthcare workers fair wage, with proper staffing, promotion and training. 11/10 perfect power fantasy wet dream for me as a nurse

As of this writing, I have 145 hours into the game and considering playing some more. Why? It's just plain fun and Two Point Radio makes it so entertaining. The humour is great and the game doesn't take itself seriously, hence don't expect much realism. It's animated in a funny way and some of the illnesses are outright hilarious. There are a few instances when the game gets frustrating (you can sometimes just not hire the right doctor or run out of cash), but they can often be remedied by starting the level over. Lots of replay value, great music and funny humour!

Two Point Hospital is a fantastic medical simulation game, but I have to admit, I've had a bit of a rough start. You see, I'm not the most coordinated person, and I seem to have a knack for accidentally killing patients in the game. I've lost count of how many people I've "terminated" at this point, but I'm pretty sure it's over 300. Oops.

But even with my less-than-stellar track record, I still love this game. The gameplay is challenging and rewarding, and I love the feeling of curing patients and making the hospital run smoothly. The attention to detail in this game is also top-notch, with diseases and treatments based on real-world medical conditions.

And let's not forget the puns! There are so many medical puns and jokes throughout the game that it's hard not to laugh. I mean, who wouldn't crack a smile at a patient with a "cactus-itus" or a "pandemic flu"?

Overall, I would highly recommend Two Point Hospital to any simulation game fans out there. Just be careful not to kill too many patients like I did. Trust me, it's not a good feeling. But hey, at least I have a "mortality rate" for the record books.
Fun hospital simulation with progressively difficult goals.

If you enjoyed Theme Hospital from the late 90's then this is definitely a game for you. If like me you sunk more hours into that game than you care to remember then give this one a go. It is called the spiritual successor for a reason.
Same humour (the receptionist, if anything, is only becoming more sarcastic with age), same feeling, newer graphics. Plenty of levels to play through, some frustrating if you want to get all three stars, different problems to overcome or location specific issues.
One fix I am so glad for is the infectious diseases. Thankfully now the infected can wander between your hospital buildings without triggering the health inspector visit (and then as rapidly as possible hunting everyone down and evicting them from the premises to avoid as much damage as possible). They are harder to find and vaccinate but at least it gives you a chance at success.

The only downside is I miss some of the old illnesses (bloaty head, invisibility and slack tongue especially). 

Now if only we could have some more spiritual successors to Bullfrog games!!

Really fun resource management game where you are trying to run a hospital. Illnesses range from silly to overly hilarious and require some bizarre methods of treatment with specialized machinery. Everything looks very cute, but this ain't the type of hospital I want to be treated in for sure.

The management part is quite light but it is still possible to screw up. Main focus goes to humor and the ability to create/decorate all the rooms. Although from a pure management perspective, this doesn't really add that much except for some prestigue numbers making your people more happy. Most cosmetics are purely optional.

I really liked all the weird stuff going on here. Bought all the DLC's and not sure what's in what anymore. There's a lot of hospitals you can build-up. Some require unlocking first but it's up to you to decide to go fully in on one hospital at a time or toy around from one hospital to another.

Going for 100% completion will take up A LOT of time and things might get a bit tedious in the end. The different zones on the map do offer a lot to stay entertained though, so you might want to mix it up a little.

I didn't really know how I felt about writing a review until I two-starred Croquembouche and saw "cure 1,000 patients" pop up for the last star. It's the little things that bring the game down for me. Curing 1,000 patients takes forever, even with fast-forward on and a 90% cure rate. And I could forgive that if I could set up the hospital and walk away, but you can't, because the end-of year awards that I don't care about and can't turn off will pause the game. If not that, a pandemic alert. And it's not that pandemics are inherently bad, but there are only two of them, and you can ignore them entirely to basically no penalty. Honestly, once I ran out of new diseases about halfway through the base game, I realized I was only finishing the game because I knew I could, and not because I wanted to. I've spent most of my 90-ish hours watching YouTube or on my phone, just waiting for objectives to finish.

I was at first disappointed with the game: the first levels are very easy, and no matter what you do, you complete all the objectives and earn a lot of money... However, starting in World 3 (hospital no. 7), the game starts to be really challenging, and this made me appreciate it much more. From then on, I had to make a better layout of my hospital between diagnosis and treatment rooms, carefully train my staff for specific skills, etc.
I did play the original Theme Hospital in the late '90s, but no so extensively as to make a good comparision. Shame they didn't transpose their iconic illnesses like Bloaty Head, though...

I definitely recommend this game. Lots of replaybility . Fun quirky illnesses, levels are challenging enough to chip away hours of your time. It's not perfect and here are some of my changes/remarks. 
Changes points:
* Give the janitors a grid working location. This would keep janitor in specific parts of the hospital, removing dead ends and unsupervised locations as well as janitor grouping. 
* Picking up patients. On bigger maps, they have a long ways to go to get specific treatments and when they get low on health. It would be nice to pick them up. 
* sand box option. Make your own hospital template. 
* Customize you hospital floor and walls that aren't in specilized rooms. 
*A % chart that show's you each rooms stats. 
* Bathroom walls shouldn't cover exterior wall window.

Simply the best Theme Hospital spiritual successor.

You'd think that the gameplay would get stale after the first few hospitals but the drip-feed of new mechanics, along with different victory conditions for each, provide plenty of variety to keep things interesting. One thing to watch for is that a couple hospitals have conditions that render them unplayable after you win, such as requiring you to drive staff satisfaction so high that you can't maintain cash flow in that hospital afterward.

That said, be very careful about offline play if you care about the achievements at all. They are badly bugged and if you complete them while offline they'll either pop immediately when you get back online or end up locked forever.

A really nice sequel to a childhood game I played called Theme Hospital, though it does have some flaws

Pros
Nostalgic
Improved Graphics 
Humorous 
Mentally Stimulating at higher levels
Cosy Game
Creative Outlet
Some Nice CC on workshop

Cons
One save file per hospital - (If you nearly get a 3 stared hospital but mess up you cant load at the moment you got it two star you have to start from scratch rather painful in harder levels)
Art Glitches - Sometimes the doctors eyes disappear though in a way adds the the humour 
Repetitive  - If you are playing the same hospital for a long period of time trying to three star it, things get start to feel a bit stir crazy
100% Achievement behind paywall - Sadly if you want to 100% this game, you need to buy all the DLC, some of which don't have a great reputation.
Twitch Prime Rewards wont link - for some reason no matter how many times I linked the game to my twitch prime the rewards never got activated on my account after they were redeemed

Overall I do recommend the game but consider waiting for it to go on sale.

Two Point Hospital is a Builder, Management and Simulation game. The game starts with a tutorial that goes on for the first 3 or 4 hospitals that you build, every time getting a little harder. It starts very easy, though, so newbies won't have a problem. 

Pros: 
+ Nice comic graphics and animations 
+ Funny diseases and treatments 
+ Easy to learn 
+ You can play multiplayer and compete 
+ Many unlockables 
+ I haven´t encountered any bug yet 

Cons: 
- The UI at the bottom left has words instead of pictures (for instance: "Rooms", "Items" and "Hire", when it would have been better to have a square, a tool and a face, or something like that) 
- The game starts too easy, and you have to play a few levels for it to become a bit of a challenge 
- The loading page takes its time

This review is years late. I started playing it upon release because much like you I wanted Theme hospital. So, is this Theme Hospital? Yes. Absolutely yes. Is it the Theme Hospital you remember? Yes, absolutely yes. Ah, so its still a lot of addictive fun yeah?

Welllllllllllllllllllllllllll lets take the rose tinted glasses off a bit shall we? For me, this game checked off every expectation I wanted and did it in an authentic way in the exact style I wanted but after an hour I start to get bored. So, whats the problem? Why can't I play this nonstop like the original?

... Did I actually play the original for 5 hour gaming sessions, or was that a fever dream? I think it was a fever dream because as much fun as I had, and as much as I loved the style of the game i don't ever remember beating it. 

I think the original has a lot of rosy memories and this game is a sheer tribute to that. Keep that all in mind. If you want a game that you expect to keep you engaged heavily for 30+ you will be hard pressed to hit that limit, but if you want to find a modern take on some of your favorite nostalgia, you'll definitely be happy. 

I don't think I'll ever beat all the missions on this game, and you know what? It was still worth the money in my minds eye. I wanted a modern take on Theme hospital and I think I got it, but this ain't Tropico and you're not gonna lose track of time while playing it. It is fun, it is quirky, it is everything you are expecting.

Not overly complex, but challenging enough to make you sit back and strategize your next moves in the best tradition of "tycoon" games.  The game is a riot, from the types of illnesses your patients have to deal with to your methods of curing them, from the voiceover "PA" announcements or to the radio DJ making occasional comments, much of the material is laugh-out-loud funny.  The graphics are also quite unique, and again, many of the characters are fun to watch, especially if they have some amusing diseases and are moving in strange ways.  The game developers really did a fantastic job and -- as far as I can tell so far -- the game is bug-free. Well done!  Moreover, the game is highly addicting, and I've barely scratched the surface since there are levels upon levels upon levels of new hospitals, new challenges, new room types and layouts, and treatment devices I have yet to unlock. Can't wait to see what comes next.

Ever feel a little discombobulated and aren't sure where to go for help? Ever feel like you are an unhealthy  magnet for attracting random forest animals? Ever have so many ideas that your head actually morphs into a lightbulb?  Two Point hospital has you covered! 

If you like games with clear goals and a steady build-up of chaos, humor, and full of artistic variation, this is the game for you! TPH slowly gets tougher, creatively building up challenges with a healthy helping of humorous maladies. You can treat your patients and staff with care, or turn their lives upside down. Each hospital location has unique goals, from teaching and training specific educational goals for staff members, to combating a cascade of pandemics and natural disasters, and encouraging creative strategies to reach each goal. Since each hospital builds a new skill, this game is mildly repetitious, but never boring! 

I've just bought several DLC packs. I look forward to digging into the DLC and see how they compare!

3 out of 5 stars

TPH is a very accessible manage-sim, with some quirky humor. It also looks pleasant and is very easy to control. However, it also is really slow and tedious. You are basically just expanding you hospital continuously, which requires you to copy-paste rooms, build new type of rooms meant for specific illnesses and hire and train your staff. The game isn't hard at all, but certainly will feel like a slog if your machines needs frequent reparing because of earthquakes (and for some reason many levels have those) and training staff takes a while. It also doesn't help that some rooms aren't high priority in certain levels but others are, requiring you to demolish and build a copy of another room and place every mandatory item individually again (like benches, plants and radiators). You'll feel like you're constantly fixing problems. I never really took the time to appreciate the little details of the game or even the unnecesary graph tab in the menus. It is shallow busy work. 

However, as shallow as the game is, It is still decently put together with lots of content. The workshop is also a welcome addition. And for that, I find it too harsh to give this game a thumbs down.

One of these games I would recommend but still call missed potential. With a small work game could have far greater level. Instead writing detailed review you can find everywhere I just point out couple things that got my attention.

First some good things. Game is smooth and generally to play. It's simple and enjoyable gaming. So overall experience as whole game is there. Games won't need too much of a challenge as far it can keep you otherwise engaged. Can it?

There a lot of things that gets on you eventually. Before I go on some details that annoyed me I want to point out weakness of general design. Hospitals in this game feels more of a factory line medicine than actual place for healthcare. Whole point is to get people through which is logical but it kinda skips part of the game. There is little point having services other than keep quick comfort around. Your staff is only people spending time in your hospital. Patients just get through it with easiest path.

But now those little things I wished wasn't:
1) Research is not very innovative mechanic. It really is there to just unlock things and is very boring clicking game for money/kudosh which you rarely need like this.
2) Epidemics aren't fun. You don't want to visually find your patients and magically apply cure on them. Mostly not worth of the effort.
3) There is no logical illness tracking. Patients get checked randomly and head to treatment room. Certain illness should require certain diagnostics.
4) Building rooms and levels to them should be need based and attraction should be only one part of it.

So game is good but not great. Worth playing but not quite worth remembering. It just requires that last step for depth so you would like to build your own little perfect hospital.

A fun and engrossing hospital sim from some of the original folks who worked on Theme Hospital years ago. The game certainly does not feel perfect in some regards, but is addictive all the same. Numerous DLCs add different angles to the game -- some better than others. The result is an extremely wide diversity of different possible maps to master.

The career mode angle helps failed attempts feel less wasted. Earned Kudosh (to unlock new items) and research projects carry over from hospital to hospital, ensuring the more you play, the more options you have at your disposal. When you go on to can easily do things like upgrade machines or boost the effectiveness of rooms, more than just improvements in skill can push you over the line with your goals in later attempts.

[b]My Score:[/b] 9/10

[h1]Prologue[/h1]
Health, something everyone wants to keep always the best possible, but unfortunately sometimes the body fails and one beautiful night for example your head turns into a bright lamp, to treat this you will need the specialized care of a medical team with all the hospital equipment. And that's why we came here, to offer you a job opportunity as manager of our company's future hospitals, accept today and help us diagnose and cure citizens across the country, but be prepared, because lines of patients waiting for the appointment and only the beginning of a long and crazy list of things that can and will happen. ^^

After all, the country is vast and you will find everything, cities, tropical islands, snowy mountains, deserts and much more, each region with its own challenges, and of course rules, as some cities made some rather curious demands to accept our services, so it's always good to be ready for really anything from people whose heads have turned into light bulbs, even lightning storms that somehow manage to strike inside your hospital, but don't let that get in the way of your mission to bring health to the four corners of the country. ^^

[b]Pros:[/b]
+ A fun hospital simulator that perfectly fulfills the mission of being a Spiritual Successor of the famous Theme Hospital, making the mission of managing a hospital something light and fun, with high doses of comedy.
+ A vast repertoire of crazy and creative diseases, some of them have visible signs and need very fun to see working machines, while others even without visible signs, have fun and funny descriptions, along with each of the DLCs add even more unique diseases.
+ It's easy to lose track of time, managing one hospital, then the second, the third and so on, especially since each one has different goals and many have their own rules of operation, including some rules that only exist in the DLCs.
+ It is possible for hospitals to help each other, for example in the case of a new disease, to return to an older one to research improvements to the machines of newer hospitals, without needing all the research structure in the new one.
+ Great freedom when building the rooms and decorating, making the use of space very efficient, I myself never had a problem with lack of space.
+ Beautiful graphics, it is possible to perfectly see everything that happens in the hospital because all the actions of the employees, patients and machines used have well done animations, and I must say that some made me laugh, especially the totally "safe" treatments.

[b]Cons:[/b]
- A few hospitals have some goals that can be a little tricky to do, fortunately they are a very small number.
- Unfortunately, the diseases of the DLC only appear in the hospitals of said DLC, not being possible to find them in the hospitals of the main game or other DLC.

[h1] Game mechanics[/h1]
A hospital simulator where we have to assume the management role, with each new hospital we start being responsible for using our initial budget to build offices, examination rooms to find out what patients have and thus treat them, and of course receive a small remuneration in exchange, after all the hospital has to support itself. It seems simple, but with each new hospital the player is challenged, as each one has its own goals to go from zero to the maximum score of three stars, allowing you to advance to the next one. ^^

Throughout this trip, attention will need to be paid to points such as budget, queues, patient and staff needs while trying to keep everyone satisfied until reaching the peak with the healing of patients, a process that can be helped with the improvement of equipment and training of the staff, including with some functions such as psychiatry and surgery being allowed only for trained doctors. After all, patients can have everything and more, heads turning lamps and just the beginning, be ready for eyebrows that come to life, clown outbreaks, patients that get pixelated like 90's games, and much more, who knows what the next patient might have, and they all come to your hospital looking for a cure. ^^

[h1] Art and sound[/h1]
Personally I found the graphics produced by the Two Point Studios team very interesting, following a style to make people look more like play dough dolls, matching the lighter tone of the game, along with the curious and fun designs of the machines, some of them have a very interesting to see operation. In addition to the graphics, we also have the sounds, I was also very satisfied, with very relaxing music and all the machines have their unique sounds when they are in operation. ^^

[h1] Conclusion[/h1]
Two Point Hospital caught my attention since its first announcement, and for me it is a very fun game, I had already played Theme Hospital and I think this new one very well fulfills its idea of being a hospital simulator, but with a twist lighter, combining diseases imagined by the team with very dubious and crazy equipment and treatments. It is not a game for those looking for realistic hospital management, so much so that no disease here exists in the real world, but for those looking for a relaxing, fun management game capable of producing laughs with its madness and at the same time a sensation of duty accomplished by seeing patients healed, I strongly recommend this game. Even here I am anxiously awaiting the next game of the same team, about managing a university this time. ^^

If there's one word to describe this game, that it is "uninspired".

The gameplay looks simple and is simplified; a parody of how hospital works. It has many variety of jobs (doctor, nurse, janitor, assistant can do many things) yet when you start the game, they only "let" you start and then run the hospital in a very linear way of playing. You do not have that sense of freedom nor achievement because there's only so much you can do and the game doesn't give you clear explanation to certain things such as inspection or report. 

The visual and art, for the lack of better words I have, are such an acquired taste. I don't know how to react to the way they parody each illness and how to treat it; I guess it's supposed to be funny, or maybe a dark humor thing; I mean when I look at Leopard Skin... ugh, it's quite disturbing for a parody. If it's your taste, good for you, but it's definitely not for me.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you
