[quote] [h1] [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38770110/] Follow my curator page for various in-depth reviews on other games! [/url] [/h1] [/quote]

Two Point Hospital is a superb hospital management simulation that takes place in Two Point County in what I'm assuming is pseudo-America, since the prices are so damn expensive (and you can make them even more costly). You are given fixed plots of land to build rooms in which cater to different ailments and diagnostics. You can also build various types of amenities like snack machines to feed your patients and employees, and water coolers to fulfill dehydration. The hospitals are meant to be prestigious and can be rated as such in the yearly reviews, so there are many decorations to choose from like dinosaur fossil exhibits, arcades, paintings, rugs, candy machines, and of course; benches for your patients to rest on while waiting for their appointment. Each item has different buffs it comes with, whether that be the increasing of room prestige, hospital attractiveness, reducing boredom, plus many more traits. 

Unlike other management or building simulators, it's kind of impossible to delve into a negative downward spiral and lose the game. You'd have to be extremely terrible. The game is really all about perfecting the flow of patients that come in and having enough specific rooms to provide treatment for them, along with making sure they and staff have comforting environments and plenty of activities to pass the time whilst waiting. Hospital layout also matters- patients must have enough room to navigate, and you have to figure out how to efficiently place rooms in whatever plot of land you're given. Low difficulty implies relaxation, which is true to this game in particular. It rarely gets stressful unless the artificial intelligence glitches, and the mechanics of the game are easy to learn. 

One of the game's selling points is that it is goofy and has character. It introduces loads of wacky diseases from "premature mummification" and "monobrow" to "inflated ego" and "hurty leg", which are all self-explanatory by title and exactly what they sound like. Each diagnosis has varying levels of difficulty to cure and patients can even die from each illness if not treated properly. The further you get in the game, the more you find out about, and you can unlock new rooms and tools to care for your customers. Staff also have different personality traits and professional specialties that dictate their interactions with patients and other staff members, creating human drama on top of every other intricacy to add to the mix. The game lets you hire 4 types of employees, including janitors, doctors, nurses, and assistants. 

Each level establishes new logistics based on the area and description. There are areas in the mountains that can only be accessed by helicopter and must be kept warm with radiators, beach regions that tend to be scorching, university hospitals full of inexperienced doctors and nurses that are meant to focus on teaching, and many more. Sometimes your buildings can even be afflicted by natural disasters, like earthquakes, avalanches, hauntings, fires, etc. The game can get a bit repetitive, but the DLC helps amend that and tends to be very cheap. There are always goals to work towards, but there is a sandbox mode available if that's more your style. 

Two Point Hospital is a very enjoyable game that I believe anybody who likes to play building/management/simulation games would enjoy. The illnesses, inanimate objects you can build, and other mechanics are a fresh and unique take on the genre and go on forever with the staggering amount of nuance and variety it incorporates. It's a little high on the price but I do think it's worth it, but if you disagree you can always wait until it goes on sale. Regardless, I think this is a must-have for anybody's video game collection, especially if you love these types of games.

After playing on and off for over 3 years, I have decided to give the game a thumbs up.  The spiritual successor to Theme Hospital, but I always found it lacking the Bullfrog touch to keep playing through the night.  

It took me years to work out why and it is simply down to the 3 levels.  You see each hospital has three stars that you can drive towards.  Whilst it is fun to drive towards the first star, it starts to become tedious towards the second star and then monotonous towards the third.  Doing so does give rewards in the form of Kudos points which unlocks more items.  Some are essential, others are not.

In Bulldog games you started a new level each time you completed a challenge.  To go back to a one star hospital later on in the game and have to virtually collapse it all to undo the mistakes you made, in order to achieve 3 stars is not fun and I found it to be like a form of punishment.

My advice to new players, on your first foundation, go through the game only ever getting one star and then move on.  Once completed then restart with a new foundation and aim for the 3 stars.  This way you have learnt all the basics and tricks and best strategies and can enjoy the second play through.

Another game where I Wish there was a neutral option. Two Point Hospital is a cute management simulator with a lot of tongue-in-cheek humor thrown around. Overall it was a moderately enjoyable experience to play through once. Minimal bugs, and a good chunk of content. 

My problem with it is that as a management simulator, it's sorely lacking. There's not a lot of controls over your hospital or how it functions. You can restrict certain employees to certain types of work, but you can't restrict the areas they can go to. Ultimately a lot of it is just leaving the job to the AI. There's a pattern to getting the game to work in your favor, and by the time you're 1/4 through the campaign, you're playing every map the same way because it always works. The only thing left to do from there is to check off your little goal boxes. 

It's also lacking in the design department. There's no planning tools (that I could find) for setting up your hospital. You're either building a room or placing an item. No placeholder indicators for something you're reserving space for later, no templates to work with (outside of templates for the rooms themselves). 

So yeah, overall it was a fun little experience. But as a management sim: incredibly shallow, and little to no replay value.

I must say, as a big Theme Hospital fan, this here was the sequel I was waiting for. Even though it isn't a official follow up, everything really does have the same feel and atmosphere while evolving into a far superior game in it's own right.

The cartoony graphics really do fit into the overall comedic theme as nothing in this game is taken seriously. The patient's illnesses, the treatments, even the in game radio and PA continually try to poke fun. And for the most part, if I wasn't laughing, I was revelling in the fun atmosphere that is created from the visuals and sound combined.

As for the game-play, it is a blast. Plenty of features and personalisation options for just about everything. Lots of management options from wage amounts to the overall cure targets. Very balanced progression and easy learning curve. But most of all, this UI is extremely intuitive, making the game-play as a whole a breeze to pick up. 

This is just a solid game and is a must for anyone that loves their management sims. It might seem a bit pricey, but good luck finding another game like it.

As a management sim, I found it to be simple and tedious. Setting up a profitable hospital is usually straightforward, and then there's a lot of waiting. Waiting to accumulate enough money for expansions, or to upgrade machines, or to complete research projects, or to raise staff experience, or to roll new staff with better traits. These things in turn allow you to incrementally scale up or optimize your facility, but the management tasks and decision-making remain mostly unchanged. Similarly, completing level objectives often involves doing things like curing X number of patients, which, again, just comes down to waiting. Each scenario focuses on some specific challenge, but most won't be demanding enough to force you to rethink your approach. I got all the stars in the base game but wouldn't really recommend the experience.

The humor felt very sanitized and was hit or miss for me. Regardless, the game has a lot of personality, and the radio DJs and PA announcer do a decent job of breaking up the monotony. I didn't have the audio on the whole time but I'm not sure I ever actually heard one of the radio DJ skits repeat.

I think this is best approached as a building sandbox that happens to have some objectives you can complete if you feel like unlocking new decorations. I can also see the appeal if you just want a casual family-friendly management sim to kill time. Whatever the case, I'd catch it on discount.

If you ever played Theme Hospital then buy this game! Many of the developers from bullfrog are now at Two Point studios so this is the natural successor to the franchise.

This game is kind of a game of contradictions, in a very good way. 

It is both funny and cartoonish while at the same time being a very good management sim. 

Most hospitals can become solvent pretty quickly and easily but if you don't develop them properly you can soon find yourself bankrupt either because you expanded too quickly or haven't expanded enough or efficiently enough to keep up with growing demand as more patients arrive due to your hospital being good and having a good reputation.

Like most management sims there generally becomes a point you have reached critical mass and have in effect suceeded and then the challenge becomes fine tuning everything and seeing how good you can make everything and there are plenty of options to tweak and improve your hospital to make it even better...tweaking the hospital to make staff and visitor happier, tweaking rooms to make them more efficient, tweaking prices and wages to make the most profit, rerarranging the layout to make the flow of the hospital more efficient with the advantage that the game style is funny and entertaining so not only can you train the best surgeon in the world you can train a feckless idiot who smells so bad he makes people puke when he walks into the room into the best surgeon in the world.

The game does have an option to copy and paste rooms as well as save them between scenarios and certain rooms in particular you will be making over and over again, even in the same hospital.e.g. G.P. room but at the same time some of the building shapes can make this challenging but again you can just create some basic cut and paste rooms you use over and over again to complete all the scenarios as there is plenty of building space to not have to worry about having to maximise space but you can also fine tune every single room to maximise the space used in every hosiptal and make it as efficient as possible.

The game does have a progression/gating system which provides additional challenges where you have to meet certain criterior to progress and/or unlock new things although the progress/essential unlocks are pretty easy (if your having difficulty unlocking them you probably aren't ready to move on) unlocking everything can be challenging (or time consuming depending on your philosophy).

Overall this game should be enjoyable by most people where you can just play it casually and laugh while doing a basic playthrough of the campaign or you can spend spend hundreds of hours tweaking and refining the perfect hospital.
This is a must buy for any strategi/mangement game fan ! worth a buy
fun!

The spiritual successor to Theme Hospital. If you're a fan of TH then this will immediately be familiar, from the wacky diseases and the room design aspects, to the dry hospital announcements.

It's a lot of fun, if not sometimes a little repetitive. Not necessarily difficult (you can move on after 1 star on each level). But if like me you go for 3 stars on each level before progressing, some of the levels are a lot more tricky to navigate, requiring impeccable hospital optimisation and sometimes many hours of micro managing. It does however do a good job of gradually introducing new features as you progress, before throwing the ultimate challenge at you in the last hospital of each area. I did enjoy the challenge of building and managing hospitals in areas with frequent earthquakes for example and the differing climates.

The sound design is amazing, with great SFX and some memorable radio tunes. There's a making of the sounds video online where the sound engineers show their methods of creating the in game SFX, well worth a watch.

There are a few gameplay issues which annoy me and is the reason I have to keep coming back to the game, rather than putting all of my time into 3 star finishing the campaign:

- Queue mechanics are awful. Patients prioritise their needs (hunger/boredom etc) over their health. So patients close to dying who are next in line to get treated will still play an arcade game if they are bored, then die. It makes adding interesting items and things like the cafe detrimental to gameplay.
- A lot of hospital objectives are often ultimately time or money gated, especially later in the game. There were some hospitals that were much harder to achieve 1 star than 3 stars due to having more money at the end.
- The game infamously lends itself to min/maxing rooms. For example there's a tiny gold star poster that gives the most room attractiveness so it's ultimately easier to fill the every wall with a gold star rather than putting hospital themed items up. Also cramming various treatment rooms with medicine cabinets to improve treatment success.  Would have much preferred it if the staff skill alone determined room effectiveness.
- The ghost system is irritating. It seems to be about 50/50 whether a ghost spawns from a person who just died. This just adds another layer of micro management in grabbing janitors to hoover them up. Would have been nice to be able turn this off, or change it for a temporary hospital happiness debuff or something.
- The pandemic + vaccinating system is even more irritating and at times impossible. Fortunately this only occurs in certain hospitals and is not always very frequent. I just ignore it now.

Ultimately not game breaking and although I still recommend, the above have prevented me from loving this game as I feel like I should.

As mentioned I play each hospital until I have 3 stars. As of editing this review I'm 111 hours in and I'm on star 3 of the 2nd to last hospital. I have only played the campaign (no sandbox) and quit every hospital as soon as I hit 3 stars. That should give you an idea of how much of a time sink it is to 3 star all levels. Most hospitals take multiple sessions to beat and some require multiple restarts before you can get going properly.

Thankfully although the objectives can feel repetitive, none are ever overly punishing for the sake of it. The objectives are designed to push your ability to handle various different mechanics and there are normally multiple ways to go about achieving them.

There are of course many DLCs, none of which I feel add enough to the game for me to buy them until I at least 3 star all of the main game.

Finally, game performance is great. My rig is old now and was only mid ranged when I built it 6 years ago. For me it runs smooth as silk at 4k with highest settings. I did have some crashing issues last year but since reinstalling the game it is solid.

I can't believe I never reviewed this game. With the advent of Two-Point Campus, I decided to replay this game to see why I didn't like it.

My complains are mainly related to pacing. The game is painfully slow to progress but fairly easy to play. The size of objects and the layouts of the hospitals are very painful to design around and many decorative objects are locked behind a "Kudosh" currency system. What's the point of a game like this if you must unlock all the items? Decorative items level up rooms and makes your staff a lot happier but more importantly, if you make a hospital design sim like this, then you need to provide your players with adequate decorative items.

But all the stuff you need to do in the game are too slow to progress. Your staff takes a long time to train, and it takes a long time to meet all the map objectives. Since many items must be unlocked either through spending Kudosh or higher star ratings of hospitals, you are forced to play for a lot longer.

Of course you can sort of  make a nice hospital in the game. The items are relatively varied and there's a point to decorating your hospital. The game remind me of the old game "Theme Hospital" but the jokes are worse and the game is a lot simpler. This game is very PG and it shows. There's nothing necessarily wrong with being PG but in this case it makes the game feel extremely bland. The pixelated mess that is Theme Hospital doesn't have much personality, but it's still a lot more charming than Two-Point Hospital is.

The music in Two-Point Hospital is also a lot worse than Theme Hospital. I hate the constant elevator music in the game.

In addition, the developers made the game as a platform to sell DLCs through. They've tried hard to make the game relevant through ingame events. This is pretty blatant and might look like they're trying to sell the game piecemeal, however the game does have a lot of base content and is time consuming to play (if only because of grinding) and a few items (albeit thematically wrong otherwise) has been released for free over the years. I've certainly never felt the need to buy any DLCs, even though the developers invade my game with "locked areas" reminding me of that content I could have had. But I really don't care, I've had my fill of this game!

Even so, I recommend against buying this game. It shall be interesting to see if two-point campus is any better.

This game may not be a complex strategy game, but it is relaxing and funny. The first few levels are easy but more complexity is gained as you progress and more diseases are added. There are other challenges added to the game as well, such as random natural disasters, temperature maintenance, epidemic control, community hospitals where you have to complete challenges to earn money, and more. None of it is extremely difficult but that seems to be the point. The music is calming, the DJs are funny, and the diseases are all silly puns. This game isn't about being stressed, it's about relieving stress.

If you want an intense, complex strategy game then this might not be the game for you. If you just want to decompress and be silly for a while this game is a lot of fun.

Every so often a game comes along that is genuinely fun for the right reasons. Two Point hospital is such a game.
Aside from everything already said about the game, the whacky humor, the play on words, the fun animations and names etc. What made this game so much fun for me is my wife watching me play (she plays also but loves just watching). My wife has fibromyalgia and is in constant pain, watching her laugh is priceless to me. The "alternative" type whacky comedy of the game makes her smile and laugh all the time. She constantly wants me to build new rooms with new cures, laughs at watching patients hold their buts and run to the toilet, and loves the names of pretty much everyone.
Yes the game is fun, it makes me smile......it does in some way help you think better (there is a logical balancing game to be had here), yes there are achievements and stuff to unlock.
But nothing is as priceless as when I see my wife laugh and smile.
The best download for me in years :):)

[i] [b] Two Point Hospital [/b] [/i] is a very funny medical sim. Your staff will be curing a variety of weird illnesses, from verbal diarrhoea to inflated ego and much more unusual ones. You’ll probably discover one or multiple diseases which symptoms will make you chuckle. But giggles won’t pay the bills! You’ll have to play smart stay out of debt, keep an high reputation and retain a good cure rate even when the amount of patients increase rapidly.

The levels in the career mode will gradually throw more and more stuff at you to deal with, which makes for a really good way to learn the game. After having done a decent amount of hospitals, it’s very fun to go back to your older ones and improve them with your new knowledge. 

I’d definitely recommend the base game, it’ll take you plenty of hours to complete. I have not tried any DLC yet, but ot tastes like more!

[hr] [/hr]

[h1] Favourite quote [/h1]
“Please leave the toilets as you’d like to find them, not as you expect to find them.”

[h1] Little warning [/h1]
The last hospital in the career mode will get laggy, be sure to lower your graphics a bit before jumping into this one.

[h1] 7.8/10 [/h1]

[h1]Two Point Hospital[/h1]
[u]"Announcement! Try not to die."[/u]

Really late to the review on this. 

Bullfrog memories and company chat before review.

This was with out a doubt one of the games I looked forward to most of 2018. Used to love Bullfrog back in the day, even lived down the road from their Guildford offices. After EA purchased Bullfrog in 1997 offerings took a decline in quality then were shelved permanently (Standard EA) Rip, Westwood, Maxis, Bullfrog (Insert many other great companies here)

When I heard that two point studios were forming in Farnham (Down the road) with Mark Webley and Gary Carr at the helm (Theme Hospital / Bullfrog) I was hyped.

When the game finally released it was what I had hoped for. A true spiritual successor to Theme Hospital with the same albeit improved gameplay and wacky humour that the original had. The fear I had is that they would get bought out again and ruined like in the past. 

Then in 2019 they announced they had been purchased after only 2 years of being in business.  I was initial bummed out and a bit sad, but then I found out that SEGA had purchased them as a subsidiary. My love for SEGA is so strong at the moment for them publishing incredible games like Two Point Hospital and Motorsport Manager and also brining the incredible Yakuza series to the western PC market. When I heard this I was pleased for Two Point Studios and cannot wait to see what the future holds for them. They have already teased the idea of making games within the Two Point world based off of old Bullfrog titles. We may get a remake of the original Theme Park (Not World or Inc please)

The gameplay for Theme Hospital veterans will feel familiar and you will be able to jump right in and feel at home. The game has had so many quality of life improvements over the original and has Steam workshop to add community items and music packs.

If you want a real nostalgia blast add this music pack, [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1745929263] Theme Hospital Music Remastered [/url] 

Instead of just moving from hospital to hospital around the game board like in Theme Hospital this time you make a foundation. Once you complete a level you can move to the next hospital but your original hospital remains as you left it and you can go back and play it anytime you wish. Loads of hospitals all with different challenges and illnesses.

A cavalcade of new illnesses. No Bloaty Head, Slack Tongue or invisibility here. From Mock Star (Great Freddie Mecury joke) to Headcrabidness (Half life headcrab yes) the crazy illnesses and ways they are cured is a silly and fun as the original Theme Hospital.

Friends leader boards, the Superbug project which allows you to assist your friends to unlock kudosh and special items. Yearly trophy awards.

The team at Two Point Studios are very active within the community. Listening to community suggestions and bug fixes etc. They just added room templates which is awesome! 

Their social media team even surprised me the other day by sharing my screenshot on Facebook.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2187518470

As an OG Theme Hospital player I really don't have anything bad to say about this game. Its a nostalgia bomb and just a fantastic game. I cannot wait to see what is next from Two Point Studios

[i][u][b]Trail-Dave[/b][/u][/i]

[i]”Players are reminded to stay hydrated”[/i]

Our Team

- Two Point Studios is a creative and fun development studio, specialising in management sim games rooted in our own brand of silly humour! We’re a young, vibrant studio that has the added advantage of nursing veterans from some of the UK’s greatest creative studios – BullFrog, Muckyfoot and Lionhead, having collectively worked on (among others) Theme Hospital, Black & White; Startopia; Fable; and The Movies.

This game is really fun for the first 15 or so hours but beyond that it starts to become a slow and boring process of making sure every part of your hospital is warm, has plants, ... Also, the break room makes it so much more difficult to manage and make sure you have enough employees of each type of work because you end up either hiring too many people or not realizing you don't have enough.

I think it's a good idea to make you build new hospitals from scratch IF these new hospitals were different enough from the previous ones to not make it feel repetitive but sadly that's not the case, each new hospital adds the potential for 1-2 new rooms you didn't previously have access to but that's it and honestly it's not worth rebuilding a hospital just to get access to 2 new rooms.

Each illness is presented as being new and unique BUT that's not the case, each illness is almost identical. Diagnose the problem and send them to the correct treating room, get them treated and voila, a "new" illness.

This game has a great potential that could easily be reached with a few tips:
- Avoid making us build new hospitals from scratch without having a massive game-changing twist or spin to mechanics.
- Allow us to choose what illness we want to tackle next instead of dropping patients on us.
- I hate mono-brows, It's just annoying manual work that we have to remind ourselves to do

ORIGINAL REVIEW - PLEASE SEE ADDITIONS BELOW FOR WHY THE SWING TO POSITIVE.  MINOR SPOILERS IN SECOND REVIEW.


It's a negative but only just.  

   It runs fine, I'm not aware of any crashes so far.  It's bright and colourful with lots of amusing animations.  As the game develops there are more and more rooms to unlock for both analysis and treatment.  There are lots of objects to add to rooms, some of which need to be unlocked by tasks - and a lot, disturbingly and irritatingly, of seemingly misplaced Sonic themed items.  There's a lot of content, some of it quite funny, on the incessant in game radio shows.  The announcer has a lot of lines too.

  So why the negative vote ?  This is an issue you'll only encounter after putting 20+ hours into the game.  The game is heavily weighted towards payment for cures.  Diagnosis is basically a loss leader with the expenses barely covering your doctor or nurse costs.  So the two most basic "cure" room s are Pharmacies and Wards, both available from virtually the start of the game.  But 2.0 Hospital unfairly in my view frequently starves you of the more basic illnesses so you constantly end up with that even with an overcrowded and understaffed hospital you're still not making enough money to cover costs.  You can end up spending long times just watching your hospital spiral deeper and deeper into debt with realistically nothing that you can do about it.  This isn't fun.

  For anyone's who's played Theme Hospital it's very similar but with obvious updates for a game made decades later.  The blatant sexism of Theme Hospital with all Doctors and Janitors being male and all nurses female has been removed in Theme 2.0 hospital.  Earthquakes and epidemics are back  but so far they've been nowhere near as lethal as under the previous game.  Research takes far longer but perseveres to all future hospitals - you never have to research the same thing twice.

  I've played a lot of Sim Games - Theme Hospital to conclusion multiple times, Theme Park, Rollercoaster Tycoon 1,2 and 3 and all versions of Tropico up to 5, completing 4 and 5.  So I know how to play Sim Games.  IMHO 2.0 Hospital is too difficult on the mid levels onwards to be fun.

S.x.

REVISED REVIEW - REFERS TO ORIGINAL REVIEW

  I was wrong and dumb.  I'd been increasing staff salaries on promotion from content to happy which bled my profit margin.

  Game tips - start off with these basic rooms as soon as you have them and can afford them - GP's office, Pharmacy, General Diagnosis, Cardiology, Psychiatry (if you have an appropriately qualified doctor), Ward, Toilets, Rest Room all of which should be decorated and facilitated to a good to high standard.  There's a very useful button on the staff tab that allows you to meet all salary demands that should be used regularly to keep staff content.  Add research later unless you need to research a new disease to progress in which case it should be prioritised.  Add new doctors and nurses when you're finding that there are delays in staff answering the calls to a room.  This way you won't get overstaffed.  On the main option screen I reduced the queue warning from six to five - persistent queues of six and higher impair performance badly.  I made cure percentage 100% rather than 95% - death rates are high enough without guessing at cures but checked the option that patients who had 100% diagnosis didn't need to go back to a GP's office for a final diagnosis - you'll already need a dozen or more GP's offices in a large hospital and they're a loss leader, a break even at best.

  So further impressions having finished the game ?  First the good.

  Contrary to my dumb original review the levels are all logically winnable (maybe not the public level - see below)  with a set strategy taking you through all levels.  It's a question of prioritising purchases according to profit.  Note that an epidemic will normally more than pay for the room to treat it and at times you will have to take out loans.  My main joy was the huge amount of content in the radio shows - I think I hadn't heard all of it by the time I three starred the last level (what was in the box ?) and the content varied between mildly amusing and genuinely funny.  For a game that can get repetitive this was a worthwhile investment by the developers and much appreciated.  Earthquakes and epidemics are inconveniences rather than absolute disasters like they could be in Theme Hospital and epidemics are far fairer although in a huge hospital they're difficult to spot in such a mass of people.  The skill trees  were a welcome addition from Theme Hospital but research was more equivocal - narrowly in favour of 2 point hospital overall.  It remained colourful, robust performance wise, and endearing right to the end.


The bad ? The "public health" level is horrible - you don't get paid for cures but for arbitrary tasks which messes up your planning completely.  The last two levels were time intensive with much time spent just waiting for figures to clock up to progress level - similar to the original in fact.  There's no "victory" screen at the end of the game - unless it comes from three starring every hospital - just credits which was disappointing and a definitely worse than Theme Hospital which had a good (if now very chunky) end video.  The muzak that backgrounds the game is unlike the DJ commentaries repetitive and dull.

Having now three starred the final level I'm unlikely (1) to try and three star everything (2) to pay out for the comparatively far more expensive DLC.  The game is good, colourful fun but the 93 hours I put into it more than scratched my itch for replaying a Theme Hospital type game.  Now the new game with setting up a university campus - that I'm price tracking.

However for the current sale price of £6.24 or lower you're getting a good, fun game that should keep you pleasantly engaged for many hours which is definitely more than good enough.

And to the devs sorry for my original review.  I got it wrong.

One of those games that is still relevant and updated in 2022! This title has been filling a space in the gaming cupboard without ever coming out to play, until three days ago! 

Music - The catching tunes that will run through your head while cooking or doing laundry afterwards. The elaborate radio host and range of songs is incredible and amusing. I found myself chuckling often when the host started speaking.

Graphics - While this isn't an RPG AAA shooter, the graphics are of outstanding quality. The only thing I found a shame was when zoomed in, the wallpapers from the base game were a bit blury.

Animations - After a while I realised some of my hospital was on fire, because I was watching all the different kinds of swoops, swishes and devilishly mean animations some of the machines have. The Jab machine is most satisfying! ~Ofcourse the fire was my fault for forgetting extinguishers. ~

Building - Incredibly easy and straightforward. Getting them upgraded though, thats the real challenge! Downloading a few textures for the walls and floor from the Workshop is mandatory in my opinion!

Worth my money? Yes. I even bought all the DLC within a day!

When I heard there would be a spiritual successor to Theme Hospital I was extremely excited. Management sims like this keep me sane because I can manipulate every factor in a simulated environment, so a refresh on a personal favorite was exciting. It lived up to it's promises and has abundant charm, wit, and adds new mechanics and challenges to keep you playing. R.E.M.I.X. mode has been great for me as someone with 30 stars to enjoy a new game mode while still keeping the same basics.

Theme Hospital fans will love the room templates, the nostalgic charm, new illnesses, and new game mechanics (Epidemic, R.E.M.I.X., radio customization, HOURS of radio host content, etc). The vomiting sound is also far less repulsive.

There is some room for improvement, however. DLCs only seem to add new illnesses rather than changing game play, and getting new items is challenging if you don't have any friends who play. The global research mechanic where you complete tasks for items is, while interesting, a hindrance to those of us who do not want to add strangers to our friends list and wonder who "Bimbo Baggins" is after a few months when they change their display name and icon. My criticisms are minute compared to the praises I have for this game. If you enjoy tycoon games/management sims, this should be at the top of your list. Or you can get Theme Hospital from GOG and see if you hunger for more...

That said, I don’t actually own any of the DLCs (except for the few free ones) and haven’t even played through the whole game, meaning I didn’t run out of content yet.

Two Point Hospital is an enjoyable sim game. There are many options to build up your hospital as well as an overall career story to play. New options continue to open up as you play the game and handy tips pop up frequently to give you some idea of what you might want to consider next. Its easy to get absorbed in creating the perfect hospital, there is so much to take in to consideration from staff, training, what facilities to build and upgrade and limited time challenges to bring prestige and currency awards to your hospital network. The more you play the more options that unlock including items and upgrades and even new facilities. I would definitely recommend this game to people that enjoy sim games, I find it a perfect way to unwind after a busy day.

Two Point Hospital is a fun and modern remake of Theme Hospital. It's a well-made and technically solid game. I have two main complaints. First, the default prioritization of patients is a bit dumb. It's just first-come-first-served, so I frequently have to move patients around queues to treat the most unhealthy patients first, and this can be tedious. Second, the game is a bit slow-paced. I often wish I could run it at 5x speed or something because it'll probably take like 100 hours to get three stars on all of the levels. There are a lot of levels, and they aren't all that different from each other, so the game feels rather samey long before it's over. (Although each level has a quirk, the basic gameplay is the same for all of them.)

Overall, it's fun but I imagine trying to finish it would be tedious.

As a totally real, totally accomplished, "doctor" who graduated from the university of WebMD, I can attest that this game is medically accurate in all its various diagnoses.  I have personally cured many cases of Verbal Diarrhoea, Misery Guts, Inflated Ego, Premature Mummification, Hurty Leg and many many more illnesses in a single days work.  I am proud to say that this game appreciates all my various skills at doctoring as well as administrating, researching and marketing. I am highly decorated in all of these areas.

Seriously tho, this game is a super fun hospital management sim. It gives you hilarious illnesses to cure in the craziest of ways. There are tons of hospitals that come with the base game, and each one presents a unique scenario to overcome. Each expansion adds more hospitals, and illnesses to cure. If your looking for a game that you will spend hours playing, then Two Point Hospital is just what the doctor ordered.

Its a good game, fun and can play at your own pace. Pretty good successor to Theme Hospital though doesn't quite catch its charm.

I have three big issues with the game:

1: Every game plays the same. Despite the occasional map quirk every hospital can be built the same which means once you have completed 3 or so maps you will naturally want to design them the same. The game doesn't really provide a reason to change up your room designs or general layout of the hospital. This means for me I can only play 3-4 hours every couple weeks to keep it fun an interesting.

2: You are never in any real danger. Once you get set up the money just flows and you are simply waiting for enough to drop the next room. Some maps have specific events but there isn't any like a "mass cas accident you are forced to take" or "someone is sueing the hospital" etc. Its actually hard to lose a map and I have never come close. On that note killing patients seems to have little repercussions. I have 2-3 patients die a month and no one cares, I have fuming patients that leave because they haven't been treated in over a year and nothing happens. 

3: Friend assisted research. I am guessing this is hear to encourage you to get your friends to buy the game and help you? Since none of my friends play this game and I have no intention searching online for random people this whole feature is walled off to me.

Other points: No ambient life outside the hospital, only one level no additional floors or basement, no real personality with the staff (they have quirks but none of it plays out in game).

I recommend the game, its really the only good successor to theme hospital, but it does have some big dings against it.

I found this hospital management game easier than Project Hospital! It's more polished and the tutorial was easy. I like that I can easily move objects and whole rooms. Although, I don't like K cash because I prefer to use money to unlock things. It gave me the impression if I needed to pay something to get more K cash? I also don't like the room size limitation. I would like to have different sizes of rooms not just 3x3. I do understand each furniture takes a certain size of space, but I feel it's limiting. I want to efficiently use every space and corner. In comparison, Project Hospital's building design is more Sims like. I have more control and I can build smaller rooms which I really like. Also, this game has more cute assets but they don't represent the real equipments like in Project Hospital. I first played Project Hospital, but I got impatient and I didn't want to waste my time. I only had 2hrs to test it. I couldn't finish the Tutorial because I think there was a problem with the 2nd floor. I enjoyed building and managing in both games though. I just found this game more easier to play. I do want both games though, but for now I will play this game. And yes, I would recommend it. If you ever feel in your tummy that you want to role play as a doctor or micro manage a hospital, this will fit your feelings.

As a Septuagenarian ( or Caveman, as some have said ) with little game play experience, I have found the many hours playing this game rewarding and lots of fun.
   I highly recommend this game. Fun for all ages and eases you towards the tougher levels gradually.
   I definitely needed to read the guides and used the discussion pages often in the early days to help navigate my progress but quickly started to play and adapt to the positives and negatives of Staff, Rooms and Equipment etc.
   I also now know that there is an easier way or a funner ( is that a word ?) way to play, but for me I prefer the option of not loading up on "gold stars" etc and try to build a "nice" environment as it raises this old mans happiness level. ( Although I have gone the quicker fix at times )
   Having a Sandbox is great for building crazy stuff and the younger ones had tons of fun experimenting, creating havoc and destruction.
   All in all a blast has been had by those who have had a crack at my game.
   Good luck if you decide to have a go.
   Cheers Al

tl;dr: It's fun enough, but gets very samey very quickly.

Two Point Hospital (Two Point Studios, 2018) is a hospital simulation game in the vein of old 90's games like Theme Hospital - indeed, many of the same developers from Bullfrog Studios formed Two Point Studios nearly 30 years later!

In Two Point Hospital, you play as an administrator hiring doctors, nurses, janitors and assistants, laying out the hospital and otherwise making sure that the patients are reasonably happy and not keeling over dead in the middle of the hall.

First things first: the animations in this game are great. From the little things like the walk cycles to the more obvious ones like the treatment animations where are pretty much all unilaterally funny. Unfortunately, you're often playing quite zoomed out and on 1.5x speed, so you don't often get to examine the animations close-up unless you're going out of your way to do so, but regardless, a lot of time and effort was put into this.

What about the gameplay? Well... this is where Two Point Hospital starts to fall apart a bit. The basic loop of a patient is as follows:
1. The patient arrives, and a front-desk assistant guides them to a GP's office.
2. The patient meets the GP, and gets a partial or complete diagnosis of their issue.
3. If the diagnosis is incomplete, the patient goes to a more-thorough diagnosis room, like a General Diagnosis or a MEGA Scanner. 
4. If the patient's diagnosis level is below the user-defined threshold (90% accuracy by default), repeat steps 2 through 4 until the diagnosis is above that threshold
5. Once the diagnosis is complete, they go to the appropriate treatment room and get treated.

This is the core loop of the game: making sure the above 5 steps go by as quickly as possible. As such, the game is really more of a layout simulator, putting rooms at appropriate locations such that patients don't need to travel far, duplicating rooms that are bottlenecks to increase patient throughput, and minimizing distractions to patients. And this is where the first major issue of the game rears its head.

Each patient has five sliders: hunger, thirst, and bladder, which are self-explanatory; boredom, which can be resolved via reading material, arcade machines, fountains, etc.; and health, which is essentially the patient's 'timer'. If their timer runs out, they die, you take a hit to your reputation, and you might even have a ghost show up, spooking your other patients and staff. And if any of the other sliders runs out, they leave the hospital angry, also taking a hit to your reputation. The thing about this is: because the most important thing of the game is getting patients through the medical process quickly, handling any of these sliders is basically pointless. Hungry patients will leave their lines to go buy snacks, even if they're next in line for the room, holding up not only their treatment, but the treatment of everyone behind them. So, counterintuitively, it's best to ignore all the sliders until you can easily afford good ways of handling the other sliders, like treating boredom with fountains, which take only a second per patient and can handle four patients at once.

Further, the money situation in the game is pretty shakey. When you're going for your first star in any given level, it's fairly good - your income is pretty low, but managable. But it's pretty trivial for the amount of money you get to snowball, leaving you with millions and nothing to spend it on in the mid- and late-game. Getting 2- and 3-star ratings in most levels was just a function of training up all my staff as best I could and otherwise keeping the window open long enough to meet whatever arbitrary goals I needed (usually some variation of 'cure 100 patients')

Maybe it's just me, but the game also has a lot of cruft that you should never reasonably use if you're trying to play efficiently. There are tons of lovely placable items to make your hospital rooms feel like real hospital rooms - but it's much cheaper and more efficient to just plaster treatment room walls with gold-star diplomas to get that important prestige rating up (so, maybe not that different from real life, after all...?). There are a lot of different diagnosis rooms - but you really only need three, max. I literally never used an X-Ray when I could just train up a doctor to use the way better MEGA Scanner instead, and I stopped using the fluid analysis when I realized the animation took 10,000 years without an appropriatly-good bonus to diagnosis. There are news stands, gift shops, cafes... none of which are actually useful, for the above reasons of just getting in the way of efficient play.

As far as the music goes, it's fine. Very catchy, but in a bad way. I found myself incessantly humming some of the background music, even though I didn't especially like it. The soundtrack, being diegetically a radio, has occasional ads and host breaks, which are mostly funny but start to repeat themselves pretty quickly.

There's a number of other things I didn't really get to experience, like the multiplayer challenges or Superbug System (none of my friends are playing a sim game from 4 years ago, bizarrely) or the REMIX levels, and I skipped out on the DLCs, which are pretty expensive for only adding 3 more levels each and a number of new diseases (which are, honestly, the least interesting part of the game, since it fundamentally just means you need to build New Room to treat New Disease).

If the game had more variety, I'd be more generous to it. There's one level, Duckworth-upon-Bilge, that I really loved because it turned the above loop on its head by preventing income from any source besides regular challenges and emergency treatments. But largely, most of the game's 15 levels are just glorified tutorials for individual game mechanics. "This is the Hot Level", "This is the Cold Level", "This is the Surgery Level", "This is the Epidemic Level", etc., etc. One-star ratings were more than enough for this, and going for two- and three-star ratings ended up being more tedious than anything else.

Oh, also, the game is WILDLY expensive at full price and regularly goes on sale for sub-$10. Don't buy this at full price!

Overall? It's okay. If you're a completionist, you're gonna have a miserable time going through the super-tedious and easy two- and three-star objectives, but you can have a nice time taking it easy, playing sub-optimally and only going for the basic objectives in each stage.

I love this game. I do. It's rare for me to write a review but I felt compelled to after I surpassed the 200 hour mark.

For those who know what it is - it's Theme Hospital. I mean, it's a new take on it, so let's call it Theme Hospital 2.0. I love Theme Hospital, have it on Origin and still play it from time to time, but Two Point Hospital is one of those 'remakes' that  actually really does scratch that itch.

I find it very addicting building the hospital ground up and trying new layouts, and the game has genuinely made me laugh out loud with it's illnesses and descriptions. The radio hosts and the reception voices, while repetitive after a while, I find charming and also very funny, especially if you enjoy dry humor.

The cons of the game are after a while it becomes the same thing over and over. While there are a few objectives that are harder than others, at the end of the day it's still just the same gameplay loop in every level.

Another thing, like many games now a days, is there are many different expansion packs that all give 3 levels, some fun, some meh, but if you are purchasing retail prices it can turn out VERY expensive for honestly not that much more content. To be fair it does go on sale often.

Overall it is one of my favorite games of all time, a worthy remake, and the base game is well worth the price, and even better on a deal.

If you were a fan of theme hospital back in the day then this is perfect for you.
I really like the gradual introduction of all the mechanics in the game, because they're a lot and it gets very complex!
I recommend only getting to one star on a hospital then moving to the next one, as more things 'unlock' as you go through them then come back to the others

Hello friends,

Today i will review TWO POINT HOSPITAL. This game is a spiritual success to Theme Hospital. If you never played theme hospital, this game plays alot like it, but also has newer things, including costumes for doctors, epidemics, new diseases, even new illnesses. This game is more like a newer version of theme hospital, but with all the bells and whistles the original game did not have. There are also many things about this game that are quite fun. If you love micro managing games, this one you will really enjoy as a simulation game, even if the game does not take itself serious with all the funny diseases and such. The game can actually be challenging on the higher levels, or getting three star hospitals. Anyways, here are my pro/cons:

PROS:

- Cartoony diseases and funny ways to treat patients.
- Micromanging at it's finest.
- Silly costumes for your hospital employees.
- Challenging on harder levels and three start hospitals.
- Lots of dlc to add to the game new things.
- Steam workshop support so you can add even more items to your game.



CONS:

- A few minor bugs i ran into, including some lag, minor stuttering, and even a superbug project that kept staying in my superbug project page. It eventually went away though.
- Repetition seems to be the worst thing in the game. After awhile, every level and goals feel the same, even if there somwhat different. I suggest if you get bored, take a break from playing, then come back to this game after awhile.

RECOMMENDED! This game can be fun if you love micromanaging games and simulators. This game is not for serious hospital simulation players. There is another game on steam for that. The game is fun, but after awhile, can become repetitive.

[h1]Two Point - Theme - Hospital[/h1]
[b]Two Point Hospital[/b] is the spiritual successor to EA's Theme Hospital by Bullfrog. [i]However[/i], I don't feel that it's productive to directly compare the two, they're different games.

[u][b]Premise[/b][/u]: On its face, [b]Two Point Hospital[/b] is a satirical hospital sim/management game. But it's actually a [i]syndicate[/i] — or a conglomerate management sim of multiple hospitals going across all of Two Point County — there are 15 total Hospitals in the base game, each with their own climates and challenges. There's also a R.E.M.I.X version of all the hospitals which has a different set of challenges — a sort of wave mode. Ultimately, the main goal is to increase the value of your organization, not [i]just[/i] the individual hospitals.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
The main mode is the career where you build multiple hospitals for the organization.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2479132513
But there is also a sandbox mode with a number of customization settings. There's also [u]Steam Workshop[/u] support.

The general loop is [b]diagnose, treat, expand, repeat.[/b]

[h3]Unique and positive aspects:[/h3][list]
[*] You don't specifically need to be aware or remember what treatment facilities are needed for specific illnesses that show up in the hospital you're currently working  in, they'll tell you what's needed if you don't have it. Of course, knowing would allow some level of preparation to occur.

[*] Any and all research achieved is used organization wide for any hospital.

[*] Though this could be viewed as a negative by some, the game can feel a little faster paced at times compared to many other management sims — this is due to the fact you're able to completely rearrange a hospital to suit the needs of any specific event as there is [u]no building time[/u] for rooms or items. Only expansion into additional annexes take time to build.

[*] When less pertinent research is needed for treatment methods, you can generalize research to generate both cash and kudosh.

[*] The Wallace & Gromit aesthetic is fantastic.[/list]

[h3]Neutral aspects:[/h3][list]
[*] The Super Bug Initiative is an interesting idea that requires collaboration between real life  players performing objectives. In the absence of players trying to complete those goals, it feels like a very tacked on feature.

[*] Sometimes genuinely funny.

[*] The UI is very clean, so much so that it feels like a mobile game.

[*] [u]It's very grind-y.[/u] Which means two things — there's a lot of [i]game[/i] to it, but your internal reward system i.e., dopamine, might get a little bored on occasion. The achievements are also pretty grind-y. Of course, they're completely optional.

[*] Some hospitals introduce or focus on temperature. It's not as in-depth as something like Prison Architect where you'd need to build a hot water heater and place a piping system in. In this you can just place a radiator anywhere and it'll have its own area of effect.

[*] Sometimes marketing campaigns feel like they only exist to complete odd objectives that don't fit the hospital's theme in what is an otherwise interesting feature used to recruit specialists.

[*] The game is always comparing your stats to other players on your friends list, which is cool for motivational purposes but it's also kind of grating.[/list]

[h3]Less than desirable aspects:[/h3][list]
[*] Each hospital gives you certain star ratings by introducing seemingly arbitrary objectives that don't inherently fit their theme. But this is largely only for ratings beyond 1 star.

[*] There's very little compelling reason to increase prestige beyond completing specific objectives or subjective cosmetic design e.g., fridges and filing cabinets don't actually do anything but increase room level/prestige. They're considered decorative items. Conversely, medicine cabinets, while not required slightly increase treatment and diagnosis percentage.

[*] Extra cosmetic [or otherwise] items not unlocked through regular progression are unlocked through redeeming “kudosh” points which are rewarded through completing objectives. Which makes early game decoration rather banal.

[*] Every room type essentially acts the same, regardless of extra furnishings. You're able to literally copy and paste them, making customization less meaningful as it won't actually affect much.

[*] In early stages of a hospital with numerous illnesses, it can be difficult to get started due to the need to train your employees or perform research on new disease treatment. While performing research or training, you don't have access to those employees. So you either suffer the loss of revenue and reputation by not treating them or you can take out a loan and hire people to do the more mundane tasks with the contingency that people with required skills are available.

[*] You're  unable to change the outer walls of any the hospitals, you can only to expand into pre-designed annexes/plots. You [b]are[/b] able change any inner walls, however.

[*] There are not many [b]micro-managing[/b] features. I list this as a negative because it can be difficult at times to get your employees to do what needs to get done. Essentially, there are only a few methods to do this, either disallow them into certain types of rooms or increase/decrease the frequency that numerous employees can take breaks at the same time. There's a fair amount of it being automated provided the needed elements are in place. You can manually tell them to go back to work or take breaks, but this can become tedious with large a staff. For patients, you can send them directly to treatment or move them around in the queue.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2478456737

[*] Employee's happiness boils down to amount of pay and breaks — that's it. VIP guests care about cleanliness and attractiveness more which can bolster or hurt reputation.

[*] Hospitals can get pretty big in the later stages. 10+ plots, which can be very chaotic.

[*] Some mechanics are not made clear, diagnosis seems to be based on skill of doctors, nurses, upgraded equipment — the EZ-Scan to Fluid Analysis. There seems to be some level of RNG. Even after all my time, I'm still not sure.

[*] I had a few bugs. — Ex: One of my nurses kept saying her path was blocked even though she was in the middle of an open ward.[/list]

[h3]Misc:[/h3]
I don't know if the game intended this, but when more elaborate hospitals were introduced, I ended up going back to older hospitals to do research to avoid needless loss of reputation and revenue in new hospitals — even after having achieved 3 stars on previous ones. Which makes the game feel very grind-y.

Between the time that this game was released and me writing about it, Sega purchased Two Point Studios.

[h1]The Gist:[/h1]
As a spiritual successor, I can understand why many are ambivalent. It simply doesn't feel that special. Furthermore, I wouldn't put money on “the kids of today” holding this game in the same regard as “us 30 year old millennials” do for Theme Hospital. Likely the same scenario for Bullfrog [in general].

That said, I think Two Point Hospital is game that clings to the past. I can recommend it as a filler/palette-cleanser. And while it has a fair amount of depth, it's not that difficult to drop and pick back up. 

The biggest issue is that I don't see many people playing it beyond their initial threshold, its longevity simply isn't worth the time investment. The variability between hospitals isn't enough to keep you coming back. After the 7th hospital, 25-ish hours in, I realized I wasn't having fun anymore. I was only after achievements.

It feels a little wrong giving it a thumbs down. But I don't think it's really worth your full attention.

I don't know if I'm missing something major, but I found some of the core mechanics of this game quite frustrating. To start off with, the art direction is fun, the ailments are silly and the basic designing of a hospital is satisfying. For both me and my partner that got us interested and in the door.

As the game progresses though, the optimization requirement really kicks in and it is both unclear and incredibly unfun. Things like ensuring you put up art on every wall, even if it's the same piece a hundred times. Training staff is clunky and annoying. The stream of patients seems to always test your max capacity, so unless I was missing some core mechanic, you could never be "on top" of the demand for hospital use. If you got more staff, you started getting more patients flooding in. It always had me sitting behind the curve of success. There was a level where all of your doctors started off poorly trained with the benefit that you got paid for training on the job. But the hospital was always brimming with patients, so I struggled to find time to do any training. Failed treatments lowered your hospital ratings, which affected your ability to complete levels and move on.

I don't know if I was missing some simple core mechanics of the game, but it felt like you ended up worse off as you built up your hospital, so later levels became more of a headache then an engaging management time.

It's bright, it's bubbly and doesn't take itself seriously. A really fun, easy going management game with really well looked after content. If you like management games like the Sims? This is worth a go and worth the money.

Theme Hospital Tw...uhhh I mean Two Point Hospital
Some 20 years on we got a successor, and it has a lot to live up to.

TPH follows the same style as its progenitor - limited story, focus on management and completing objectives to unlock subsequent levels, very un-serious tongue-in-cheek style. So far so good right?
In fact, there's very little other than the (mediocre) graphics that has changed, and that's actually a problem. See, although Theme Hospital was (is) a very good game, it was released in the 90's, and as such had a number of issues and limitations that came with the times. These are all still here, but it's not the 90's anymore.
There are still too many bugs with patients getting stuck in places they shouldn't. The hospitals are too small and in weird shapes, making room placement problematic at best (and efficient placement often impossible). The staff available to hire are often made terrible with either bad traits, or training combinations that make them inefficient or ineffective. It tries a bit too hard to be funny and ends up in that awkward place of seeming bland. Animation time for everything is incredibly slow so takes ages for thing to actually happen - and it's not in line with other timers in the game (day/month progression, health decay time, challenge timers).

But worst of all is the queue and job management algorithm. This is so bad it gets it's own section in this review, and is in large part responsible for it being negative.
Here's a few examples:
-Janitors assigned to [i]only[/i] repair machines will wander around "looking for work" when there are machines that are not at full health. They will only take action when there is a machine below 50%. There is no way to adjust this.
-Sometimes the game will decide to send all patients to a single reception desk (even when there are 5+ desks, and 100+ patients). When removing the desk (to try and make it recalculate and fix a problem that shouldn't even exist), all 100 simple go to another single desk, instead of being split. This happened multiple times across multiple levels.
-When attempting to staff a room, it will sometimes pull staff out of an idle room 2 buildings over rather than the "looking for work" staff member (of the correct type) nearby.
-Patients being added to a room queue will get added to the far away room with a queue of 1 rather than the nearby room with a queue of 2. Why is this a problem? Because the walk time for this is often far longer than simply waiting in the closer "longer" queue.
-If a machine sets on fire and has to be put out, it will remain on low health. The janitor does not then automatically fix it, and will likely leave the room, allowing patients in to use the machine again. Which sets on fire again. How this got allowed to release I'll never know.
-Patients in a queue will wander across half the hospital to find a vending machine that has a queue of 0 rather than a nearby one in use. Again with a walk time that amounts to several patients worth of treatment time, for which - if the patient is at the front of the queue - the room has now been idle.
-The bug where a patient will just stand at the front of a queue and stop. And simply stand there until they die, holding up all the patients behind them (who are now nearly dead as well).


I fully recognise that these are very non-trivial problems and that making an algorithm that can solve these kinds of scenarios is difficult; but this level of failure is just not acceptable in a modern game. Yes Theme Hospital had similar issues, but that is not a modern game.

On top of all this, the price is too high. TPH released in 2018 and has a price (non-sale, at time of writing) of £24.99. PLUS all the not-exactly-cheap DLC on top of that (which don't have a whole lot of content for their price).


So overall, it gets a thumbs-down.

A fun hospital management game with plenty to do, but don't be fooled by it's appearance the game gets pretty difficult later on. The game is also 'slow burning' as in it takes forever to actually lose which allows you to salvage it, but this usually means you spend like 5 hours on a hospital just to have to restart completely. If something like that enrages you (it got me to rage a couple times) then maybe not the game for you. It's still fun however and leaves lots of room for creativity and design. The game also has a lot of strategy and planning forward. 

[b] Gameplay & controls: [/b] Controls are simple, but there are a lot of options and shortcuts you will have to learn on your own. Pretty simple gameplay, you select an area, you have missions and to complete the level you have to do a certain number of missions. You can manage pretty much everything.

[b] Visual design: [/b] Lots of attention to detail, the people don't look completely copied and pasted and the art style is very good. The menus take a little getting used to navigating, but they are organized well. A really good example of the detail is the pictures for each staff member which slowly gets disfigured and ruined.

[b] Music and SFX: [/b] The game has this very nice radio with different radio hosts and many speech lines. The music is pretty elevator type music which can get annoying pretty fast though. You will probably need to play something else over top after your 10th hour. The Sound effects fit pretty well and are very well done.

[b] Multiplayer: [/b] There is multiplayer, but its pretty sad (although understandable, not sure how you make a tycoon multiplayer), essentially you can connect your hospital with someone else and complete missions together on your own hospital (Ex. we both buy 20 plants in our hospital). Your reward for doing these tasks is a plant or something pretty small. Its not really worth it to 'get the boys together' just to do these tasks, neither is it worth it to buy it just cause a friend wants to play with you.

[b] Enjoyment:[/b] The game is fun just it takes so much time to complete a level, obviously this could be me just being bad at the game, but still really hard. The patients rage quit and die so quickly and it gets annoying because we have the option to do something like increase the prices, but once you increase it by a dollar the patients just don't pay complaining about higher prices. Like I haven't had to pay at a hospital before, but like you can't just not pay for stuff right? Also the assistants cost so much why would I hire them, like one assistant brought in 200$ profits, but I was paying them like 2k a year and they were working at the store next to the entrance, so I never got return on investment. The patients would then complain about no food or drinks and its like I pay this guy 2k to feed you and you wont even walk like down the hall just to buy from him or use the water fountain or anything, so annoying. Anyways back to the game, it is fun and the game is very for a lack of a better word, goofy. You have people who have the disease known as 'bad breath' which is fatal apparently or people who have lost their colors which effects their clothes too? Then you also have when patients die they turn into a ghost which a janitor has to vacuum up.

[b] Bugs & other problems: [/b] Haven't seen many bugs, but the models and animations break pretty quickly. I think this is actually on purpose because it happens every time, but the janitor when vacuuming a ghost will have his vacuum perform the animation first then the janitor will do it so the vacuum will essentially be floating.

Overall pretty good, but enraging and hard.

Pretty good game all things considering, but there are a few bugs that need to be worked out, specifically in the Fracture Ward (you have to make sure the casters don't touch the walls and have space all around them otherwise they don't work)
In the Ward you have to put the dressings room exactly the same distance from each other otherwise the patients will only use 1, which can cause a big queue to form when it's busy.

A lot of stuff isn't explained to you, like why prestige is important. I've had to look up a lot of information to get a good understanding of how everything runs and what is needed for specific things.

Overall I enjoy the game and will probably pick up DLC to shake things up once I beat the base game.

It's a dream for players who enjoyed the Maxis / EA "The Sims" games. Lots of ways to decorate your hospital room for room, although to be honest you will be reusing decor items, but that doesn't have to stop you! It's great because you have a management game like any of the "Tycoon" games, mixed with ribald humor, and and some awesome pop culture references (like the Patient who thinks he is Freddy Mercury). 

You do have to watch your cash flow early in each scenario, but once you have 4-5 treatment rooms, you can easily start upgrading your equipment, which means you can get your patients in and out faster, and by the time you have a few hours in a Hospital, your cash flow no longer is a worry because you're rolling in it. 

It's a fun little game, and it's even better if you can buy it on sale on Steam or on some REPUTABLE Key resellers *cough Eneba dot com* and even the DLC expansions are worth buying, although the fancy dress pack and sound track were easy passes for me. 

In short, this game was an easy 9.5 / 10 for me, and I would say this is an easy YES to buying, especially on sale or again on good key reseller that have never caused any problems *cough Eneba dot com*.

Addicting game, although it feels a bit repetitive after several levels. However, each level does present a new primary object or focus (such as a natural disaster or a specific type of illness). Essentially, you manage a hospital by diagnosing patients and curing them. It can get quite difficult to hit a 3 star rating for your hospital. For clarification, each hospital level provides objectives, you complete them to earn a 1 star rating, 2 star rating, or a 3 star rating before proceeding to the next level. The primary challenge is to keep your hospital debt free while ensuring your patients are waiting in line for a long time. Otherwise, their health continues to drop and they eventually die. Overall, the game is a lot of casual fun. However, I do believe the game itself could use some quality of life updates to make things easier to manage. Regardless, I recommend this game and can't wait for Two Point Campus.

(EDIT) I now have almost 100+ hours logged in this game, I can confirm that getting a 3 star on every level within the base game campaign is time consuming but still fun and/or challenging. If that is not enough, there is also plenty of DLC and a workshop on Steam.

Childish, corny, whimsical and not very serious.  Everything is big even at high resolution like for kids or half blind elderly, with little options to increase resolution graphics. Over-heated my computer and had to turn the graphics down, they aren't that great anyways.  All patients have non-real world problems easily cured, but fails most the time.  Room building is clumsy and error-prone.  Staff wander off from their jobs while their patients stagger into the hallways to die and I constantly have to put them back to work before more patients die.  Janitors fix medical equipment and chase ghosts of dead patients.  Research involves chasing some alien rats/worms, which I never found.  Kinda more like a hospital flipper with all the decorating...I'd rather cure real world diseases, perform complex surgical operations and research virus vaccines - I could care less if a flower in the waiting room isn't pretty.  Doesn't seem to have much depth...I'm trying, but I'm already bored and want something more complex and engaging, so it goes back on the shelf probably forever.  No bugs or big problems, so I have no excuse to return it, unfortunately.  Very disappointed in Sega and will probably not buy anything from them for a while.  And to all the fan-boys whom don't like my review, you can go and give yourself a lobotomy, you'll enjoy the game then even more.

Feels like Theme Hospital - the tannoy might be the same actor, the map layouts are familiar and the rat hunting is back, albeit without weapons, plus Rival CEOs blow up your rooms!

6 tutorial maps followed by a relentless series of challenges, where the 1st Star is relatively easy, the 2nd Star is challenging and the 3rd ranges from tricky to almost impossible

For example there could be endless natural disasters or an algorithm designed to send only patients who require treatments in rooms you don't have (resulting in massive queues)

There are also a huge variety of rooms, illnesses, staff traits, management features (incl. staff break times) plus numerous upgrades, with a fully customisable soundtrack

Past levels can be revisited without exiting the current level to use old research facilities and acquire new upgrades in the current level - a feature almost no other sim game currently has

This all leads me to a huge appreciation for the game, but the developers adding achis from DLCs, even if you haven't bought them this gets a red flag for achievement hunters.

8/10 - a disappointing ending for an otherwise tremendously enjoyable game

Advice:
[spoiler]Fully upgraded machines and staff with 2 levels of training in their fields = 75% cure rate
Ice Sculptures give room cooling without maintenance
Queues of 7+ per GP? Send them all home to avoid making a loss![/spoiler]

A more slapstick version of Theme Hospital that's also more challenging and varied.  You don't have to play the levels in a linear way either which I like ie. you can go for 3 stars at a hospital or you can get 1 star and move on to the next unlocked hospital and come back.  There are different modes and challenges to complete when the base game becomes too easy.

The multiplayer challenge mode could be better but overall a cracking game.

I was addicted to Theme Hospital as a kid and Two Point Hospital's Developers prescribed a happy overdose of nostalgia!
From the base game to all the DLC's - I have enjoyed each and everyone one.
No game is ever perfect or to everyone's tastes, but for me Two Point Hospital pushes all the right button's. I love the theme, design, sound, all the management systems, all the puns and fun! 

My only critique would be the Superbug aspect of the game - Most of my friends are not into Sim type games and it's sad I have to  use "Gyro-nut" basically add strangers to my friends list in hopes to even do this part of the game. 

Yes it has a lot of easy to exploit systems for easy wins.  Yes Sony forces in shameless cosmetics (but at least for free). But the game keeps getting updates, keeps making new DLC's that don't feel like they should have been part of the base game, but truly creative, interesting and fun DCL packs.
The game is still getting constant updates and the developers are obviously working hard to improve the game and adjust it. 

Again: I have rose tinted glasses due to my 1st true love: Theme Hospital, but if this is your gene and you wants to have a Fun/Silly yet deep and thoughtful game. Give it a look.

I believe I like this game out of nostalgia.  It reminds me a lot of theme hospital, which is one of the first tycoon type games I ever played.
You have control of how to expand your hospital; the policies you set and how to manage your personnel among other things.  You even got a pause/play button and speed buttons so you can go at your on pace; Being overwhelmed by patients? hit the pause button and kick out everyone you can't help (and therefore not make any money from them) and resume once you catch your breath.

Also it has quite funny names and descriptions of the diseases you have to cure and funny announcements over the PA system.

There are seasonal events and items as well.

Overall quite an enjoyable game.

A highly polished hospital management simulator, made by many of the same people that made Bullfrog's classic Theme Hospital.

All diseases are comical so no risk of taking the game too seriously. Extremely nice graphics, and it is hard not to feel immensed in whatever troubles your patients and staff are getting into.

Very nice background music interrupted by the hospital's ridiculous radio station, and humorous tannoy speaker. 

Hospitals have a nice selection of diseases for extra replayability. Even more are added in the four story DLCs that are all well worth the money.

The only negative I can find is the amount of meteors striking your hospitals on a few levels, but that's a minor issue.

So, I've played this game off and on since I got it during a Summer sale of some kind. I've managed to beat the main game hospitals with three stars in all of them. I've started to work on the remix levels and the DLC but honestly, I felt pretty satisfied  with the main "questline" that I decided to take a break but I digress. The game is an absolute banger.

Starting off, you get a small scale clinic that with each progressing hospital gets significantly larger. The goal is to meet specific criteria for that level (like a specific cure rate, curing x patients with x disease, ect.) and when it's accomplished you get a letter from the health minister and a star. You are not obligated to get all three stars, you can continue to the next with one star, but the criteria gets harder to accomplish the more stars you try to earn. I personally never felt like it was unfair but some levels will make you pull out your hair because the percentages.just.won't.go.up. Not a bug, it just can be hard to figure out what aspect you are lacking that is keeping you from reaching your goals. Probably one of my few complaints of the game. The game is fun to play long sessions or in short bursts, it's a very easy "pick up and play" kind of game. You don't even *need* the DLC to enjoy it. You'll easily be able to figure out if this game is meant for you within the 2 hour refund limit, so give it a shot.

Just, a tip, there is a template tool in the game that allows you to copy and save rooms. Trust me, the amount of General Practitioners you'll need, this will save your fingers.
