[b]From the viewpoint of someone who never played theme hospital:[/b]

It's a good hospital building simulator with a wide array of objects and several options to customize aspects of the game. There's plenty of hospitals and challenges that come with each one of them, and an online multiplayer mode that has some local and global challenges. There are some downsides however, such as the lack of effective communication between the player and game, the fact that you often need 4-5 GP offices to get to a 1-star hospital, the necessity to go back into earlier more developed hospitals and spend some time "researching" new treatment methods in order to treat patients in later hospitals, and multiplayer challenges that require 2-3 friends on steam that actively play this game in order to gain access to some more items and content.
This game is pretty good but there definitely could be more mechanics and rewards for progressing and getting more stars on previous hospitals.

I reckon it will be as hard to write a review about this game without mentioning Theme Hospital, as it will be to write a review about this game without using the letter 'e'. Let's find out...

Like most people, I bough this game because Im actually old enough to remember a game called 'Theme Hospital", and this game can in all honestly be called a spiritual successor. It has the same kind of humor, build style and cartoony feel to it. So yeah, I was sold right away!

Now I do need to warn everyone, this is not heavy management game. It does require some management, like research, checking staff and making sure your staff is up to par with their training. But it is not nearing Project Hospital levels of management. Its very surface level management stuff, but if you feel like it, you could choose to "optimize" every hospital, by staying on top of training, making sure that certain doctors work at certain departments, etc. The management aspect is as deep as YOU want it to be.

The missions are varried, and new sicknesses get introduced on a regular basis to make sure that you stay on yer toes, and the number of DLC's out for the game make sure that you are NOT getting bored with this game any time soon. I love the fact that most DLC add new missions, with new types of illness, even though the main game is already pretty big.

 All in all, its a great successor to Theme Hospital, with even some multiplayer aspects like WorldWide Research. So, if ya liked Theme Hospital, make sure to give this a try.

[h1]A rich-man's 'Project Hospital'...[/h1]
I really like 'Project Hospital', and even before that, I used to play 'Theme Hospital' in highschool... now both of those games are really good, and 'Two Point Hospital' (TPH) is very good as well. TPH is a clearly bigger budget, more ambitious hospital-sim game, with better graphics and a much less 'hands on approach' than Project Hospital, but TPH is much more expensive, and for some reason, even 3years after TPH was released, it's STILL being sold at 100% of the original price (my guess is that you've got SEGA to thank for that).

Apart from TPH costing $35, there's over $70 worth of expansion DLC to buy, which is pretty egregious tbh. I think that the game is well worth $35, but it's NOT worth the $100+ that SEGA would like you to spend on it... I honestly struggle to think of [u]ANY[/u] game that is worth $100, so it's very obvious that TPH is NOT worth $100 or even close tbh. But, I digress... I can recommend the base game for $35 with no real reservations; it's a good game and is basically a better looking, much less hands-on version of 'Project Hospital'. So I'd recommend it, but SEGA need to catch a f*cking wake-up.

For a game that did not sell me at first, I have to admit it is pretty fun. Definitely one that game play speaks better than trailers. I'd be lying if I said it did not have a problem with repetitiveness, but the various different hospitals help mix it up; especially early on or with the DLC hospitals. In that respect, I suggest not being as stubborn as me and be willing to bounce around before you hit star 3. Plus, there are QoL things like kudosh and research unlocks being meta, as well as saving room templates. The latter should help largely when you get tired of building a new hospital from scratch each time.

I will quickly comment on the tone: if it is not already obvious, Two Point Hospital is pretty zany and light hearted. If you are looking for realism, this isn't your game. I personally do not mind it, and even laugh occasionally, but I understand the appeal of something like Project Hospital instead.

Anyway, if Two Point Hospital was this fun, I am looking forward to seeing Two Point Campus.

It would also be great if I could force staff on breaks to go to the staff rooms, I can't stand them in the hallways. Untraining would be awesome. Regardless I adore this game, the team, and it's absolutely worth the spend!

I'm not an avid gamer, but this game brought back memories when I used to play Theme Hospital (anyone remember this?) and this Two Point Hospital is similar, but more exciting and interesting due to technology, graphics and challenges in the game.

What I liked about the game is you can go into different locations to start a hospital, with it's own challenges. It keeps things exciting and there is always something new to explore, to overcome, and to solve the problems that happen. Looking at the graphics, I think it's pretty good. I like watching the patients getting their treatment with those funky (named) machines, and it brings some laughter. The developers' humour is appreciated. ;p The realistic-ness of getting a loan, not able to pay back and then file for bankruptcy... hahaha!

What I dislike (minor) about the game is that sometimes it gets a bit mundane to reach the 3-star level because things can get repetitive at times. I haven't played to the end yet (is there an ending???) and have yet to try more and explore more, so I really can't comment much on what I dislike.

Overall, it's an awesome game, get you hooked for hours, and the satisfaction of achieving all the goals. ;p

Presentation (2.5/5) - Pretty standard cartoony graphics yet demanding a good computer. I don't think this game is very optimized and may push you to lower your settings. There is a PG comedic tone with literal humor that will certainly grant a few smirks the first time you see them (even if it can be really stupid), but eventually the novelty wears off and you start associating them in terms of gameplay (I see goofy sickness X, I need treatment X). I think the biggest problem is the lack of variation within each disease type and how the patients interact with the doctors - the interactions play EXACTLY THE SAME each time.

Story/Dialogue - N/A

Gameplay (2/5) -Maybe I didn't give it enough time, but after 5+ hours, I could tell this is a pretty casual, repetitive game with little complexity. You build rooms specialized on certain needs, earn profit, hire staff associated with certain hospital needs, watch things play out, and so on until you build the next hospital, doing very similar gameplay to advance further. If you are looking into a multi-dimensional simulation game with complex management mechanics, you got the wrong game.

I really enjoy this game. it is a great manager. it falls more into a "strategic" manager than a "tactical" manager, in that you are more focused on the big picture (hiring the right people, having the correct rooms, and training your people appropriately for said rooms) than it is about micromanaging emplooyee and customer stats. those stats are still there, but not as signifigant. i think the developer intent was to keep time pressure on the player to a minimum so you can focus more on looking at all the silly animations and room design instead of microing employee brake times and schedules. 

the only thing i think the game is missing is a few more tools for employee job assignment. treatment skill is one of the more important stats and once you get a big enough place you want to keep employees lacking treatment training out of treatment rooms and its a pain to do for a bunch of employees at once. a cohort system would be neat, where employees of a particular cohort can only work in certian rooms. There is a mod to help with this, FWIW.

Two Point Hospital runs well, looks good, and it's fun. It's not a particularly deep simulator or management game; it's no Rimworld. That's not necessarily a bad thing. But some mechanics seem overly simplistic or half-baked.

For example, the hygiene stat seems to add nothing more to the game than a reason to put a sink in the bathroom and hand sanitizer in every treatment room or else have more failed treatments; there are no other relevant items or effects.

Benches and other items claim to "improve comfort", but comfort is not a stat for either staff or patients, and even though you get a pop-up warning you that people are having to stand in line, it doesn't appear to have any impact on happiness or anything else at all.

But despite this, it's still a fun game. And it runs great on Linux with my R9 390.

Put a lot of hours into this game, which has been both fun and vexing. Pleasant visuals and a light-hearted take on a hospital sim. To get the most out of this game and to lessen frustration, *do* explore all the info options.  Yes, I recommend, but prepare to be annoyed at some things. You can lessen your annoyance level by looking at the tips below.

Possible spoilers

- Take a loan if you need one [$ tab] (essential for the objective oriented income eg. hiring an employee to train). Pay back your most expensive one first, deficits are ok, unless you are about to go bankrupt...
- Use the 'Patient' info to get a list of your patients [person tab], you can order them in terms of health and see the ones that need intervention because they are unhappy or about to die (eg putting them to the top of the queue)
- Also use 'Patient' info to select and manually send a patient to treatment that is just short of your diagnosis threshold (It could make or break completing your wave)
- Use Overview [$ tab], look at 'Policy' tab and make sure your treatment decision is fast tracked - otherwise you will have clogged up GPs, patients going back to get their illness named at 100% diagnosis and extreme vexation
- On Overview>Policy Set the Diagnosis level slider where you are happy, 85% works for me generally
- Do use Person tab>Staff>Job Assignment to ensure skilled staff work in the appropriate rooms.
- When trying to find aliens and paparazzi, go thru your Patient list>Log. These bludgers arrive, go to reception and then direct to a diagnosis room, sometimes straight to diagnosis. Legit patients will always have Reception followed by GP. [If they are in the Ward and can't be sent home, rename them for later eviction]
- Don't be tempted to upgrade all your machines when income is scarce. Work on the treatment ones that will get your income flowing first.
- Multiple small training rooms and staff rooms are better than big ones
- Think about your placement eg. nesting a 3x3 on at 4x4 when space is tight, too many GPs close together causing congestion, like treatment or diagnosis staff collected in the same spot for ease of going between rooms, patient flow from diagnosis to treatment - don't make the poor wee poppets trek back and forth vast distances.

There are a couple of terrible design decisions in this game:  fast treatment decisions default to off (why is this even a thing?!), and patients in the loo or cafe cannot be manually selected to send for treatment. I suspect coding convenience... don't mess with me when I'm micro-managing (lol!) let me designate what they will do, I don't mind if it happens after they eat/evacuate etc, but don't make me wait for them or come back to them. [ Ed. I need to mention the yearly reviews, which are painful - unavoidably interrupting your placement of rooms or movement of staff - this also, while possibly created to disallow idling, is horrible and infuriating design, the only positive is you get a 5k bonus per award] 

But overall, fun and worth the spend espesh on sale. If in doubt, buy the base game to see how you fare with the above vexations before dropping money on the DLC.

Deleted my first review. This is what happens when you write a review after playing a few hours of a long game: boy was I wrong. But that's by design. I write these things mostly for myself so I can read what I wrote when I revisit the game.

I complained about a lack of challenge and micromanagement but later levels certainly deliver on that. It's still not very challenging once you get the hang of it but the game throws more than enough new stuff at the player. 

I still have some complaints. The biggest one is that levels are too long. It can become boring. The levels also aren't varied enough, they play out the same which again can become tedious. The base game also doesn't have enough items, making every hospital and every room look alike. I'm still not the biggest fan of the game's humor (or attempts at making the games theme lighter, if you will) but it's growing on me. Personally I would have preferred a slightly more serious approach.
Hospital attractiveness is also very important but the game offers very little in variety of items to design the hospital. There's plenty to unluck off course (though not enough) but that means that there are very little options until you put in the hours and unlock them.

While the game is easy to get into it fails explaining anything but the basics. Very important features are never explained in any kind of tutorial. 

Steam offers two ratings: Recommended or Not Recommended. Thumbs up or Thumbs down. This one is either a "recommended" with a "but" or a "not recommended" with a "despite" behind it. I get not offering a 1-5 or 1-10 score because players only use the two extremes of that track. There really should be a neutral rating though.

Having played over 200 hours of this game, including most of the DLCs, I can say without a doubt it is an incredibly addicting and fun game to have in your library. The management component keeps me interested while the game still gives enough flexibility for players to be creative. The humorous take on a simulation game is unique and not overly ridiculous. The difficulty is just enough to make you think and plan, while not leaving you frustrated and unable to complete levels. All in all, one of my top games!

As an avid Theme Hospital player back in the day, I was looking for a new version of the game to play. And this does have the same playstyle and overall feel as Theme Hospital, just with new graphics and a few more options.

The problem is it also has the same issues as Theme Hospital – the levels are a bit of a grind and its very repititve. And whilst you can expand the hospital, walking times become a bit problem and it becomes more frustrating than fun.

And then you have additional issues with this game that you get too many patients and with the above issues and lower patient recovery rates, there is less and less fun to have as you progress.

Overall, disappointed and should have just left this alone.

If you enjoyed good old fashioned theme hospital from back in the day, you may enjoy this game too. It is a bit silly, the patient care is a bit messed up but at the end of the day, its a fun little game.

Lots of little jokes.

My only really big complaint it the speed of things seems to be a bit wonky. It takes days to get a single patient to even talk to 1 person. So you can imagine how silly that can be. A consultation with a doctor that the animation shows him walking in, talking, paying 500 dollars for and then leaving could take 1-2 days. Meaning that for an entire year, a doctor may only have 150-200 patients. I had a patient that left after 415 days without being treated once. I mean its a bit stupid to have them being able to wait that long. Also the health, number of patients etc. Is a bit of a failure.

I would like to say this is the spiritual successor to Theme Hospital but I feel like its more like a fanboy tribute. It had a lot more potential but its still a fun game. However unlike the original, I can't just binge play it, I need to take breaks between maps and even during maps.

The multiplayer aspect is also just a joke. It would have been better to not have it but these days everybody is trying to connect online game mechanics with regards to working together, click here and invite your friends nonsense to games outside of web based games. As such it is something that can be just simply left by the wayside and it really is more of a poorly conceived novelty than anything else.

Whilst I'd recommend this to other players, I would say to anyone that has played the original Theme Hospital that this has absolutely none of the original's charm. If you are of a particular age you will have grown up with the NHS tropes of the late '70s and '80s. From the announcer telling you that "Coughs and Sneezes spread diseases" to dirty, rat invested hospitals this game has none of it. As a matter of fact, in the first six hospitals I've yet to see a single piece of litter. 

So you can also imagine just how jarring it is for the first voice you hear to be some cheesy American Radio host, rather than the (English) Receptionist politely asking patients not to die in the corridors. Whilst it's a good game in and of itself, it's not a good sequel which is a shame because they've kept the original's visual style, just let themselves down by removing the original's themes.

Most sim/management games allow you to plan ahead and prepare before you expand. This is not really the case in this game - the game escalates incredibly quickly, and proportionally to how developed your hospital is. You have a queue of patients for a GP's office? Well, logically you build a second one. But that increases your hospital level and now suddenly patients with a new illness show up. So you have to build a new treatment room. And your hospital level goes up, and now your GP's office is overwhelmed again; so on and so forth. Good management can keep you from failing, but it's inevitable that your hospital will slide into chaos. But then again, that's fairly advertised in the opening cinematic, i suppose.

I have pretty mixed feelings about this game overall. As someone who played Theme Hospital back in the day, I can see that they've tried to recreate the experience of it in this game with varying levels of success. Regardless of that, I think it's important to review something on its own merits. The gameplay is straightforward enough with progression to more difficult levels as you play through. So far, so good. I think one of the issues lies with the difficulty, it's not that difficult to get all of the stars on individual levels and the requirements for doing so often just involve grinding away and time. I would have preferred more thought put into this. It gets a bit boring after two levels. If you have a game with a number of systems within it that have to be carefully balanced in order to play well, I just think it needs to be harder and that it should be more refined than it is in this game. Graphics were kind of meh and granted, the game was funny at times but overall, my impression was that this game is kind of boring.
Its theme hospital but for the new generation. Just what you need.

Either I'm too good for the game or the game simply does no challenging. Saying that, because I don't understand all the positive reviews and here is why:

The way the game is made, you simply don't have to look much on all the details and so most people probably miss how bad some things really work. After all, it's easy to beat anything: Just put out more stuff of anything. Too long queues? Simply build another room and hire another doctor. Need higher prestige? Spam the walls with posters or certificates. Need faster training? Spam the room with training boosts. 

The "challenges" the games put out, are always similar: Achieve so much money in so much time. Treat so many patiens having a specific illness in a specific time. Not hard to beat those. And if you don't, there's no downside. You can even simply dismiss them or not accept them. 

Overall the game provides little to no challenge. I've been playing classic games of that kind, which all had some balancing and difficulty, with negative effects for your success. But this one doesn't have anything of the like. A bad rating somewhere? Doesn't matter. Bad reputation, so what? Too high prices, patients keep visiting you anyway. Balancing? I don't see it.

Take as example this: You can have the worst hospital, but then you can have one room, spammed with posters, certificates and other stuff (and this is btw the only way it works and what affects prestige all the time from beginning till the end), and while the rest of your hospital is Level 1, this one can count as Level 5000 (exaggerated to make it clear), without anything else affecting this rating. Not even, if you place in the staff's room like 20 radiators and burn your doctors alive, the room still counts as awesomely awesome and your staff is happy with it! 

Once you start paying a little bit more attention on what the patients and your employeers do, you start getting the feeling, things weren't finished or fine-tuned. People keep bumping on each other and they only manage to move forward, once they "slide" enough and other things. Similarly, other things feel missing or unfinished, especially since nothing has a real downside on your gameplay. In the end, everything is achievable, even if you are the worst hospital manager. Money is also never a real issue in the game.

I suppose, the game wants to make money based on the nostalgy of that classic game. Because, on it's own, without borrowing the enthusiasm of the classic fans, it leaves a lot to be desired. 

I kept playing nearly 30 hours hoping it would get better and somewhat challenging, but that's not the case. If a game does not achieve that in less than 30 hours, then... 

It's a simple simulation and not a very good one. The one thing, that seemed to be cool when watching the trailer, the different "crazy" illnesses, actually is only cool in the trailer. In the game, it loses immediately it's funny side. I'm really missing the "fun part" in the animations and in how the patients or doctors behave. 

Further, the game is very unpersonal. At no point you connect with your doctors or any of your patients, since it presents everything and anything in simple text-only popups, all being the same. This is another part that feels unfinished and as if no love went into it. 

And these annoying messages that keep appearing, you can do this and that, hundreds of times, when you already know, that you can upgrade machines, or how to hire another nurse. No way to deactivate them, when they come up. It will keep annoy you, over and over again.

So, you see, I don't understand all the positive reviews, with so many things not done very well. But like I said, at first, the way the game plays and makes you focus mostly on room-building -> hiring -> training -> hiring -> room-building, it is easy for anyone to miss all these negative sides of the game. And I believe, that this is what happening.

As a veteran player of Theme Hospital, I had high hopes given this was touted as the spiritual successor we all craved. Unfortunately it isn't quite the blast of nostalgic crack I wanted, as the visual gags often fall flat, it can get repetitive rather quickly, plus a lot of diseases aren't represented visually (it's disappointing for example that patients with lycanthropy don't sporadically turn into werewolves). Despite this it has a unique graphical style which reminds me of the original game's cutscenes, while the sound and music is fantastic (those DJ's can be hilarious). It's a great game, but for Theme Hospital fans it's like getting a new girlfriend with the same hair colour except she's got bigger boobs and is noticeably more stupid.

I don't know what gets me so addicted to these kind of simulation games especially with selecting the furniture/interior that I lose myself when I start playing but Two Point Hospital is great. Its been almost 50 hours and there's still so much I haven't done! Really nice to see more about how hospitals work, especially since outside of this game I have no interest of visiting one- yuck. Thankfully, this game is super playful and with the humour makes every disease fun- like the pandemic where patients start walking like zombies. Fun.

If you like colony builders/management games, please give this a try! I just keep coming back to it. If you ever played Theme Hospital, it's the modern-day version -- balanced gameplay, well-done graphics, and a HEFTY dose of humor. I find the levels to be unique enough that (unlike Theme Hospital) there are levels that I love and levels I find annoying.

If you haven't played this game before (or Theme Hospital), then I highly recommend you don't buy the DLCs until after you play it. Sure there are some useful items, but they're really not necessary, the DLCs are mostly just additional levels, additional illnesses/rooms (that are only in the DLC levels), and different mechanics to beat those levels.

Want to be in charge of your own hospital, but lack the knowledge and funding? Perhaps you're even a danger to genuinely ill people. This game, you don't have to worry about the consequences. If you run your hospital into the ground from debts, deaths and terrible floor planning, it's all good because nobody is going to lock you up in a prison cell. This game is pretty much a remaster of the classic game Theme Hospital, that many of us know as being the silly, funny hospital managing game that had you dealing with bizarre illnesses and amusing FMV's. If you played and loved Theme Hospital, don't worry about reading the rest of this and just get this game, they also have much more precise placing of objects and more than just 90 degree rotations.
If you've never played TH and are interested in this, it is thoroughly fun to play and enjoy, plan out your hospital with multiple GP offices, chuck down a reception, place your only toilets in the furthest building to inconvenience your patients, create the perfect smooth running hospital or be the stingiest Hospital CEO to have lived.

I was addicted to this game for a month, as my 71 hours show. Like, stay up real late trying to build addicted. But in the end I got frustrated by all the little mechanics that were not explained properly that kept me from beating a level and quit playing. At first the game is easy and explains how to create different parts of the hospital and reach the level goes. But as the hospitals you're expected to build get more complicated the new mechanics lose their explanations. I gave up on a level that expected the hospital to be a certain level of valuable, and look good, and cure one kind of disease. And no matter what I did the hospital kept losing money and the game would never explain why. II tried to a bunch of different tricks to just have a month where I made a profit and nothing worked, and eventually I gave up.

UPDATE 7/4/2021: I suppose it would be hypocritical to put this many additional hours into this game and still give it a negative review. I got sucked back in thanks to the trailer for Two Point Campus. My advice is: do not go for more than a one-star rating for each hospital. Trying to get the requirements for higher stars leads to the worse parts of the game, grinding to cure five hundred patients, or make the hospital worth several million dollars, stuff that will lead to your money disappearing which the game will not bother to explain. At least with one star it's less frustrating.

A fun hospital management simulator that makes what I like to call a good "idle game," which is a game that you can leave running while you're doing other stuff and come back to (see also things like Civilization, FTL). 

You play as a hospital and try to build and manage it, mostly by building, furnishing, and hiring/firing/training staff, and try to balance your revenue with your expenses. There are a few sliders, like paying staff more or the diagnosis threshold before sending patients for treatment, but not that many. The maps also provide interesting challenges; new hospital locations usually come with interesting challenges, such as working in a place with frequent earthquakes or epidemics, working with a public health system where you make no income through normal means and instead have to meet arbitrary goals from a health minister, and where you take over a crumbling inner city hospital $10k in debt. 

There are a few criticisms, mainly that the balance is off; the vast majority of your queues, unless you seriously focus them, are to the GP office. A lot of the challenge is also based on when you first open your hospital, and once you get your money really flowing, it just starts flooding in and you can spend and expand as much as you want. On top of that, the items have no scaling, so you can, for example, put 20 monitors or medicine cabinets to stack that % treatment power bonus it gives, so the best rooms end up looking ridiculous, and if you have challenges like get a level 5 staff room, you can buy 20 Gold Award frames, get the challenge done, and immediately sell them. The number of things you can buy is also limited, although I don't have any DLC so that may be part of it. 

All in all, well worth the $8 I spent.

As someone who is chronically ill and disabled, Two Point Hospital is a bit of escapism and wish fulfillment in this comedic hospital sim. Every patient who enters the hospital in the game has an illness that can be diagnosed AND cured, as long as you get to them in time before their health and/or happiness runs out!

The illnesses are amusing at every level, some more ridiculous than others. The in-game radio station is quite amusing. It is possible to listen to your own music, but since I like to stream 2PH on Twitch (as Karistina) I tend to listen to the default music most of the time. Two Point County's pop star, Jasmine Odyssey, has some entertaining songs that have been added to the music rotation, but I was disappointed once I actually listened to the lyrics of "Nice-Smelling Face." Despite its cheerfully catchy melody, the song is terribly ableist in its mocking of specifically autistic traits. As an autistic person, it's pretty offensive. I wish they could re-record it with alternate lyrics that didn't suggest the subject was a loser whose only redeeming quality is a "nice-smelling face."

But I digress. The DJs on the in-game radio station are quite entertaining, as each is a caricature of various types of radio personalities. They are all played by the same voice actor, and I'm quite the fan! The tannoy messages from the hospital announcer are amusing as well. The game has a wry sense of humor!

I've bought and played through all of the DLCs available to date, both item packs and new levels. I find it all has great replay value, as I enjoy seeing how quickly I can replay the different hospital levels.

Does this game have its drawbacks?  Sure.  Sometimes, levels feel like they drag on for a long time, waiting on enough patients to be cured to grant that 2nd or 3rd star on a given level.  But the balance between expanding your hospital and maintaining enough income to support it seems fair, and the charm in the character models plays a role in the game not feeling like a slog.  I think you have to like this kind of management game to enjoy Two Point Hospital, but I'm liking it so far!

The goofy humor really shines through. From the comedic maladies to the over the top cures, the game brings on the laughs with the challenges. On that note, the game is a fun play through, that gets progressively tougher (though not too much) as you progress from hospital to hospital. Throw in the curve balls of added mini challenges in addition to the main goals and you have a management game worth the price. I have yet to play the expansion, but I imagine more of the same just with a motif twist. I'd recommend this to any management game groupie. For those new to the genre, its a great place to start something new.

[h1]Get out of my emergency room[/h1]
[hr][/hr][i]
Developed by Two Point Studios and published by SEGA, "Two Point Hospital" is a hospital management simulation and strategy game released in 2018.

Build and design your dream hospital, cure its quirky patients and even weirder illnesses in a simultaneous juggle for staff morale, queue optimization and hospital reputation.[/i]

[b]DISCLAIMER:[/b][i]Two Point Hospital is the spiritual successor to "Theme Hospital", developed by now defunct Bullfrog Productions and published by Electronic Arts in 1995.[/i]

[tr]

	[td][h1]Design & Graphics[/h1][/td]
	[td][b]Good[/b][/td]
	[td]Great reimagination, same ridiculous diseases and their treatment, great detail to cute & funny animations, solid graphic design lacking complexity, many animations too long-winded[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][h1]Sound & Music[/h1][/td]
	[td][b]Average[/b][/td]
	[td]Iconic speaker announcements, acceptable sound design, some sounds out of place, soundtrack lacking urgency & tempo, very mediocre compared to the original[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][h1]Gameplay & Controls[/h1][/td]
	[td][b]Poor[/b][/td]
	[td]Fun for the first three hospitals, gameplay loop way too slow, too easy to cheese objectives, gameplay elements run against common sense of the player, tedious and laborious for no reason[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][h1]Appeal & Innovation[/h1][/td]
	[td][b]Bad[/b][/td]
	[td]A nice trip down memory lane - with caveats, no challenge to the player, gets frustrating with time, many levels too similar, no interesting changes to the old formula[/td]
[/tr]

	[td]50h+ basegame, game doesn't respect your time, DLC which only add three more hospitals each, additional content lacks innovation, not worth the full price[/td]
[/tr]

[i](Scoring range: Poor (worst) - Bad - Average - Good - Superb (best)[/i]
[hr][/hr]
[h1][u][b]Personal Thoughts:[/b][/u][/h1]

[i]I really wanted to like Two Point Hospital. The premise sounds so great: a reimagination of the more than two decades old Theme Hospital, a game I remember playing with delight. This can only be good, right? Wrong. Playing the first three levels felt so close to the original and I was positively impressed. The soundtrack was a bit more downtempo compared to the original and, for some odd reason, the game felt way slower than I remembered. Suddenly things start to feel off. And by the fourth level, it started to annoy me.

I started to realize that this game doesn't respect your time. I wanted to know why and I found the reason - gameplay and new animations fight against the player in more ways than just by difficulty. I started losing income even though I felt that I did everything right. Until one day, I realized that giving patients benches, vending machines and things to reduce their boredom with holds up the entire queue. I started to struggle with queues all the time and even 5-6 GP offices couldn't reduce the buildup. I had to initiate mass exodus from my hospitals every year because they would die like flies. Why? Because they hold up the queues. I don't understand. Why add a mechanic into a game that bites you in the behind like this? Why give the patients options to annoy the player more than they should? This runs against anything I've experienced before. And for the animations: bloaty head in the original is cured within 10 seconds, the recurvery treatment for cubism needs a whooping 50 (!) seconds for one patient. What the hell went wrong here? Remember emergencies? Good luck treating all patients in time because (unlike in the original) people can't walk through each other anymore. This all culminates in a painfully slow gameplay loop that takes up too much of your time and is not worth the effort. Avoid this game unless you really want to feel that tiny bit of nostalgia.[/i]

A worthy successor to Theme Hospital that recaptures the glory of that venerable game. One of the few games in recent memory where the base game is actually a full game and the expansion packs feel both optional and enticing at reasonable prices for what they are. They are what they should be too: Not skin packs (mostly), not microtransactions or cut content DLC that should have been in the base game (looking at you, Paradox and Creative Assembly) - for between seven Pounds a pop, you get not one, not two, but three extra levels.
It's a throwback to a better time, when dev teams actually put love into their work and didn't abuse their customers for quick cash.
Buy this amazing game and support good business practices in the process!

Where to start!

Pros,

Theme hospital was one of the greatest games ever made, this just came along and matched it.
High amounts of content and hospitals, more than it looks when you first buy it.
Hilarious dialogue and treatments.
Awesome amount of freedom and control over what you do to a certain extent.
Perfect for anyone who has an OCD for micromanaging.
Graphically extremely relaxing and pleasing.
The best of British humour.

Cons,

Learning curve is brutal compared to the first game.
Micro controls can be frustrating.
An awful lot to remember in the later levels.
RNG based staff recruiting system which can be annoying and cause a few resets.
Some form of co-op mode would be awesome.

Not really much else to say, props to Sega for bringing back this perfection and actually not messing it up!

[h1] Not Much to Manage [/h1]

[b] What I Liked [/b]

I love the look and feel of the game.  It's fun to design rooms, decorate hallways, and see all of the interactions going on.

[b] What I Did Not Like [/b]

The problem is, for the most part, what you do doesn't matter at all.  You can design a perfect hospital and get all the patients/money available.  Or, you could let your hospital go and still get enough patients and money.  Patients leave angry?  So what, there are 10 behind him.  Employee quit?  Eh, there are six to take their place.

At the end of each mission I had so much money I couldn't spend it fast enough.  Most items didn't seem to have an impact.  Should I put a trash can down?  Why?  Litter didn't seem to matter to anything.

[b] Why I Stopped Playing [/b]

It's a great game for the looks, but not for the gameplay.  As far as management games go, there just isn't anything to really manage, so I stopped playing.

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I have been a gamer for over 30 years.  I tend to play mostly PC games.  I also bounce around between games A LOT.  I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it.  Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad.  It just means another game caught my attention.  I also complain about flaws in games a lot, even about the littlest of things.  Keep that in mind when reading my reviews.  If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!

While yes, I recommend this game - I do strongly suggest that people wait for it to be on sale before purchasing it. I think if I had bought it at full price, I might have been mad at myself.

It's a fun game though, def good for killing time and relaxing.

It's basicaly Theme Hospital 2.

The game is so filled with game breaking mechanics and exploits that it actively encourages you to use that it gets to a point where it is really only enjoyable to continue playing just in order to mess with it and see how badly you can break things.

For instance items like the medical cabinet which increase diagnosis power in a room by 1% stack. So you can simply build a giant GP office with 100 of them and a student doctor with no GP skill can diagnose most of the diseases to 100% immediately, rendering any other diagnosis rooms pointless. For the harder diseases it will get them to 60-70% meaning you only need one other diagnosis room likewise stacked with medical cabinets in order to diagnose everything.

If you do not exploit this mechanic however then you inevitably end up in a situation where half your hospital is filled with GP rooms and yet you still have massive queues for them due to patients visiting the GP between every other diagnosis room. This is the single most game breaking mechanic because there is no way of setting GP offices to just be used for the initial diagnosis and others for follow up exams so it's rarely possible to utilise the full space of the hospital and keep patients funnelled through it in a logical order. They'll walk to the GP on the opposite side of the hospital rather than the one adjacent to the last room they visited. So you end up with hallways choked so full of people going back and forth that it takes days for anyone to get anywhere.

For the harder diseases that often means they have spent half a year wandering about the hospital and are borderline dead by the time it comes to treat them. Whereas you can avoid this by spamming a single item in a single room. It's ridiculous. The game really incentives this item spamming and the best way to get a room to 5 stars is just to pick a small, high value item like the gold award and plaster every space on every wall with it leading to a very stupid looking hospital. Likewise you can spam medicine cabinets in treatment rooms and bring the cure rate up to 100% without bothering to spend ages training doctors to high levels of proficiency. It realistically seems to be the only way to not have deaths in your hospital and get the award for that. Or you dramatically expedite training speeds by spamming the same poster on every wall and training bookcases in front of that. The mechanic would work if it just didn't stack and it forced you to use a limited number of different items to achieve maybe a 10-20% improvement rather than 100 of a single item halving training speeds.

If you actually want to enjoy the game as a hospital simulator you could choose to avoid just spamming items and cheating it but if you do that the game will punish you for it and things will become unmanageable and unplayable. It's like only using a knife during a shooting game in order to deliberately make it harder for yourself. You really have to force yourself to do it.

After a few levels or playing the same one long enough you start to see how broken the game is and it feels pointless to bother playing it anymore so personally I've just taken to entertaining myself by seeing how broken I can make things. Whether that is making one hit diagnosis GP rooms or pharmacies that occupy a whole building with the corridors woven into a labyrinth such that people die before ever reaching the end - it's still more fun than playing the game as intended.

I have no idea how there are so many positive reviews for this game.  There must be a lot of bots writing fake reviews, or accounts are getting hacked and used to write reviews.

This game is COMPLETELY plagued with bugs. I couldn't get through the first 10 minutes of the game - the bugs stopped me from advancing. You'd think these bugs would be worked out since the game's release date in 2018.

2 minutes into the game, the very first patient gets stuck by the road, the vehicle door opens and closes infinitely.  After 10 restart attempts, I was able to get by this particular bug 2 times.  Other patients got stuck the same way 10 minutes in - couldn't advance the game.

Another bug occasionally happens when you attempt to hire staff - a bugged ghost version of the staff is placed in the hospital, and doesn't register.

Another bug causes patients to stack and get stuck in the GP's office

Another bug causes staff to get confused and not do their jobs.

If you think you can save and reload the game to quickfix this, you cannot.  Either the came will continue to reload with the same bug, or there will be an error and it won't let you load your save, and you'll be forced to start a new game.

How can all of these issues still be here? I've never encountered so many issues with a game before, even in beta stages.  If I encountered all of this within the first 15 minutes of gameplay, I don't want to even think about how many more bugs await.

Two Point Hospital isn't such a simulation game like the most others. In fact it's far away from showing the reality but that is what the game makes special and lovely!
It includes [u] a lot [/u] of sarcasm and humorism in general. The diseases/illnesses the patient have follow this line and are therefore more funny than anything of realistic. I mean we're speaking from illnesses like Cubism, Floppy Discs, Grey Anatomy, Jazz Hand, Premature Mummification, Cauliflower Ears, Flat-Packed etc...
And really, it makes so much fun to discover all these different diseases and everytime you experience something new you have to laugh because it's always connected with a funny anecdote.
And in general it has to be said that Two Point Hospital has such a lot of lovely details in it which makes the game only even more great. With that I mean for example the loudspeaker announcements- this woman is so funny with the little things she tells and you often have to smile about it, the same goes with the announcements trough the radio. And the stil of the graphic fits also perfectly!
And even if you only have the main game without any DLC, you can spend a lot of time in that game! I spent round about 100 hours only in the main game, because I had a lot of fun to collect all possible stars for every different hospital- it gets never boring!
I can also tell that the DLC are worth it too because there is also so many new things to discover, new diseases, new hospitals, new challenges, new landscapes etc... 

I don't say that often, but I have no negative aspect about that game, I'm just really happy with it!

The game has improved a lot since the original release and there are zero bugs today. The top negative reviews are outdated.

* There are room templates, you can easily copy rooms.
* GP queues were fixed, the #1 patient could go away to get a drink or cafeteria, and the queue would be blocked for a while.
* All bugs were fixed. I recall one where a doctor could get stuck on a cell, forever bugging a cell of the map, that was fixed a year or two after release.
I love this game. Simple and relaxing. If you loved Theme Hospital this is for you.

Two Point Hospital offers an enjoyable amount of complexity, but makes it simple and approachable with a gentle learning curve, clear interface, and handy tools to see what is going wrong. Even in a fully developed hospital, placing rooms differently is not too much of a headache, which allows you to experiment with different layouts. You can always pause the game, take a good look around and modifiy you layout without having to restart the mission.

You can gain 3 stars in each mission. Only the first star is required to unlock the next mission, and you only have to understand the new element introduced by a mission to get this. You gain additional rooms and items in new missions, so if you ever have trouble getting the second or third star, you can continue the campaign and revisit the hospital later, with your new items and experience to get it done (Although its perfectly doable to gain all the stars with the equipment you got at the start of the mission - switching between the hospitals is not required).

The artstyle is easily readable. This is great for a management game like this, because you still see and understand what's going on, even when your hospital is filled with hundreds of patients with wacky illnesses.
The humour makes even the jokiest of joking dads blush. If you dislike the focus on wacky, punny diseases & treatments, Project Hospital might me a better fit for you.

You can spend a lot of time decorating your hospital, if you enjoy this. The option to create room templates and use them in all other missions is great. Now you can design the GP office, Cardiology and Ward of you dreams, and just resize them a little, if need be. There are plenty of decorations, benches, entertainment and food options, allowing you to give your different hospitals different styles. When you gain new decorative items, you can put them in your room template and use them from then on. Every GP office of mine now has this fancy cocktail-bar-hidden-in-a-globe from the Bigfoot DLC. My Doctors deserve a pick-me-up now and then!
If you don't want to spend too much time decorating, you can also copy&paste the same item to improve the decor.

With a predecessor the likes of Theme Hospital, this game scratches all the right itches. I love many aspects about the game, such as the off-the-wall illnesses and quirky cures, the loads of neat decorations, the blueprint, copy and paste tools and even the training and research. I like how my blueprints and unlocked research translates across all locations in the same organization, making going back and restarting levels so satisfying. Just like Theme Hospital, this game is supposed to keep you on the brink of being overwhelmed, and sometimes mercilessly tossing you over the edge, but I love it! It makes it so much more satisfying when you can earn that extra star unlock that next level! Some also may complain about the dlcs not being free or that there are decoration packs for purchase, but honestly, this game is worth every penny and then some! For such a low entry price, you can't go wrong!

Fun building aspect and decent humor. The game can be somewhat repetitive, but the ever expanding lists of items and DLC help. I wish it were easier to place some items, but the controls are fairly decent. Clicking on rooms to copy them can be difficult. Room design also seems pointless as most people spam medicine cabinets and gold certificates so the rooms look awkward with certificates everywhere and items out of place. I would have preferred the ability to modify my hospital in a more passive way while keeping the aesthetics visually appealing. As it is, items have to be placed in odd ways simply to ensure temperature and beauty requirements. I enjoy the game at times and continue to play it from time to time. It would be nice if all items were available to use from the beginning of the game rather than requiring the completion of challenges to unlock. The game also needs a manual save feature as its easy to build yourself into a negative budget and have no recourse as the game has already auto saved.

The good: This is indeed the spiritual successor of Theme Hospital. Better graphics, better gameplay and funnier.

The bad: Some stages are almost unplayable but you can "kinda cheat" by pumping research in a previous map and cash out on your new map. There are also some imbalances in the patient inflow / hospital level and a steep learning curve but the fun provided heavily outweighs these issues.

The ugly: DLC's have almost nothing to offer and are pumped out at near speed of light rate. I would expect more than 3 maps for their price.

The verdict: The game is decent for the price and an absolute steal when on sale. 8/10 Excellent management / tycoon game

Two Point Hospital is described as a "spiritual successor" to cult favorite Theme Hospital but is so close to the original game that I would call it sequel. It was developed by a team that includes two of the original Theme Hospital developers and maintains the same theme and humor while updating it for the modern day. It includes a number of features that were desired for Theme Hospital including room templates, an easy to customize music, and the ability to easily run on a modern system. The skills and mechanics of the game have been updated and expanded with the game's map having a smoother learning curve for new players. If you have played Theme Hospital you'll understand most of the game very easily but also find it [i]almost[/i] too easy until the later maps as mechanics are introduced more slowly compared to Theme Hospital.

There are a few negatives to the game I found that include the inability to change UI colors with background and foreground colors being too close for comfort on some monitors, a clunky UI that feels counterintuitive and often requires more action to accomplish something than in Theme Hospital. There are also items that probably should be nerfed and certain mechanics, like not really requiring seating for patients, that should probably also be fixed.

All-in-all if you enjoyed the original Theme Hospital or any of the Theme games from that era or just want a light-hearted simulator game with a lot of humor you'll probably enjoy this game. However if you are looking for something that is more serious, has sharper graphics, or plays like a board game you might find your hopes dashed.

The year is 1997, you're rocking up to your little box shaped desktop computer and your mum tells you that she bought you a new game.  The game is Theme Hospital.  You get to build your own hospital, treat patients with weird illnesses and listen to a rather chipper lady announce obscure things over the tannoy system.  The game is amazing, funny and you have a blast.

Now, the year is 2021. You see the title, 'Two Point Hospital'.  The graphics bear a striking resemblance to something you've seen before... Suddenly a wave of nostalgia hits you and you're reliving the terrifying days of running into debt trying to cure someone with 'the squits'.  You watch the trailer for the video and that haunting voice comes back to you: 'We're sorry for the litter that YOU dropped on our floor'.  She's back.  The game is back.  You have to relive building hospitals and managing your money like you actually know what you're doing whilst trying to cure patients with weird diseases.
But this time, there's a twist.  You have an amazing radio to go with the game. Now you can listen to the dulcet tones of Harrison Wolff lulling you to sleep whilst you try your best not to let anyone die.

TLDR; This game is amazing and if you have played and loved Theme Hospital previously, this is an absolute must for you. It will hit you in the feels with all the nostalgia (and I swear the got the same lady as the announcer, it's insane how much they sound alike xD)

This is a hospital builder, very similar to Theme Hospital for those that remember playing it. Build treatment rooms, enhance your hospital, hire staff and cure strange illnesses. It's fun to watch all the patients and staff interact with each other and all the strange, hilarious illnesses, like pan-demic. Patients with literally a pan stuck on their heads.

The gameplay is exactly the same as Theme Hospital. They improved the graphics, added loads more illnesses and treatment rooms to cure them, and expanded the room building UI with a lot more options for room decor items.

If you wanted a modernised Theme Hospital with pretty much the same gameplay as before then I would recommend this game. However, if you were expecting for something more than the original Theme Hospital in terms of gameplay then you may end up a little disappointed.

The DLCs add a couple more levels to the campaign each, with new treatment rooms to build, but nothing changes about the gameplay and they all become repetitive.

Coming from Cities Skylines, the simulation in this game is mediocre at best. The patient size and types of illnesses at your hospital will always remain the same throughout the gameplay regardless of how much reputation your hospital has. This is pretty unrealistic and entirely unchallenging. To acquire new rooms and new illnesses, the game forces you to create a 2nd hospital or purchase their DLCs. Still, the patient size will never increase, which means the gameplay gets stagnant very quickly.

However, the biggest let down for this game is the variety of rooms they give you. You expand new room options with new hospitals and DLCs. However, other than that, there isn't really any creative freedom in the types of rooms you can build. It'd be so much more playable if they let you to create your own rooms and put whatever items you want in them as in The Sims.

If you like sim games, word play, setting goals, and managing a lot of different tasks at once, then Two Point Hospital is a game for you. 

There are plenty of guides out there to help you find your feet, or you can go my route, dive head first and just sort of float along, starting and restarting areas until you get the hang of things because thanks to youtube videos, I know that I never ever want to take out a loan, that slippery slope. 

Sometimes the pace can be overwhelming, especially when you start to head into the later levels and star requirements, with disasters, chaos and a sheer lack of space all begin to work against you and you have to carefully move, arrange and solve the problems, but I love it. I especially love the saved rooms mechanic that was added in, because that has saved me a lot of time when I just want to throw down another decent Gp's office, or bathroom when all the patrons and staff start to complain

I love the graphics, and the style, and the disease names. They're very creative and though some are unfortunate in relation to current events (2019 - 2021), it really makes you feel like you're accomplishing something as you watch the the diagnosis and cure animations for the different rooms in action.

I've had this game in my library for a long while now and only decided maybe three days ago to install it and play. I've been playing so much since, it's very addictive. It's pretty relaxing, the art style is fun and interesting, and there are several different levels (individual hospitals with unique challenges) to play, including a sandbox mode where you can make your own challenges! There's plenty of content to keep you busy for hours. I have 16 hours at the time of writing this, and I've only got four levels to 3 stars. There's a lot more to go but I'm enjoying every minute of it!

I love how it compares your stats to your friends! You can even work together to unlock research projects, or compete against each other for a special in game currency. 

Overall, I highly recommend snagging this game! It's really enjoyable and you'll find the time just soars by while playing.

I like the game's overall stylistics, visuals, sound and gameplay. It's great, amusing and funny. The game shows a good sense of humour while having a lot of interesting tasks to entertain you.
But there are some things which are not implemented good enough. The game contains several abuse mechanics which are easily found and exploited, making some of the features useless. And after some missions, the game tends to be repetitive when you already know the algorithm and just repeat it until you reach all level goals.
But the biggest issue for me is coop/mp mechanics. It'd rather had none of that than having an existing one. You literally play by yourself and just check the progress of the global mission to see if your friend is still playing or not. Feels like a joke from devs.
To summarize - goods stylistic, catchy gameplay and amusing jokes, but not enough diversity and challenges to enjoy it for a while. Yet, IMO, it is enough to be worth every penny. Definitely recommended for fans of the building simulator genre.

I got this as it reminded of a classic from my childhood - Theme Hospital. This game scratches exactly that itch and more. In general, the play is pretty 'easy' and can even be a little repetitive at times but if you get really stuck in, some levels can actually be quite challenging. A lot of the achievements require patience and tweaking of your hospital e.g. assigning specialist staff to certain rooms, marketing properly and so on. The graphics are great and I like the style overall. The illnesses are very creative, as are the ways of curing them. I've played about 80 hours so far and it isn't too taxing but keeps me happily occupied and destresses me after a long day. The DLCs are more interesting than the main game I would say and well worth buying, especially on sale. I would prefer more customisation, like multiple floors and changing the room styles but these are minor :) Overall, I recommend this if you like micromanaging an almost pointless and illogical hospital.

TLDR: For anybody who has any doubt: Two Point Hospital IS Theme Hospital from decades ago. But not in the good way. 

Two Point Hospital is a funny take on a Hospital Tycoon game with its origins very clearly set back in the Theme Park days of the 90's. Build up a hospital, make some money, expand and repeat. Try not to kill patients. Two Point Hospital does this, much like it's predecessor, with a slightly dark sense of humor. There are almost no real illnesses (the only exception I can think of is broken bones) and some of the made-up ones are genuinely funny. 

The game has a campaign that gently introduces players to new concepts, as well as new conditions and their treatments. There are always up to three stars that can be achieved in a campaign mission, with varying objectives for each. Getting three stars at the beginning is virtually impossible, as certain objects still need to be unlocked in later mission. You then go back to the ealier missions. Personally I like this. I also like that there are unlockable cosmetic items in the campaign map that you can use on all the mission. These feel like they might be paid-for unlockables in a mobile game but they are all unlockable with in-game currency. 

The game looks, for the genre, quite good. The only other modern Hospital Tycoon game I can think of is Project Hospital and Two Point Hospital looks much better. But then, even though it's the same sub-genre, they are totally different games, so I think a comparision is almost a little unfair. The one thing I will say in Two Point Hospitals favour in regards to display is the UI. This is one aspect of the game I was super impresed with. Everything is easy to find, easy to use and looks great.

I really have only one issue with the game. The trouble is, it's a rather big one. As mentioned earlier, the gameplay consists of build up a hospital, make some money, expand and repeat. Apart from staff training and different building layouts on the maps, that's it. In other words, while the UI and the graphics have had a big ol' overhaul, the gameplay is EXACTLY the same as the 1997 game it was so obviouly based on and man, that gameplay has aged.

As much as I loved Theme Hospital and as much as I love many aspects of this game, I just cannot recommend it. I've racked-up some hours on this game but that's only because I've returned to this game repeatedly, telling myself that it must be good, given I loved the original so much. But then I play a maximum for 20-30 mins and realise it was probably just nostalgia.
If you miss playing Theme Hospital, this game is for you.

Original review: Great time sink if you want the nostalgia of Theme Hospital. This title does a wonderful job of capturing the essence of TH, but something they did not bring to this title is very important and with out it leaves me feeling like I am playing a glorified FB game; threshold settings. 

You can limit the individuals to certain tasks, but unlike TH you cannot (as far as I can tell) set when these tasks should be completed. 60%? 90%? I am talking about being tired of constantly having to pause the game to individually select every plant that I would like to have watered. The need to select each machine before it catches fire. 

If development continues, please please !please! add slider function that, like the "when should I take a break found in policy settings" feature, is applied to, "when should I water the plants? When should I stock the machines? When should I do what I am supposed to do?"

Unless this lack-of-feature was meant to highlight the current (2019) real-world workforce (manager IRL) where we have to tell them everything they are supposed to do all the time, even after training and instruction, this is simply unplayable and frustrating because it becomes a major process of gameplay. Not why I bought it and as much as I would love for this to be a positive review for all of the things they do well (radio, DJ commentary, many customization options, hits the Bullfrog feel, the overall "fun" feature of the franchise)... I just can't with such a simple tuning ability not being included.

Please fix this issue.

Two Point Hospital is quite simply dull. Wonderful animations and humor to it with a good dose of modern game design to it. However quite soon you have seen all the game has going for it, add more buildings that have little more than a different animation to them, constant bottlenecks that you just need to live with and repeat. All that makes an ok game to be fair, but the issues I really have with the game are the needless elements trying to make it into some online "experience". It constantly tells you about what your friends have done, with no reference to what that means from a game they have not played for months and the odd challenges that can be done alone meaning you need to get them back into it if you want an item, or even convince them to buy it. It is a shame to see so little done to make a good management game but instead trying to chase online trends that I have no interest in while playing a solo game.
I love this game, hella addicted, can't say theres anything wrong with it.

Short Summary:
Well, like others have said and I will also say: It's Theme Hospital but better. If you like hospital management sims, Two Point is the best mix of building, upgrading, teaching and micromanagement to keep you engaged while still staying true to it's silly roots. It's a bunch of former Bullfrog devs making this game, so it's an updated but good clone which makes me very happy.

Long Summary:
It's a perfectly serviceable game, which is weird to write because you'd think you want an exciting title to really keep your attention and distract you. However, like most management games, the best written review I think  I can give this game is that if you lose more than a few hours playing each time, it's (hopefully) a good management game. 

Overall it's bug free, solid experience which reminds me of a 90's Toyota Corolla and all the truisms that came with owning a vehicle like that at the time: Dependable, Bland and full of Features you would and would not expect. 

I'd like more outfits and more decorative items and while I already looked at the Workshop, I hope they'll add more in the future. The selection in the Workshop is pretty great for carpets and some room items, but I can't seem to find what I want, but that's NOT the fault of the devs or the Workshop content creators. 

Everything functions just it should game play wise and other that the Three Star achievement hellscapes that Duckworth Upon Bilge and Rotting Hill are, it will keep you engaged for some time.

Current DLCs Review:
I own the all the current DLCs ( as of 3/19/2021 ) and while I have not beaten any the new levels, I do like the stuff I got in the DLCs. They're NOT necessary to enjoy the base game however.
It's Theme Hospital in a new and shiny version. Just as lovely. Strategy-ish, resource management-ish, people wrangling to the max. Fun sicknesses and a lot of developer attention. Awesome!

When that itch to play Theme Hospital comes around, I could blow the dust off my old Windows XP machine, plug it up to my monitors and wait for XP to painfully boot then load the game. Or, I could jump on Steam and load this gem up. Sega of Europe did a fantastic job revitalizing this times old title! It embodies what Theme Hospital was and takes two steps forward. To say the least, I love it. Two Point Hospital, Sega, what a wonderful job you've done keep it up!

What sounds like the opening line of a joke, is in Two Point Hospital a clear sign that your current strategy to run this hospital is failing. Maybe you did not hire the doctors with the necessary qualifications or train the nurses or installed the necessary equipment but somewhere the diagnostic process went wrong, so your patients will keep dying like flies.  What makes this game so great is that it works on both the macro strategy level and the individual level - it is fun to watch interacting the gazillion characters with each other and the medical devices. Well balanced, the game difficulty is rather low at the beginning and increases within each new hospital and throughout the game. And although it has plenty of ironic comments on modern health factories, it feels also impressively correct in its depiction of how these buildings are conceptualized and work in reality. While playing, I heard (in my mind) colleagues saying things this like "My new office is now in front of a toilet, urgh, and then there is this vending machine where people gather and chat the entire day. I cannot concentrate at all.", "The cardio diagnostic? I don't know. Last week, it was next door, but they keep moving this around constantly.", or "The teaching room? It is somewhere in this isolated, empty part of the building. Rather spooky there." And just like working in a real hospital, you will spend more time in Two Point Hospital than you contractually are obliged to. Addictive.

Pros:

Cons: 

After the first few hospitals - same thing over and over. Yes, there's a new disease but everything else is the same.

Then there is a bug or a mechanic (I really don't know exactly) where nurses and doctors just stand in their room waving at patients instead of curing them. 

Room levels are also more frustrating than interesting. I ended up with small rooms filled with dozens of small pictures so the room has its max level 5. I don't see the point behind this mechanic since the level gets calculated only by the total value of the room. Size doesn't matter anymore like it did in Theme Hospital.

The 90s are back, and they are better than I remember them. This game is pretty much just like the old sims, but upgraded in every way. 

The gameplay is the typical "I'll just this one more thing and I'm turning the game off". There's always something for you to do, something to upgrade, hire, or improve. It has the potential to suck you in for hours, assuming you're into management games.  I think that map variety could be slightly better, but that's not really an issue when the core gameplay is just so good. 

Two point hospital gives off vibes similar to Monty Python. I absolutely love the slightly dark, tongue in cheek, absurd humour ("Clean up required. Dead patient in the corridor." "Patients are asked not to sleep in hospital beds. We are busy, recover at home."). At first I had slight reservations due to the cartoonish-style graphics, but it turns out they work out quite well, making running a hospital not as grim as you'd expect it to be and underlining the slight absurdity of everything.

And then there's the music. It's slightly goofy, but not annoyingly so, and it contributes to the overall relaxing experience. I actually remember several tunes in my head, which is quite rare for soundtrack for new releases. It's distinct, it fits, and Big Foot's Commute is the best track in the game (challenge me if you will on that, but I am not changing my mind, NO SIR!). And there are radio stations (just like in, say, Cities Skylines), with DJs that actually have distinct, satirical personalities.

Feels just like the old bullfrog games, but without the elements that we'd consider outdated today. An old classic uplifted to new heights, if you will.

[h1]What:[/h1]
The successor to Theme Hospital, properly done.

[h1]When:[/h1]
Modern Day.

[h1]Where:[/h1]
Two Point County, a sleepy, minimally drawn bay of towns.

[h1]Why:[/h1]
Simulate hospital staff and patients, treat wacky illnesses, and keep everyone paid, fed, and happy.

[h1]Significance:[/h1]
Attempt to manage many people, cure them with ever expensive treatments, and accepting that many will likely die (but only after they've walked back into the hallway).

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
Huge post-release development effort based on community feedback, hundreds of hours of dynamic and unique gameplay, and a dedication to the predecessor.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
Somewhat tedious room decoration, for marginal effect. Logical design flaws, such as patients returning to GP for re-evaluation after each diagnosis. A disconnect between each individual hospital, the research being game-wide, and milestones - could be better if there were more regional connects, such as a shared budget, talent pool, or milestones being more important. Too many DLC.

[h1]Summary:[/h1]
A faithful recreation of an old classic. Two Point Hospital serves as a strong example of how to take a concept, improve the graphics, and use modern techniques to produce valuable art and entertainment. I'm really not a fan of all the DLC.

Rating: 6/10

[h1] "Win in 15 Minutes Waiting Simulator" gives you the sense of being a patient in the queue to a doctor but in reverse. You get value for 15 minutes each level and then wait for 3 hours for the level to end.  [/h1]

This game is sick with massive amount of data that makes it hard to diagnose what you really need to do to win each level in the campaign - which is absolutely nothing.
It's a weird game.
It is fun and yet boring.
It is nostalgic yet fails like all those new age crap games.
The issue is that most of the mechanisms in the game don't matter if you just want to win the campaign. This game is properly meant to spend your time in sandbox on meaningless micromanagement and decorating - and it does an awesome job at that. It is a good hospital management game.  But if your goal is to win some goals, you can do it in any hospital within the first 15 minutes after which you'll jest stare at the screen, accepting all inbox messages without even reading them, train here a bit, upgrade there a smooch and wait for 3 star. 

People die. Doesn't matter.
Staff unhappy. Doesn't matter.
Everyone is hungry, bored, need to pee, thirsty, sick, throwing up, running from ghosts, complaining on long queues, eating off the vomit ridden floors... Does. Not. Matter.

At least now I know why the global health system looks the way it is. They are busy with monobeasts instead of treating people... well, I don't blame them. Shooting the bastards is so much fun.

PS. Seriously, F Camouflage Falls!

TPH is a very fun game, but be warned, it will suck you in and half a day will pass by without you even noticing.

If you are a tidy person, efficiency is your middle name and you are driven by an urge to optimize everything you can or can't get your hands on, then you will most likely breeze through this game, following the natural order of micromanagement leading to automation.

I do as such, but still enjoy the game tremendously, even though I have to remind myself once in a while that it is still a game and I do wish sometimes that I took a bit more time to appreciate all the funny little jokes and interactions, many of which you will certainly miss if your camera is zoomed out for the sake of efficiency.

Do I recommend TPH?
Absolutely! This game is a gem, nearly a 10/10 for me, with only a few inconsistencies, such as the infamous Benches, which the game so often reminds you to make use of, but you actually should not, I speak from experience.

I am really looking forward to seeing more from Two Point Studios, perhaps even a Two Point Hotel?
That would be fantastic and much needed in the community.

Two Point Hospital is a hospital simulator in the sense of games such as Thene Hospital from 1997. Where the player is tasked as the Dean of Medicine and tasked with helping diagnosis and treat nonsensical diseases and ailments for a nice profit.

Twin Point does this over the span of a campion where, over time more diseases and complicated issue will challenge a player to treat their patients and to achieve the objectives set out for them by the local government. I will first give credit for taking a complex subject such as medicine and making it engaging and fun, to the point that this game can be considered a spiritual successor to Theme Hospital which defined the genre in the 1990’s. Second, the curve for Two Point is the perfect valence of challenging but fair with the backdrop of whacky antics to keep the player entertained. In my experience this resulted in several close calls for optional objectives and streamlining of my hospital to achieve efficiency. The biggest complaint I can give the game is the backlog you may experience, where in several missions I would have patients die because they would take forever to be diagnosed. To the point where 8-10 fully trained doctors that could rival Dr House for their skills could not break the backlog.

Overall, Twin Point Hospital is a whacky medicinal simulator, that if your looking for a causal builder simulator within the medical field, this is the game for you.

The AI on this is really really bad. To the point I can't play anymore. I can't keep my plants watered and things fixed without a ridiculous amount janitorial. And even if that was intentional, I really dislike that when I go through a signal 5 different plants to be watered, that I get 5 different janitors and they do not take proximity into consideration at all. If you have a janitor on the other side of the hospital who takes his sweet time moseying on over to water a plant you're in for a bad time. 

I couldn't play past the second stage because by the time I had built that one up to occupy about 75% of the map I was spending all my time flagging things to be attended to by janitors. So hire more I might hear you say. He just doesn't know how to play the game you might quip.  But I did hire more. And you know what they do with a hospital full of janitorial tasks to be done?  They all stand around and do nothing and I get constantly told by the advisor that I have too many janitors and that they have nothing to do. Yet if I look at the heatmap for janitor tasks, there are red items everywhere. It was becoming a practice in frustration so I quit and am about to uninstall. I really really really wanted to like this game. But I want to build a hospital that becomes self sufficient. Not micromanage janitors that can't see a dying plant beside them. 

As a side note I did look to see if there were any workshop mods for the AI, but unfortunately they only allow cosmetic mods.

This game is a manifestation of what is wrong with the industry.
While the old version had an "absolute" difficulty-level where you needed to work and grow in order to succeed, this version can be played by a toddler. Yes ... you may challenge yourself to get a few extra stars (candy) but there are no consequences if you fail. Just play the next level and have fun ... right? No need to strain yourself!

It is part of the trend toward games of reward vs games of consequence and I really dislike this trend.
While the old version is a tool packaged as a game, this version is just pure entertainment.
If you want that ... go for it. I don't like it so I can't recommend it!
