I really love this game. I grew up on playing Theme Hospital as a kid. Since then over the years I have redownloaded Theme Hospital a few times and it's still a great game but very dated. I found out about Two Point Hospital but knew I didn't have the time to play games. Since second lockdown I have had more free time so downloaded it and this is all I'm doing in my free time and I love it! If you played Theme Hospital you will LOVE this. The graphics are really cute, the humour is on point (especially for the Brits) and the challenges make it so fun. I also think the soundtrack is brilliant. I find myself singing Nice Smelling Face and Fish Whispers quite a lot. I really like the radio idea and that there is a host. It is to Theme Hospital what LOTR Two Towers is to the Fellowship: a sequel that improves on something that was already great.

I will say that it can get a bit tricky in the higher levels as your reputation increases relatively quickly and then you get way more patients than you can handle quite early on. You need money to build diagnostics but the real money comes from the strange treatment rooms which can be quite expensive with a low influx of those patients. The queues for GPs build up pretty quickly with people on deaths door, even when you select "Send straight to treatment at threshold" option. I still haven't managed to build a perfectly run and efficient hospital yet that can keep up with the ever growing number of patients, while training staff and having them appropriately assigned to keep up the cure rate. Also low cure rate and high prices does not seem to lower overall reputation, it just pisses people off and they rage quit but the reputation is find and you still get more patients. It would be nice to increase reputation slowly which would be more realistic. On that note, there are too many VIP visitors to the hospital and you don't have the opportunity to reject them. 
I also think there should be more repercussion for patients dying too, they die and then nothing bad really happens. I once had a cure rate of 60% and I still won hospital of the year.

Thanks for developing this game I am very happy!

Team Hospital is back better than ever.

Old school gamers will probably remember Bullfrog (RIP) who made Theme Hospital as a spinoff of their succesful Theme Park. It was a whimsical hospital tycoon game before the term 'tycoon' became a genre term with a heavy focus on humour.

You do not treat real illnesses: instead you get farcical diseases such as Lightheadedness, where someone's head becomes a lightbulb, and the treatment is to send them to a device which unscrews the lightbulb and attaches a new head. Or someone is rendered in greyscale, and the treatment is to spray paint on them.
As the game goes on the diseases become increasingly more absurd and it can be real fun to just watch the sick people stumble around with all the weird effects that happen to them.

Two Point Hospital is almost a Theme Hospital clone - and that is a good thing. You run a series of hospitals where you start with an empty building and have to create offices for doctors to diagnose, treat, and cure patients. As the game progresses you unlock more and more different diseases and treatments for them and soon it becomes a real challenge to build everything you need while keeping up with the never ending influx of patients.
Each hospital has its own three star goals, with one star needed to unlock other hospitals so the additional goals are only there to provide an extra challenge.

With over 40 hours in I still haven't unlocked everything but I'm at the point where I can say without question that this game is worth your money and time. In addition to the hefty base game content there are expansion packs which add new items, hospitals, diseases and treatments, and the game also features workshop support for even more content.

The music is also a high point. The base game has fitting music tracks but on the workshop you can find a lot more to add and there is an option to enable or disable individual tracks.

Besides being a super fun management simulator, I love the variety of fun, wacky, diseases that come into my hospitals, and I also appreciate the various goals and challenges that I have to work to meet in Two Point Hospital. My one complaint so far (34 hours in) is that I haven't been able to progress very far on the research projects. Once I figured out how that aspect of the game worked I got super excited (especially with the larger initiatives that many players can participate in) because it's fun to work towards a collective goal with other players in my own hospitals, but I was frustrated by some of the personal research projects since I don't have any friends who play this game and some of the research nodes require 2 or more players to participate in order to complete them. So essentially, I'm just stuck. Other than that I am definitely going to keep playing and I aim to get three stars on every hospital (so far so good)!

However, if like me, you have nothing but fond memories of the silly humor, the straight forward game mechanics, a challenging-not-taxing gaming experience, and enjoy a game where interior design is a significant part of the the game design, then Two Point Hospital brings it. While almost entirely fan service to it's spiritual predecessor, the game brings many modern expectations to the table in a fun and engaging way. While it's true that this isn't going to push hardcore sim fans who spend as much time running spreadsheets as they do actually playing the game, there's still a lot on offer here that makes the game worth the time investment as long as you know what you're getting into.

This game is great, I regret waiting so long to pick it up. From the masterful deployment of mechanics and new rooms in the level design, to the quirky bad humor, and the overall pacing, it's just great. I will elaborate a little further on everything I have mentioned here and try not to gush too much with irrelevant side-notes.

Audio/Visual Experience (9/10) - The game has a simple art style that works very well for it and it adheres to that nicely throughout. The animations are quirky and amusing, and everything is pulled together with the game's blunt and dry sense of humor. As an example "Lightheadedness" is one of the first diseases you will encounter, where the cure is to use a machine to unscrew the bulb from someone's neck and replace it with a head. From the sound side of things, I can't really say enough. The game does an excellent job with audio queues that aren't too annoying, the music is good, and the occasional interjection from the radio personalities is a fun way to break things up.

Game-play (9/10) - Two Point Hospital has everything you require from most sim/tycoon style games to make the experience enjoyable. There are proper metrics, stats, and tool-tips to help you along, the room system is intuitive, and there is plenty to keep you busy. I am breaking flow out into a separate category this time because I believe that is where this game truly shines. But as for the general game-play, I found myself wanting for no feature or content in my 25 hrs so far. It's a really rare thing when you don't imagine half a dozen things you would like to be added to a game in that amount of time.

Flow (10/10) - This is where Two Point Hospital makes the transition from a good game to a great game. The rate at which they introduce new mechanics and content to you, as well as the pacing of events during general game-play here is outstanding. It is one of those scenarios where the game keeps you so engaged that you can easily let yourself be taken in and suddenly hours have passed. I was surprised after the first couple of maps when I was still unlocking new mechanics in the game. By the time I was on to map three and four, I was excited to keep moving through them to see what was next. The intentional design of the constant additional content and mechanics could not have been delivered any better in my opinion and is the greatest strength of the game.

Narrative (9/10) - It's a sim/tycoon style game, so we don't expect an epic on par with the Odyssey here or anything. With that state of mind going in though, Two Point does a lot of world building and storytelling through the radio like I had mentioned earlier. You will find yourself looking around the map later in the game and recognizing places based on things you have heard on the radio or visitors you have had at your hospitals. I think this is a great narrative design for this kind of game and it honestly surprised me a little.

Overall (9.5/10) - Like I said in the beginning, it's just great, one of the best installments in the genre I have played in a long time. Two Point Hospital is a charming game and will leave your brain in a dopamine addled state that will have you drooling for more every time they ring the bell! I highly recommend you check this one out if you have any interest.

A point in most of the negative reviews is that the game is very repetitive and not difficult enough.

Once starting the game, you begin with a small hospital on a new map and a set of goals to reach. If you reach those goals, the hospital gets the first star and you can move to the next, bigger hospital which introduces new mechanics. But, first, you have to build the new hospital from scratch, and that is boring.

However, apart from moving directly to the next hospital, you can opt for reaching the second and third star for the hospital, and getting those turns out to be really difficult.

You are free to switch between all your hospitals and share knowledge (e.g. research) between them (but not money :)). So, yes, it's true that you will build many hospitals from scratch, and this can get quite boring.

However, I play two or three hospitals to three stars and then I pause the game for several months. WIth this playstyle, I find the game perfect and challenging. In the first hospitals, it really only comes down to placing objects to win the stars, but in later hospitals you really have to manage wages, training slots (allrounder or specialist), recreating times and so on. So, if you are in for micromanagement, this game is for you.

Looking for a relaxing management tycoon game? Here you go. The difficulty curve is pretty shallow, it really only gets hard if you want to push for high scores. You only need 1 star per hospital to progress all the way through the game and are  never required to compete against other players, it's optional. It does get a little difficult if you want to get 3 stars on every hospital, or challenge yourself by out doing your friends on leader boards for hospital value or cure rates, etc.

This reminds me a lot of old school relaxing management sims from decades ago, what you see in the trailers is a pretty accurate summary of what you can expect while playing.

My only complaints are you don't really have any control over the outside shape of the buildings, but you do have full custom control over everything inside (even to the point of being able to change it instantly on the fly with no penalty, which goes a long way towards why this game is so easy, you can revamp everything, constantly as needed without issue). And secondly the speed controls should have an even faster option, even playing in fast can take a long time to treat patients and wait for an income.

So while there's a lot of fun in designing your hospital layouts and some depth to the managing of staff, it's actually kind of shallow in difficulty and once you get past the learning curve there's a lot of just waiting for income as you can't speed the game up by very much.

Overall if you like this style of game it's probably worth getting, but I don't think it's worth full price, and the DLC are cute, but also really expensive for what they contain. IMO the base game is worth at least $20 while the DLC are worth maybe $4 each. 

I paid about $30 for the entire bundle of the game plus the 3 main DLC (Pebberley, Bigfoot, Close Encounters) (not including the retro items pack which is just cosmetic) and I'm not disappointed, but I'd have been a little put off if I'd paid full price for everything.

(Full price for Game plus all DLC while I write this would be almost $70, this is not a $70 game, but it's definitely a really good $30 one)

2PH stands above the rest with its eccentric character models, hospital designs, and its mature humor on awareness of contemporary politics around privatized healthcare and late-stage capitalism.

What it really excels at is its ability to streamline the UI and have simplistic goals for the player to achieve, leaving you feeling fulfilled at every challenge. 

However, it's greatest strength is also its greatest weakness as time goes on, its simplicity in achievements soon becomes too easy for the seasoned player. The freedom that is enjoyed in a regular city builder falls short as every level is not meant for creativity since every level is a pre-designed building, allowing for players to only dwell upon the interior rather than a marriage of both interior and exterior. 

Another weakness I find in 2PH's gameplay is its pacing, namely, its "reputation" system that awards players with more customers. However, this "award" system and its incentives to keep up with the amassing customer base quickly forces the player to move away from building a unique, creative, beautiful healthcare center that cares for its patients, into a profit machine seeking maximum efficiency at all times. Which turns this game into more than just a game, but a statement on contemporary politics and late-stage capitalism, where greed only breeds unhappiness and dissatisfaction while creativity shies away from efficiency and productivity.

For the first couple of levels I loved this game - a nice and modern version of Theme Hospital, with a quirky art style and a bunch of new fun illnesses to treat. It runs well, even on my somewhat bad computer, it has easy-to-use controls, and the gradual increase in difficulty is just right, at least for me. 

However, after getting a bit further into the game, a disturbing trend started to emerge.

Jest Infection: An illness where the patient dresses and acts like a clown. Treatment? Put them in a circus-themed room, then scare all the fun out of them. Barking Mad (from the Bigfoot DLC, which I got as part of a combo deal when I first got the game): An illness where the patient believes themself to be a dog, and thus dresses up in a dog costume and starts behaving like a dog. Treatment? Put them in a dog-themed room and let them indulge in their dog-like habits, then violently shake them around to scare the dog behavior out of them.

See the pattern that these are establishing? That's right: they're horrifyingly similar to the real life practices of conversion therapy. "Illnesses" that are really just the "patient" expressing their identity without hurting anyone, being treated by violently traumatizing the "patient" until they start associating that part of their identity with fear and pain... all presented as just quirky and fun comedic violence, and always presented as morally correct. It's disgusting, and leaves a sour taste in the mouth of any LGBTQ+ person or observant ally playing the game. 

It's really disappointing to see this kind of stuff in a modern game. If not for these "illnesses" the game would be great fun, but as is, the only reason I've been able to enjoy playing it at all is ignorance, first from not having gotten far enough and later from pretending like I didn't see it (despite the nausea that rose up whenever I thought about it). That only worked for so long, though, and now I'm here. 

I'm done being willfully ignorant, and I'm officially condemning this game. Don't get it, don't play it, don't support it in any way - at least until these illnesses are removed from it entirely.

I bought Two Point Hospital a year ago. I played for 45 minutes and it didn't grab me. I tried again a couple of months ago. Same thing. However, once I really gave it a try I've been quite addicted and very pleased. I think you will be too.

Two Point Hospital is the spiritual successor to Theme Hospital, with Two Point Studios being founded by the very people who made Theme Hospital back in the 90s. I didn't play Theme Hospital much back so Two Point is a novel experience for me. So what it is? It's a business simulation that appears cartoony and shallow but is really funny and deep. You have to build a hospital to heal the sick. You build rooms, hire and train staff, set prices, research and upgrade your equipment in the quest for health and profit. It's not overwhelming but there's almost always something to do. 

You're given a series of scenarios, each one posing a different challenge to build your most optimal hospital in the "shell" of  a few buildings. The layout of the exterior of the buildings are fixed but you can build internally however you want. Part of the game is making optimal layouts for both your staff and your patients. That means minimizing walking, providing restrooms, food, entertainment and the like. The longer the patients are there, the more money you can make. 

This is a serious sim but it doesn't have serious diseases. No COVID or cancer here. Light-headedness is a patient with a light bulb for a head. It, of course, has to be unscrewed with a wacky device. Animal Magnetism of course has animals stuck to the patient. You'll have Freddie Mercury wannabes running around, patients that are made out of cubes, mimes, people with pans stuck to their heads (Pandemic, get it?) and even clowns running around. Each might take a machine coupled with a doctor or a nurse, or a psychiatric treatment or even surgery to fix.

Most of these diseases require their own treatment rooms, each with unique machines and decorative items. You might only need a drug mixer to have a Pharmacy but you'll want to decorate it up. The better the decorations, the better the prestige score of the room. This in turn gives your patients a more positive feeling and helps the reputation of the hospital. Decorations are unlocked over time, spending a currency earned in game so you can prioritize what you want. If I had any complaints here, it's that there are few objects that can really enhance your score like a particular plaque, so that plaque tends to get spammed a lot. But as you build your rooms, you personalize your hospital. This goes a long way in giving the player some pride in their creation.

As I mentioned above, this is a scenario based game. You'll build your hospital to meet objectives, which unlocks other hospitals. You can quit at one star or continue to get 3 stars for your hospital. You never have to stop playing one though, so you can continue as long as you like. Two Point does a great job of introducing mechanics the first 2/3rds of the scenarios, so you're always learning something new. But there are a few issues with this. One in particular isn't great fun - it's the only one I just did the 1 star so I could move on. The last few scenarios don't introduce much new and the objectives can take a long time. I shouldn't have to just let the game run and go take a shower to wait out an objective. Finally, because you're almost always starting from scratch you tend to have the same build order for quite a while. Thank God you can template rooms because I'd have stopped playing if I had to build another GP office. The last scenario is more of a Sandbox than anything else, so that's waiting for you at the end.

Making money isn't hard once you have the hospital going. It's just a matter of expanding as the money rolls in, training your staff and growling ever-bigger. Most of my hospitals tend to look similar at the end but that's somewhat expected. I've only had to restart once when I didn't understand the scenario. Otherwise, it hasn't been a great challenge. But I've had to think about the pace of expansion and how to best spend my $$$, so it isn't a cakewalk.
  
The graphics are perfect for this game. They look like toons and given the nature of the diseases, they're perfect. They nailed the art style here. This is in large part because the diseases are hilariously absurd. My machine is a beast so I can't comment on how it runs on older machines but I think it would be fine.

Sounds are similarly well done, with appropriate pops, clangs and other sounds you'd expect from a Loony Toons Hospital. The Two Point Radio Station plays in the background and is often funny. The music got a bit samey after a while and I finally turned it off about 30 hours into the game. That's unusual for me. It's not bad but there simply isn't enough of it to keep it fresh. 

Okay, so are there any other downsides? Not really beyond what I mentioned above. The game is really, really well done. There's a goodly amount of DLC if you want but it doesn't offer new mechanics. The DLCs offer more diseases, items and scenarios. So you aren't missing anything by just getting the base game but if you want more then you can add on to the base game for a relatively small amount of money.

As for the time you'll get in, I'm playing around in the last two hospitals. All other scenarios have been 3 starred except one that I didn't much care for. So you're looking at 60 hours or so to play through the scenarios. That's good bang for your buck even at list price, but the game is often for sale at about $10-$15. Either way, if this genre interests you then pick it up. And when you do, don't be like me - give the game a chance. You won't regret it. The only thing I regret is waiting a year to get into this one.

For the past few weeks, I was craving a management style game and Two Point Hospital delivered that greatly!

For anyone who has played games like Roller Coaster Tycoon, you will feel right at home with this game. You are given a building and you must create rooms, hire staff, and decorate accordingly. The game's campaign mode does a great job at introducing the new rooms and features slowly so you can get used to it. You need different rooms to handle the different sicknesses that patients will come in for.

The game has a pleasant cartoony feel. The music is chillaxing and zany to fit the theme of the game. I love how they present the sicknesses in the game. For example: Lightheadedness is a patient who has a lightbulb for a head, and a pandemic patient has a pan for a head. They present the sicknesses in very funny ways that had me grinning at all times. You have to pay attention to your staff as well. They will need breaks, you need to promote them, and as you get higher up into the game, they will need certain skills in order to treat certain illnesses.

Decorating is very fun in the game. You start with basic items, but as you complete objectives, you not only unlock new stages, but you unlock currency to buy new items to decorate your hospital. From arcade machines, to plants, to artwork and statues, and so much more. The replay value on this is extremely high.

The game also has plenty of DLCs for more items, locations, and more if you feel you want to expand your palette. As your hospital gets better and better, things become more chaotic and it's fun trying to keep up with everything. Gotta make sure your staff is taking breaks. Make sure everyone is getting paid fairly, and make sure some of your janitors are ghostbusters. There's just so much to do and so much to enjoy with this game.

Final verdict? Check this game out, especially if you like management games. The game does a great job of easing you in, so even if you are new to management type games, you won't be immediately overwhelmed. So grab yourself a copy and start curing  patients today! Thanks for reading!

This game really pulls you in and helps kill time, and I like that there's a genuine struggle to get the hospital up and running properly. I've spent a ton of time on it, and I like moving on to a new challenge once I've exhausted the current one.

There are a few things I'd wish were better balanced. I have to keep adding more and more GP offices as my hospital expands. I wish there were options to help with that, like making my doctors much faster so they can get through the queue in a timely manner, being able to restrict the flow of patients, assigning a patient diagnosis flow (to send them to specific offices after the GP), being able to set a diagnosis percentage that automatically sends them to treatment (if they're below 100%, they get back in the queue, and I actually caught one that was at 100% waiting to see a GP for diagnosis), or even just being able to put multiple doctors in one office with cubicles or something. My diagnostics section is huge, and my treatment section is quite small.

Another thing is that I wish stats were broken down better so I could calculate how much training my doctors and nurses actually need. The percentages shown are often confusing, and I had to look online to find out that upgraded machines mean your nurses/doctors using them don't need to have perfect stats themselves to be successful with that machine.

This game is hospital building and management sim. Each hospital is also just one part of a growing portfolio of private clinics, surgeries and hospitals. By fulfilling each mission’s first objective, you’ll be able to move onto the next, but progression isn’t completely linear. There’s room to experiment and chart your own course. 
The main reason to return to old haunts is to get a higher star rating by completing the additional objectives. It’s possible to do them all in one go before moving to the next hospital, but slowly in the later regions they start to become demanding.
Progression feels brisk and consistent. New toys are always appearing and throughout it all you’re getting rewarded with kudosh, a special currency that can be spent on items to spice up your sterile rooms.
Missions tends to bleed into each other and gets repetitive, but there's a lot of opinions of multi or single player objectives to spice it up...

Things I've learned about running a hospital in relation to real-life interpretations - 

*You will die and it's not my fault you were born to die.
*There are always too many people to diagnose.
*Fracture Clinic patients suck at curing and aren't worth the time or investment.
*People poo a lot.
*If you die on the street or the subways, but not on my watch, it's not my problem.
*Pay me regardless of success of treatment (and never take out loans).
*Always hire staff who are good people over skilled people.
*I'm a good person really you can believe me look at the plaques which say so.

Lot more to cover too - it's a management game in so many aspects - assign staff to particular roles, build and re-build entire sections to utilise the influx of patients, juggle a multitude of priorities, and be smart about your decisions as they will catch up. The types of illnesses are as funny as they are fantastic and any old fan of the 1997 Bullfrog classic Theme Hospital will immediately regard the pedigree here not as a spiritual successor but as a true sequel. Many quality of life changes and improvements make this one of the definitive management sims of modern times.

If you're here for the long haul the rewards will be yours to claim - for those who have grit.

After two years and over 600 hours of gameplay, I think it's time for a proper review.

While I've never played Theme Hospital, I've watched some playthroughs, and I know some of its developers also worked on Two Point Hospital, so, if you enjoyed Theme Hospital, I definitely recommend you try its spiritual successor.

There are a total of 15 hospitals in the base game’s career mode, each with its own unique challenges, and they each take a couple of hours to complete (depending heavily on your skill and playstyle, of course). Each hospital has a possible three-star rating requiring unique objectives to earn them, and you’ll need to at least earn the first star to unlock further hospitals. Early on, stars also unlock items or machine upgrades, so it’s best to three-star the earlier levels. If you don’t, you can always come back later and continue where you left off.

You have complete control over your staff’s assigned jobs, and, as they gain experience, you can promote and train them, with some jobs, like surgery, requiring them to learn a specific qualification. While it’s best to have specialised staff, hireable staff tends to have terrible qualification combinations, although the game is still manageable if you really need them. Staff can also have traits, which are either good (like walking faster) or bad (like walking slowly).

Patients will need to check in to reception before they are diagnosed and cured of their made-up illnesses. They’ll start to go back and forward between the GP’s office and a myriad of diagnosis rooms, with the more expensive ones being generally better, although each illness reacts differently to each diagnosis room, so even the cheap ones can come in handy, especially early on each level. You also need to keep them happy by providing them with items and facilities to take care of their needs, or else they might refuse to pay for services, or rage quit the hospital outright.

The game is also very charming: item and room descriptions, illnesses, the radio, the tannoy, even the messages you receive - the humour is amazing.

Lastly, but certainly not least, the developers listen to their audience, and the game receives regular updates: they’ve added a sandbox mode, loads of free items, a more difficult R.E.M.I.X. mode for a couple of hospitals, and more.

I really enjoy this simulation/management game! I tried it on a Free Weekend opportunity and bought it immediately.

-Their custom radio is hilarious and I LOVE the flavour texts they give to staff when you are deciding on who to hire. 
-Maps are fun and I found right to the end I was always learning new things to make my hospital run more efficiently. Some people complain the maps are repetitive and once you save a room design you will be using it over and over again. However, each hospital map has a different building layout and I actually like my hospitals to look nice while completing the challenges. I will admit, there were one or two maps I was not fond of, but I got through it. Sometimes you need to just restart.
-You can play conservatively (the quicker you level up your hospital, the more frequently patients arrive so in the beginning I find it better to start off slow and make sure no rooms have long queues.) Or you can rampage through the game on fast setting! Once I slowed down I found the game much more enjoyable!

Additionally, when you finish all the basic missions, there is replay value in the R.E.M.I.X. versions of the levels where you have to beat continuous waves (completely different game in my opinion.) 

Overall, especially on sale, I recommend this game!

This is a fun game with loads of silly humor. I don't think it's worth the full price, though, because it doesn't seem to have much lasting value.

The campaign started out great, but then quickly became a tedious chore. Every new map starts with you establishing basics that you've done multiple times before - reception, GP office, et cetera. Then you wait to stabilize your income and get into the exciting mid-game upgrades and growth. Then you have a lot of income, and you're waiting for all your tasks to complete without a clear idea how else to expand. You can, of course, keep building the same rooms, but to what end? You make a mini-game of building cool shapes with your rooms and decorating them, but that can sustain my interest only that long.

I still enjoyed it. It's always a delight seeing new silly diseases and symptoms. Above is my main issue with the game, and it was strong enough to turn me away, but it was after hours of joy.

The level of micromanagement you have to do, is really low so that you can just spend time having fun.
Definitely recommend playing it.

At first it seems like your decisions matter and you are revealing a wonderful enjoyable game. However, the more you play, the more complex your hospital gets, the more you realize that... patients don't respond to placement of objects, design, and other decisions. So what you do... really doesn't matter. So there goes the game play... When you start check info and redesign you notice there is nothing underneath powering this game. There is really no point in understanding or optimizing design. Its just a clicker game. Not worth purchasing for more than a few dollars.

Two Point Hospital is a game created by a new company called, fittingly, Two Point which is made up of folks from former companies Bullfrog (Theme series, Dungeon Keeper), Muckyfoot (Startopia) and Lionhead (Black & White, Fable). They were able to come together and make something truly fantastic.

[b]Positives[/b]
+ Runs absolutely great on my PC. No issues whatsoever.
+ Full of charm. From the animations and puns to the radio, names of characters and miscellaneous items.
+ Gives you plenty to do so you're most of the time not hanging around waiting for something to crop up
+ Same magic that was present in the Theme games.

[b]Neutral[/b]
> Just a personal thing but I wish finances were a bit more hands on

[b]Negatives[/b]
- It takes a fair bit to load when I start it up but that's the only long load screen
- If you never were into tycoon games, this definitely won't change your mind

Two Point Hospital has crept up to being one of my favourite recent games and the folks at Two Point have done a fantastic job. I genuinely look forward to whatever their next major project is and don't secretly hope it's a theme park sim, I swear.

There is a mod that will take care of the employee issues.  There is a lot of attention to detail in the game.  Some of the animations in the treatment rooms are quite funny.  Water runs out of the waterfall painting.  Things like that.

I got this on sale, and it is definitely worth the price that I paid.  However, I don't think that I would pay $35 for it.  I'm a single mom, and money is tight.  So, part of that is my circumstances.  If the price isn't an issue for you, I would recommend it to anyone who likes tycoon games.

This is not a bad game. But, to me it never quite hits the heights of the original, and at the same time doesn't really introduce anything that's fun beyond what Theme Hospital offered. So, I'm negging it because overall the only things I enjoyed about it was the feeling of nostalgia for TH, but at the same time it didn't really do anything better at any point.

Here are some issues off the top of my head:
- Graphics are more 'the sims' than TH, probably by design but personally I dislike it
- Animations are limited, one per action .. same animation, every time .. (yes I know TH was the same)
- Announcer is sort of mildly funny? But just doesn't really capture the spirit of the original
- Likewise, the characters for bankers, doctors, and helper-man are just ... meh, I didn't even grin in earnest once.
- In a similar vein, why change shooting the rats if you're going to just make it the same but worse?
- I found the music bland and boring, and it cuts and chops between tracks.
- Game pauses for a split second each time it autosaves, which is jarring.
- The hospital spaces are way larger now so there's ostensibly more complexity. But the gameplay loop is identical throughout and it gets tiring fast.
- The things they add to try to introduce new mechanisms feel like chores: training in particular is arduous and unfun.
- There is little to no consequence to failure for any act in the game. At one stage replaying a mission to get the platinum star I thought I'd test just having no toilets, no janitors, and all 1 star staff throughout the mission. Despite frequent deaths and all manner of excrement and body fluids throughout the hospital I raked in cash like a madman, had pretty much max reputation and won public voted hospital of the year several years running.
- Loans follow this pattern. There's no real risk-reward.
- This also goes for staff challenges. Someone turns up with a challenge? You may as well accept it because why not? If you accidentally complete the challenge, great. If not, doesn't matter in the slightest. Why even give us a choice?
- If a staffer does turn up with a challenge you really want to do for some reason, you can for example pause the game, build a Lv4 Toilet as per their wishes, gain the benefit (happy staffer for six months!) and then immediately sell all the items you just added. Still happy staffer. Great..
- The time system seems weird. I know it's to measure the progress of years but even the quickest visit -> GP -> diagnose -> treatment ends up taking (in game terms) 30 or more days .... again, why bother at that point? Stop pretending.
- Building rooms is tedious due to the 'level' system they've implemented. The size of a room and the things in it influence how prestigious it's viewed by patients and staff and presumably affects their happiness as a result. So if you want to operate efficiently you end up having to chuck the same stuff in every one. Machine, plant, chair, heater, and then as many of the same Certificate along every damn wall of the place until it gets to the desired level. They didn't even bother to code a diminishing return feature for adding multiples of the same decoration.
- They recently added a way to clone rooms which is welcome but still irritating as quite often you'll be a column or a row off the available space.
- Sorting and deploying items is tedious even when using filters. There's at once too many items, and not enough with the vast majority being posters with the same effects but different pictures.
- Can't copy/paste items from hospital floor. It'd be real nice to be able to copy groups of benches / heaters / plants / etc ...
- Many illnesses are basically vanilla, eg they have a "funny" (arguably..?) name and/or description but in practice the patient looks identical to everyone else, and is treated the same way with no real graphical or audio cues or anything. It's all a bit boring for most types of cases particularly those related to Pharmacy and Ward.
- Poor implementation of stats throughout, eg having a target 'cure success rate' that operates on a straight % of total patients in a wave rather than adapting in real time to how many you've cured, and how many remain

Finally .. before anyone says rose coloured glasses, I replayed Theme Hospital within the last year. It's limited in scope but far more charming. I liked it more despite its limitations. So for that reason I'd recommend you check it out instead.

A solid sim with a delightful sense of humor. Unlike most sim games, Two Point is divided into separate levels where each one has its own gimmick. Getting three stars on each level is satisfying, and it makes the experience varied enough that you don't get tired of it like you would playing the same thing over and over. Also, in over 50 hours of playing this game, I have yet to hear the radio hosts repeat dialogue; they are probably the best part of this game. 

Fun pro tip: there are two secret songs by Jasmine Odyssey that are off by default that you can turn on by going to the audio playlist settings in the menu.

This game is my favorite base building / management sim in a long time. If you loved Evil Genius then this game is for you. Allow me to explain why I tend to get frustrated in building and management sims:
Usually you load into a huge map and you have hundreds of options for items to place, rooms to build, and production chains to get humming. It tends to leave me crippled with indecision. How big should that room be? Is it so big that I'm wasting my precious space? What items have to be in that room and do I need to add them now or can I wait and add them later when I have money? Usually this leads me to look up a guide to see what the established meta is, and then I end up playing each mission the same way doing each step somebody else already taught me and it's an exercise in repetition. 

This game does not do that. This game has so many quality of life features that it makes the game super easy to get into yet challenging enough to keep you playing. When you start building a room, the game shows you the minimum size a room needs to be to hold the minimum equipment. If you want to go bigger, you can. But it's nice to have the minimum requirements right in front of you. Another feature that tends to become a problem in these games is the AI. Workers will start having task assignment issues and AI will have pathing issues to the different destinations in games. This game has an EXCELLENT AI. I have built hospitals where I tried to lay out the rooms according to the usual flow (G.P. -> Diagnosis - > G.P. - > Treatment room) and I've built hospitals where I build stuff anywhere I have room. Both ways work. The tools the game gives you for staff assignment to certain rooms is good for efficiency, but if you are worried about not being able to grasp the core systems the game is possible to win without them. It's really stupendous how good the game is at allowing you to feel in control. The challenges come from trying to make your hospital better, not functional. You have to work to improve your staff through training, so they're happier and your patients are happier. You upgrade your equipment (which has the rare feature where the equipment actually visually looks different after you improve it) in order to get higher diagnosis % and treatment %, which is the goal of a game like this. You actually get to manage instead of trying to debug the AI the whole time. 
I can't recommend enough. Give it a try!

I was a big fan of the original Theme Hospital back in the 90s. This game brings that same fun back, while adding new features (or making them easier). Training and research is better. The ability to switch hospitals without losing progress is good (not really beneficial until you unlock mitton university and access research). Just discovered how to use room templates, awesome. I wish I could set thresholds on happiness and energy. My spare employees, that I want to be resting in case I need then, burn all their energy walking around not working. And some employees overwork (won't even go to the bathroom, then get angry and quit). Entertaining peaceful strategy game in which you create a "Hospital empire".

One thing I want to mention up front is that the game features a mild "gatekeeping" system: The main 'story' mode will not let you go to the next hospital until you reach at least 1 star at the current hospital, and some later hospitals are locked behind 2 different hospitals. Fortunately, you only need 1 (out of 3 possible) stars in each of those pre-requisite hospitals, which is sensible.

You can also always return to your previous (or "other") hospitals and basically take advantage of their good economic shape to offload whatever it is you are struggling with at your current hospital - mainly research. So, if your current hospital gives you a tough goal such as 'Research technology X', and you can't spare the doctors on research to stay afloat, you can switch to one of your well-functioning, 3-star hospitals, and do the research there. This is apparently an expected strategy and helps tremendously in some of the tougher scenarios, where you are not in full control of your hospital's economy.

The graphics are mostly clear and the building and control interface is very practical, including the ability to simply copy-paste or copy-paste-and-then-adjust for the different rooms, or the option to set a specific room as a template that can be used in other hospitals (this is basically copy-paste across hospitals, but with multiple templates possible).

The game has an abundance of humor and in 30 hours, the more complicated jokes have repeated only few times.

The diseases you are curing are 'fantasy diseases' and the treatments are hilariously animated; my younger son loves watching me cure people who think they are dogs by putting them into dog houses and then bouncing those houses on big load springs.

Wholeheartedly recommended.

Do I recommend it, yes. Because I loved Theme Hospital when it came out and finished it several times back in the 90s. And I am happy at the thought of new players experiencing the same joy I felt when I played it for the first time more than 20 years ago. 

But is it actually a sequel to Theme Hospital, no. It is the same game. Very minor, almost non-existent changes. It is literally the same game. Is that a bad thing, no. If it ain't broke, don fix it, I guess.

At first I found some of the gameplay too stressful. I bought this for a relaxing "diner dash" game that I could just turn off my brain and do tasks with. 

But after about an hour I got exactly the experience I was hoping for. I now have several hospitals and I feel like I choose them just based on mood. If I go to my first hospital it's, like, I just want to chill and decorate. If I go to the teaching hospital I want to actually try to accomplish something in this game. And there's stuff in between.

The different hospitals with different goals and flavors is really, really fun and lets me get whatever experience I'm looking for that day.

The review of this game has taken me 80 hours of game play time, mostly because in management style games I want to see how much depth the simulation has, which was especailly the case with this game, with the nonsensical humor.

After these 80 hours, I conclude that there is enough variety and depth to the game play to continue another dozens of hours into the game. The fact that a designed room can now be saved as a template really did help with this positive review: it started to feel a bit useless to reconstruct every room time and time again: that's not what makes the game fun.

The delicate balance between curing, diagnosing, and designing an efficient lay-out makes every level a challenge (at least to get all 3 stars) and the levels are diverse enough to do something different every time. The learning curve is very nice to work with, and everything also just works :-) 

Have fun playing!

Two Point certainly is one of my favorites. I enjoy management games, tackling a challenge head on is so fun. 
One problem i ran into and you will as well - Too many patients, not enough GP Offices. I tried to combat the problem by training and adding more offices, didn't make a difference when you only have so much space to build. Also the vaccination missions are annoying when you have huge hospital. You can't be expected to vaccinate when there are over 100 people in the building, too many to animations to spot one specific symptom. 
Other than that, a spectacular medical management game. The announcer is so funny and the radio hosts made me crack up. The menagerie of treatments and their buildings are wacky and entertaining to watch in action. 
The best thing you can do early is to train GP Doctors, they'll give higher diagnosis. Which'll result in less deaths, and more money.
Purchase Two Point if you want a silly management game with plenty to explore.

It's good, though not great. I was a great fan of Theme Hospital, and was really excited for this release. After you've gotten around the mechanics, it's essentially rinsing and repeating a similar strategy over and over again.

1. Don't rush to expand, or build every treatment room when a patient needs it
2. Only build (or loan money to do so) when you are sure to get a return on investment
3. Upgrade machines and invest in training as priorities
4. Don't be afraid to send patients home

Essentially, it's cash flow management. Once your finances are stable, you can go about meeting those ever pesky exist-just-to-annoy-you objectives. Not the most balanced of games:

1. Managing for reputation doesn't do much i.e. there isn't that big of penalty and therefore incentive to manage it. Once you've got our finances sorted out it'll manage itself
2. It's so much easier to simply pay the penalty and resolve the pandemic immediately. There's little incentive to really think about 'hygiene' or straining your eyes looking for the infected
3. You can make life easier for yourself by foregoing most of the diagnostic rooms. They're money sinks and takes a lot of effort to shuttle staff around. Ward + Psychiatry + General Diagnosis + DNA is really all the diagnosis you need. With these alone, you no longer encounter the scenario where a patient has exhausted all diagnosis options.
4. Managing patients comfort and happiness? Not super essential. The priority is to run things efficiently anyways. And by doing so you mostly get patients through the hospital before they get excessively pissed off. Sudden influx of surgeries however, are a bit tougher. They take very long to perform and require two staff so there's more in-built inefficiencies.

If you're new to the genre, give it a try when it's on sale. For veterans, bit of nostalgia is there. You'll have no problems with beating the stages (though some are really annoying and time consuming). Except for one (I got caught off guard with a new game mechanic), I've cleared all the stages on the first try. That's just how much lather rinse repeat it is.
This game feels like the theme hospital spirital successor that it is. Brings me back to the good old days of gaming tycoon style games. A must have for any fan of the genre

Staff and patients have needs which must be maintained, and continued objectives keep pushing the game state forward.  A light and whimsical distraction worth playing.

Just finished the vanilla game. This one gets a huge thumbs up from me. 15 levels is a steal these days for the amount they charge. It's a remake of Theme Hospital, for those who are familiar with that game, and they really did well by the original. They got the original PA announcer to do the sounds for this, they included a lot of the elements of the original that made it so addicting, and added a lot of gameplay beyond that. Tons of rooms, decorations, new shops, multiplayer objectives (which are all optional but can nab you some nice extras), and maybe most importantly, mod support. There's a ton of replayability because of all of those things. Even though I said this is a steal for the price (and it is), this goes on sale frequently enough that you can save a good amount if you wait. Worth getting, either way.

I do recommend the game . 
In small doses  it is a fun and funny management game  .  
To get the first star is pretty easy , to get 3 stars  is  difficult  . It takes a long time , and  make adjustments on the fly. adjustments of  prices work force , staff training while try to keep your income positive . 

The game has sudden difficulty spikes that makes you wonder how did you get from 6 figure income to minus 6 figure income. In spite of that it is a  good challenge to turn from failing hospital to successful one .

As i mentioned it is good in small doses ,  it gets repetitive after a while if you play more than couple of hours in a row. 
I passed most of the game before introduction of templates , so i had to rebuild every room over and over again , this was really annoying. Templates fixed  that issue.

The objectives are a bit repetitive in the main game , but it  was  fixed in the DLC the  gave  different and interesting objectives and gameplay

Overall i do recommend this game.

I'm sure there is a lot of love for this game coming from Theme Hospital but I would suggest to anybody thinking of purchasing this to relive an old classic... don't. I admit, I'm only 10 hours in but I've already come to the realisation there is no point playing any further as there is absolutely no challenge to the game, it's more akin to a simple mobile game. There are no challenges/deadlines or tasks which you need to watch out for in case you fail a level, you simply plod along indefinitely until you eventually complete a few tasks and win the level, regardless of how good you are/ how well you built your hospital. When I realised there was absolutely no challenge to the game and no potential to lose a level, there was no point playing.

I was a huge fan of Theme Hospital in the 90's when i was about 11 years old. I waited some kind of sequal for 15 years and when Two Point finally arrived, i was so excited! 

The game is fun, funny and so much more detailed than it's predecessor. There´s a lot of different diagnostic and treatment rooms, and i like the fact that nurses can also work many other rooms too besides pharmacy and ward. There are many different training possibilities to all staff members from doctors to assistants. I also love the room decoration options, which were very minimum in Theme Hospital. 

The game is definitely more challenging than it's predecessor, but still quite easy to manage. You have to pass different challenges and objectives to get stars for your hotel, and after getting 1 star hotel you can move on your map to next episode. There are few hospitals that are very difficult to get to even  1 star. The one i struggled the most with was the public hospital, where you get no income from treatments - only donations from public healthcare organization, when you get different objectives done.

The music in this game is awesome and has such a positive and funny vibe to it. There is also a radio commentator, but i found that a bit annoying, so it can be turned off if you like and just listen to radio music list. Of course you can turn that off too, but i couldn't imagine playing this game without these musics.

The one negative thing about this game is the timeline where you have cure certain amount of patients coming as a group for treatment. It's usually 90 days, and the clock starts ticking when you accept a challenge to treat these people. However, depending on where you have that certain treatment room, it can take up to 30 days before the patients arrive from helicopter spot to treatment room's door. There's usually 6-12 people group to treat, and if 30 days from total 90 is spent as they walk from helicopter to appointment room, there's no way you have the time to treat them all. If you don't succeed in the challenge, you get minus points to your reputation.

Overall i think Two Point Hospital is an excellent building game with different tasks and challenges to do. It has versatile contents, but after you get all the possible diagnostic and treatment rooms to built, it might feel repetitive. But If you enjoyed playing Theme Hospital 20 years ago, i think you will like this game as well!

My [b]only[/b] issue with this is the time dilation affect on your life. You think you've been playing half an hour or so, then you realise you haven't been to work for a month. How does that even happen?

Giving Two Point Hospital a thumbs down is a tough choice. The game has merit and is endearingly charming.

CONS
One of its major issues is the simplistic and incomprehensible manner of its simulation. I can't imagine TPH appealing to serious sim fans because not only is the simulation shallow it also doesn't make itself clear. 70+ hours in and I still don't know exactly how the diagnosis process works. Success and failure of treatments seems to be left up to RNG based on the skill of the physician and how well diagnosis went, making it somewhat of a crap shoot. Features like room prestige and hospital attractiveness, reputation and level don't appear to be any more nuanced than how they're vaguely defined.

While in the process of developing the hospital things will be going smoothly until suddenly there are double digit room ques for no apparent reason. Or you suddenly have a spike in death rates. (s'far as I can tell, that seems to happen if you suddenly hire a bunch of unskilled doctors and nurses). Or you were making six digit profits and now all of a sudden you have a five figure deficit. Then as suddenly as it happened, despite having seemingly done nothing at all, it's fine again. Even though the assistant complains about how prices affect reputation and there's even a meter to display how much patients approve of your prices, I never noticed any discernable effect on overall reputation. Sometimes patients will just outright refuse to pay higher prices, but afaict that's entirely random.

TPH has no tools that explain why these things happen. What rudimentary graphs and charts that track stats do exist are practically useless and I only remember referring to them once. This gives the feeling of an off the rails simulation you've got little control over. Besides, these simple graphs only tell you what is happening, not why it's happening.

You'll be laying out the same rooms with the same templates, hiring the same randomly generated staff, training them, upgrading machines, researching technology over and over and over and over again. Fortunately the simulation requires no micromanaging. Staff always seem to know how to delegate tasks to stay optimal, so as long as you hire enough of them they'll cover all the bases themselves. There are controls to delegate staff and room behavior, but I never felt like I had to resort to using them. 

But this means that every mission is the same. Every game plays out the same way with no variation. TPH doesn't even offer up much in the way of visual customization for rooms, deco, or the appearance of staff, so every hospital is pretty much going to look exactly alike. You'll place the same rooms, with the same walls, and the same floors, and the same components, and the same decor over and over and over again.

Fortunately a recent update finally added room templates so at least you don't have to construct every room from the ground up anymore. Some fussing with door and item placement will still be required to make things fit sometimes.

Another odd design choice. While you can place any size or room shape, you can only do so within the boundaries of each hospital building's pre-existing shape. And sometimes these templates just make getting every room to fit efficiently within them a deliberate fuss. The strange logic behind this method sees someone who isn't the player laying out the building's outer walls and then letting you fit rooms inside of them. Wonky. But you'll never make many rooms of varying size and shape anyway since each room only allows for so many mandatory components so you'll never need to construct a room any bigger than its minimum size. It would be nice to be able to have one huge pan lab with multiple machines, for instance, but the game only permits one per room. Heck, even being able to add multiple doors to rooms would be nice.

For how shallow a sim TPH is, the game's user interface is needlessly fussy. Sliders for adjusting staff salaries are a pita for getting their pay rate exactly where you'd like it to be. The only factor that seems to matter are the pay thresholds at which your staff's disposition to their pay improves, which affects their happiness. But there is no visual indication on the slider as to where that threshold is. You just gotta fiddle with it until the smiley face changes. Even then, if you want the salary set to just above what makes them happier, you gotta fuss around even more. Sure, there's a button to toggle any "unresolved" pay raises. But all that does is set all under paid staff to the middle of the road salary. Oh, and you can increase all staff salaries by 1%, but that results in overpaying everyone! Why can't there just be a button to set each individual salary to just past the next happiness threshold?

There are three menus you'll be cycling through the most. To open one you have to collapse the others, you can't just have them all expanded at once. But the icon to expand the menu then shifts a ways to the right. So to close it, you have to chase it! In fact, at no point can any window be open simultaneously with any other. There is no resizing or repositioning of menus. Little issues like this may seem trivial, but they quickly become a constant repeat annoyance.

PROS
Since the gameplay is awfully thin, most of the game's entertainment factor comes from the visuals. I absolutely adore TPH's Wallace and Gromit style graphics. The visual gags are fun but you see em once and they're already old. I got the most amusement out of the three disk jockies who cycle through doing voice overs through the game's soundtrack. They are genuinely funny and they always have something new to say so a lot of writing was done for them. They're about the only continuously fresh content this game provides because everything else is repeated incessantly. I also got the occasional chuckle out of some of the random staff descriptions too.

Speaking of the soundtrack, I haven't heard a video game soundtrack this catchy in a long time. It seriously took me back to the days of simple infectious jingles like I remember from - say, Ocarina of Time. And I found myself humming along to the familiar tunes again and again. There are only a scant few, but most of them are pretty enjoyable and at least for me I never got tired of hearing em.

Performance wise I had few hiccups. TPH isn't exactly pushing the limits of modern computing power so it'll basically run. I experienced a few oddities. After one long play session my hardware cursor started drifting. I had one nurse resign because she just froze up after exiting a room and I couldn't even pick her up. And the game can start to chug under large busy hospitals. 

CONCLUSION
All in all, TPH is a very casual experience that'll be fun to mess with for a bit but will undoubtedly get boring pretty quick. The total lack of longevity is TPH's biggest flaw. There should be more and varied content to keep the game fresh and really allow players to play around and experiment. But as it stands, every play session is awfully shallow, repetitive, and by-the-books formulaic.

30 August, 2018 - Did not recommend.

Loved Theme Hospital and was excited to play this game. However, this game has clearly not been tested on a range of compatible (but differently spec-ed) Macs. My Mac has an i7 4GHz processor and a Nvidia GTX 1080 graphics card, so can easily run games with much better graphics.

Unfortunately, the game freezes up on launch and sends the graphics card haywire freezing the system. It takes a while for even the control-alt-delete equivalent for Mac to launch to force quit the loading screen.

If you have a Mac, even if you meet the spec's, it may not work so be wary. I will try again after Two Point is next updated, or I will have to get a refund.

Its a wacky game. Its very much like Theme Hospital if you have ever played that game before. I would give it a try, and if you are not sure then see if you know someone that has it to try out. Its a nice easy game to sit and relax while you listen to music or a podcast or something.

Great game very relaxing and fun to play. I would recommend it for anyone who likes point and click games!
If you liked Theme Hospital, this is a carbon copy of it

I LOVED Theme Hospital back in the day, and this game takes all the fun parts of that game and updates them (and lets me run it on my computer in full resolution). Same fun diseases (and lots of new ones), sound effects, etc. Lots of things have been improved, like the ability to train any types of staff (and you can specify training topic), making rooms different shapes (not only square), and there are many different kinds of objects for decorating (instead of just plants). If you loved Theme Hospital you will adore this game.

While it has a very goofy aesthetic, this game takes some strategy and thinking on your feet to keep your hospital running smoothly.  The sense of humor in this game makes you want to keep overcoming challenges.  It isn't as hardcore as some management games, where you have to fiddle with every little setting to complete your goals, but it has enough bits and pieces that you discover as you play to make it engaging. Easy to pick up and put down and I like all the different gameplay options they have been rolling out over the last two years. 

If you like sim management games that don't require you to get into the weeds too much, this is a good one.
really funny and relaxing to play i reccormend
If you loved Theme Hospital then you will love Two Point Hospital. Personally I don't think it is as good as the original but how many times can you play the same game over and over again :-P.

Introduces new elements perhaps a little too slow in the story mode, but there are a lot of rooms to build and a lot of items to customize your hospital. Parts of the system feel like they aren't focusing on the right aspect (why do I have to have sooo many items crammed into a room to give it prestige? Why can't the system allow for more patients per room, because my hospital has too many pharmacies and I need more room for prestige items!) but I never feel like I'm without something to do.

The bigger problem is that it very quickly becomes apparent that there isn't actually all that much to do. About half of the rooms function in pretty much the same way. Build it, put 'weird science machine 3000' into it, then assign someone to it. Surprise, the next room works the same way. About halfway to three quarters into unlocking all the hospitals (not entirely sure) I just got bored. Lots of play hours, sure, but once I figured out that I would never truly be 'on top of things' and every expansion is just animations and cosmetics and 'new' ailments that function the same way allllll the rest of them do....it's almost insulting.

I thoroughly enjoy playing Two Point Hospital. As a kid, I played a lot of Theme Hospital and other tycoon games, and I find that TPH incorporates the best parts of all of the older games! The different types of hospitals with different requirements and levels of difficulty make the game suitable for all ages and gaming abilities - plus with the DLC there are added challenges for those who need a little boost extra. The options to play online challenges with friends who also have the game is fun for those who need some more social interaction in the game. The radio overlay is very fun and adds a layer of amusement to an already entertaining game - especially Sir Nigel Bickleworth and the Hospital Tannoy System. The mechanics of playing the game are simple and easy to use - so there is no need for specialist equipment for your laptop - however, the game can run very slowly on certain operating systems when there is less than the optimal RAM available. Otherwise, one of my favourite games!

It's a good game, but lacking features I've wanted since launch. This game needs a free build mode where players are free to place the main walls and doors of our hospitals as well as the rooms. Think like Planet Coaster's challenge mode. You're given a giant open plot of land and are free to do as you wish. You still have to keep currency in mind and all the game features/mechanics. This is what the game needs. To allow us to free-build and expand our own hospitals as it grows. Let us run free with our imaginations. The whole plot doesn't even need to be available. We can buy more chunks of the plot as we grow.

Sure, we have a sandbox mode, but it's just not the same.

EDIT: I am editing this review to explain how this game and developers have decayed in my opinion. The developers do not hear the fan base anymore as they did in the beginning. A lot of cool features to implement, but no! Let's just put new cosmetics into the game. The game is repetitive a lot. You will do almost the same thing in every scenario, even after some DLCs. I don't recommend this game anymore. Unless you are a blind fan as I was in the past.

Edit 2: After a while, the development team heard the fans again. It took time, looks like TWP is not a major project (decisions...), and some features implementation might be slower than many of us would like. In summary, I am satisfied. It is a great game, and I recommend it.

Pros:
+Regular new features implementation, and free stuff
+Nostalgia to Theme Hospital players
+Fun game

Neutral:
*Communication with the fan base is regular

Cons:
-Some DLCs just include cosmetics

The big problem is that it gets rather grindy and you basically must redo the same exact thing over and over when you start each new level. Build reception desk, build GP office, build general diagnosis, build pharmacy, build break room, build training room, build bathrooms, build food and drinks, build entertainment, build ward and so on. 
There are unique challenges to each level, and it is fun when you discover new diseases to treat. Some levels can be frustrating (The constantly spawning ghosts got a bit old) but having to do the initial grind work every time gets rather old. You basically get to the point where you have to put in about an hour work or so just to even get to the real meat of the level.

The other negative is there is a massive amount of items to add to make you hospital look nice, but in reality there are only a tiny handful of them you will use if you want to max out your hospital. Putting gold certificates on every possible space in every room should not be the only way to do this.

Overall thumbs up, but I wish they would do something about the repetitive grindy game play at the start of a new level.

Two Point Hospital is definitely entertaining and the various diseases and methods of treatment are hilarious. These alone warrant a positive review. While the maps are fairly repetitive, they each offer unique challenges to push you into designing your hospital a little bit different each time. You can also purchase a large variety of items to decorate / improve your hospital, allowing for a pretty good degree of customization.

There are some problems with how the game is played, however. The biggest issue is that in order to get a room to level 5, the game essentially forces you to make the least aesthetically pleasing design of all. The way I do it (and have seen others do it) is cover the walls in gold star posters. The way rooms must be designed sort of forces the player to do this and does not give any incentive to try anything creative in the rooms. This is unfortunate considering the multitude of items available to design your hospital. In the end, the only ones I ever used were gold star posters, fire extinguishers, and occasionally water fountains. I don't foresee this ever being addressed as it seems like they would need to overhaul the entire room prestige structure. If it were me, I would have given increased prestige value based on each unique item. Just a thought.

[h1] Your merry first tycoon [/h1]
One could argue that a tycoon game about creating a chain of private healthcare facilities is in a bit of a bad taste. A notion Two Points Studio tackled with a peculiar sense of humour, leaving the somber reality of healthcare behind, to instead pursue cartoonish visuals and cheesy jokes. The caricature is not only the game’s most defining trait, it also contributes to a truly soothing and heart-warming title. Welcome to Two Point Hospital – a place where having kitchen utensils stuck on your head is called a pan-demic and cured with a giant magnet. 

[b] Starting small [/b]
Two Point Hospital is a game that gradually grows on you both in terms of gameplay and atmosphere. The campaign starts slow with the first few hospitals dedicated foremost to learning basic gameplay mechanics, which you will then need to use all at once further down the line. While playing these “tutorial” levels I was surprised by how flexible everything in Two Points is. At any point of the game you are free to move, replace or rotate any items and even the entire rooms. Granted you have sufficient space to do so, it is possible to move the entire wing of the hospital to another. Would you like to build a nice-looking hospital but you are afraid it won’t meet the practical objectives of the level? No problem, you are free to remodel the entire facility, once it has earned enough.

You might want to get a wider set of items first. Beside mundane money, Two Points also has Kudosh – a currency that allows the player to unlock aesthetic and practical additions to the hospital. Kudosh is scarce early on, so it is advised to prioritise hand sanitizer and treatment books over the dragon statue. The primary source of Kudosh are the hospital stars and career goals (e. g. promote 100 doctors) and later your hospital can generate them too. At first the mechanic serves as means of visible campaign progress, though the longer you play, the more Kudosh unlocks fade into the background. The currency is also related to the limited “multiplayer” capability of Two Points Hospital. You are allowed to challenge your friends for hospital performance (e. g. most money made in 180 days) or contribute to community-spanning research project where all Two Points players are required to perform specific actions, to unlock new items for all the participants. A really nice community-building touch, if nothing else.

[b] Reach for the stars [/b]
To give you a more immediate idea of progress, every hospital is rated with stars, a maximum of 3. To earn these each facility has tailored objectives. On the early stages they are mostly related to specific sicknesses or mechanics introduced at the given level. Once the 3 stars-rating prerequisite is met the level is considered maxed-out, though mostly there is plenty of room left for the player to linger. The opposite is also possible, if you find a level particularly tedious progress can be made after reaching only 1 star. Beside level objective, each part of the county has its own gimmick – some parts are cold, others are hot and yet another is plagued by a steady stream of natural disasters. Does it suffice to provide genuine diversity? In the opinion of yours truly, it’s a nice touch but an insufficient one and you would have to pick up one of the DLCs for something properly inventive. On the up side, there are quite a lot of illnesses in Two Points and not until about 70% of the campaign will it run out of new tricks.
[url] https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2168318058 [/url]
In order to match the relaxing quality of the game, tutorial levels really do go easy on the player and frankly the early lack of difficulty goes to the point of being deceiving. I picked up a few bad building habits there, realising only much later that perhaps I did get my completion stars but those hospitals were quite bad. Alas, roughly at the half-point of the campaign is where the greatest challenge of Two Points appears – the transition from making a cosy hospital, to one that doesn’t go bankrupt. The game does get more challenging in time and especially some of the 3-stars ratings can be tricky to get, and require double the amount of time it took to get the first 2 stars. That said, once you get a proper grasp of the game’s economy and rather simplistic (yet very necessary) micro-management you are free to build as you please.


[b] Cheesy gobbins [/b]
The joking tone of the game simply cannot be overstated. Two Points Hospital’s brand of humour definitely isn’t for everyone. To be honest, it wasn’t my pair of shoes either. Still there is some undeniable endearing quality to it and as the time passed, it simply grew onto me. Cheesy jokes encompass every part of the game, the illnesses, wacky treatment machines, ghosts vacuumed by janitors, down to minute details such as names of the songs. There is a brilliant consequence to it all, though the definite highlight of the game is the Two Points Radio.

Being a tycoon game, Two Point Hospital takes a while to beat the campaign especially that there is hardly anything about this game that would prompt you to hurry, quite the opposite. During these long hours Two Point Radio becomes a perfect companion, not only serving suitably cheery tunes but also delivering 3 lovable radio jockeys. Be it ostensibly posh Sir Nigel Bickleworth, upbeat Ricky Hawthorn or paranoid Harrison Wolff, each character breaks the monotony with their seemingly endless radio entries. It would appear as if every map had its own set of auditions and they don’t ever seem to repeat. Two Points Radio comes complete with jingles and advertisements equally absurd as the rest of the game. While the music is somewhat limited, it is believable local radio station and possibly my favourite part of the game.

[b] Two the point [/b]
Being a newcomer to the tycoon genre I enjoyed Two Point Hospital as a refreshing change of pace. If you have a taste for slow-burn forms of passing time, this is a great way to ease the mind after a busy day at work. That said, I believe that veterans of the genre will find Two Point to be too easy and simplistic. The AI of both workers and employees is quite dull and most of the micro-management in the game goes towards preventing people from roaming too much. There is a rather odd survival-style mode where the patients try to overwhelm your hospital in waves but this is as far as challenges go. On a similar note, those among you used to playing high-paced action titles, should only approach this game if you look for a vastly different experience. All in all, Two Points Hospital was a highly pleasant time. Rather than being a satisfying car chase scene, the game is an equivalent of a warm blanket and cup of coffee on a rainy day. Do give it a try.

I'm writing this review because I honestly believe more people need to have this game.  *I can't speak to the dlc as I do not own them; but for the base game this gets a big thumbs up.

If i woke up tomorrow and this game was gone from my library and i had to pay full price to get it back; i'd do it in a heartbeat.  That's how good this game is for a semi-casual builder.

There are a ton of scenarios.  Some you can kick back, put up your feet, and coast through them.  Others you need to pay attention or your hospital is going into the red and on a path to failure.  You can replay scenarios even after you beat them if you think you can do better.

But if your looking for a non-serious builder to relax and have a drink while playing this is the one.  It's a perfect blend of macro vs micro management.  If you want to really control your staff you can; but you can also just set them up for success and let the game play.  I've never enjoy a builder-type game so much since the original roller coaster tycoon.

If you're on the fence; let me tip you one way.  Buy this game!!
