Two Point Hospital is a great successor to Theme Hospital! The graphics, the animations and the soundtrack create a very enjoyable playing experience while you are trying to cure patients from all sorts of witty ailments. The only drawback is that the game allows you to spam the same object over and over in order to raise a room's prestige, thus leaving very little room for creativity when designing your hospital.

A guy named humor walks by and you can't help but notice that his cheeks has engulfed his entire face.  Yes, this game has quite a lot of cheeky humor in it....

Ok, jokes aside, that's what this game is all about, repairing these kinds of "defects" and getting paid for it.  

This hospital sim is fairly easy to learn and play and although there are a few challenging scenarios to play during the campaign - for the most part, this game is fun and addicting.

The only negative thing I can say about this game is that the campaign takes too long to become slightly more challenging and the first few hospitals are simply too easy to feel rewarding.

Man, I really tried to like this one. The humor is camp in a good way, the complexity is there, graphics are smooth. Overall, a great feel. Unfortunately, the glaring problems forced me to quit.

In this game rooms have a value determined by how much crap is stuffed in them. Plants, beds, every tool has a value that is a mechanic to force you to make bigger rooms and plan your patient movement. Unfortunately, every time you start a new hospital you'll be making these from scratch, over and over. There is a lot of repetition. A lot of repetition. A lot of repetition. A lot of repetition.

The financial mechanics I was hoping to really enjoy are vague and one dimensional. Your hospital will overflow with new patients if you don't turn the price all the way up, which is fine because patient dissatisfaction about price has no effect on gameplay other than slowing the flood of new patients down.

This game needs a lot of copy/paste added into it and higher layers of financial assessment to be fun for an adult.

Two Point Hospital is a 2018 business simulation game developed by Two Point Studios. A spiritual successor to Bullfrog Productions' 1997 game Theme Hospital, players are tasked with constructing and operating an empire of hospitals in the fictional Two Point County, with the goal of curing patients of fictitious, comical ailments. Because visiting real hospitals is unpopular, the emphasis on humour to lighten the mood was deemed important by the developers. The game was designed and developed by some of the creators of Theme Hospital, including Mark Webley and Gary Carr.

Within weeks of release, Two Point Hospital was the second most downloaded game in the sales charts for Europe, Middle East, Africa, and Australia. The game was received positively by critics, garnering acclaim for its style, humour and its faithfulness to Theme Hospital's aesthetics, but criticised for its repetitiveness and room design. The game received four major updates as downloadable content after its release, adding new regions and illnesses to cure.

Two Point Hospital features a similar style of gameplay to that of Theme Hospital. Players take on the role of a hospital manager charged with constructing and maintaining a hospital. Tasks include building rooms and amenities that satisfy the needs (such as hunger and thirst) of patients and staff (such as toilets, staff rooms, reception desks, cafés, seating, and vending machines), expanding the hospital into new plots, the hiring and management of doctors, nurses, janitors, and assistants to maintain the hospital; and dealing with a variety of comical illnesses. The player can manage several hospitals, each with their own layout objectives.

it's a lot of fun, addictive to the point where it's borderline evil, but i have no idea how to stop the hospital from inevitably being overwhelmed with patients. it seems like it's all going just fine when you have 1-2 plots and you make good profit at this point, but once you buy all the plots and have used up all the space by putting all your rooms etc, it's just impossible to stay on top of all the patients coming in. every time i've built a full hospital it's not long until it gets overrun and then i start losing huge money and inevitably bankrupt the hospital. i've gone from +3m budget to bankrupt in like 2 years after fully expanding, and i don't understand why. even if you build like 30 gp offices to try and get all the patients through quickly, it's still not enough - it seems like you can never build enough gp offices at this point to stay on top of the number of patients coming in. and even if you do build 30 gp offices to try and keep up with the patient influx, that leaves you very little space for the actual healing rooms, so the patients just get backed up post diagnosis, and die, too. you can still progress through the game easily enough and finish it, but if you want to get 2 or 3 stars rather than just 1 star in some of the later levels, it really just seems impossible to do it. maybe i'm missing a key trick but i've tried to build some really well designed hospitals with every trackable component of success considered, but it always ends the same, with way too many patients and just not enough space for them all, then bankruptcy. still a great game to play on the side but if you want to take it seriously and 100% it or get all the max scores/stars...good luck...

I've played the crap out of Theme Hospital when I was a kid. Two Point Hospital surely is (to me) an oath to that game. Same witty diseases and overal sim feel.

As I have a short attention span, this game feels ideal to me; you can pick it up and play for an hour or less and then continue a few days later with another session, gradually completing the levels. It doesnt take a long time to remember how things worked, so you're back into it in a jiffy.

Its just so dang cute. :3 The illnesses are fake and most often " punny". The announcer in the hospital is always cheeky and fun and even sometimes helpful. Many hours of amusement came from this game and I would say its appropriate for all ages. I had a blast working my way through the different hospitals and illnesses and lives out my wildest dreams in sandbox mode. 

What I would ask they improve on?

Update the hospital announced with more dynamic stuff. More decor ( yes I know there is expansions) 

Other then that I cant think of one thing I would change. Its a wonderful, cheeky, well running game with no glitches or hiccups that I saw. It just an absolute polished jem that has been overshadowed by more popular titles. 

Do yourself a favor and but the game and enjoy it in all its silly, slap-happy fun :D

When I first herd about this game and how most of the original bullfrog staff not only created this game but also formed there own studios after so long to undo what EA has done to them how they bought the bullfrog studios and closed it a few years latter.  Theme Hospital was by far one of my fav games back in the late 90s, first playing it on the PlayStation then on the PC (much easier with the mouse).  This game is the true spiritual of Theme Hospital, Two Point Hospital has everything I was hoping for and more, and its also the lay out is so familiar that its was almost scary that there were times I forgot I was playing a game that was not 23 years old.  They went by the "if its not broken, don't fix it" approach, moving the camera to any angle is something I forgot that you could do as I was so use to the default view and that "awesome" moment where I was like "yes this is even better."  Reasons to get this game if you ever played Theme Hospital you will feel right at home, and if you never played this game get it as the OG Theme Hospital does not really play nice on modern PC's, plus the voice actors are the same.  In closing this game is just as goofy, funny, nutty as the one before it, but they ramped everything for this one, but they do it at a pace where your not over run, but watch out for that domino effect once one things goes wrong hope you have insurance because that is when sh*t hits the fan, and you'll be mad but you'll be laughing the whole way, in other words Buy This Game!

Vast improvement on the original Theme Hospital - the different levels and different diseases on different levels are a really nice touch. Fantastic game! Great nostalgia reminding me of the original "Theme Hospital" that I lost countless hours of my childhood to.
The diseases are genuinely funny to see/read about and the ongoing commentary throughout the game is hilarious making it a delight to play.
The actual gameplay is fantastic too - enough strategy/management to engage the player but not so much to deter from the underlying humour the game sets out to deliver.
If you're in to city building or management style games then I'd highly suggest playing this game. Likewise, if you're in to light hearted humour (no pun intended) with an easy going game then this will also be right up your street.
For anyone that played the original theme hospital this is an essential addition to your collection!

The perfect update to the brilliant Theme Hospital.
It's fun and gives hours of play. The amount of customisation is good and although there are some minor things including how to get a room to Level 5, or that the buildings provided can be awkward shapes that others have raised, that's all part of the challenge.
If you were allowed to create the buildings in exactly the size you want, it would be less of a challenge.
Another comment was that training takes staff out of other work completely - surely that is another part of the challenge of the game. If you have run your hospital so you can afford to replace them then great, if not, then you have to find other ways of managing.

All in all this is a brilliant game and I'm glad we finally have a really good update to Theme Hospital while still keeping the original, fun spirit of the original.

I really like this game; it's super fun and just like other tycoon games which I've always loved. I would recommend it for sure. I only have a couple of problems with the game so far though.

- The training takes a very long time and it takes your workers out of commission. So if you train doctors in GP, and they're the only GP's you have, no one will be available to take patients. It's very frustrating.

-I really wish you could assign employees to one room and that room only. You can of course change what a specific employee can work in, but you can't assign them to a room. It would be much easier to keep track of doctors and nurses, and they're not running everywhere to try and fill in spots. 

-It gets a little grindy if you don't change to a new hospital every so often. In one hospital, I now have 10 GP & 5 psychiatry rooms because the queue was getting ridiculous for them, having to hire new staff and train them all in specific areas. It's kind of tiring having to remake rooms over and over again.

-You can't really just hang out and enjoy your hospital and watch things happen. I always feel like I have to be doing something. Building new rooms, hiring and delegating new employees, training employees, dealing with the pop ups. I wish I could just watch some people be treated every once in a while.

I have been wanting to check out this game for some time. As a huge fan of the original Theme Hospital back in 1997, I was looking forward to seeing if Two Point Hospital could build upon that and create a better game. I have been absolutely pleased to say that this game exceeds all my expectations. With the addition of sand box mode it further adds to the depth of the game. This is hands down the best hospital strategy/sim game ever created. Add to the fact that there continues to be added content is exciting.

Recommend if you love really simple management sims that are hard to screw up. That doesn't mean there aren't any hard levels, but it is very simple. You won't get that crazed City Skylines vibe, where things get too hard to manage. Overall it was good to kill time while watching Youtube videos and chilling for a bit after work. My only wish is that I could have a "favourite layout" saved for each of the rooms, so I could just build my favourite optimised room and then just copy paste it in other levels. Definitely falls into the "grindy" category, but I still enjoyed it.
If it was just a remix of the classic Theme Hospital that'd be swell, but Two Point Hospital is much more than that. Highly recommend.

This game is fun for a short while, and is very charming, but there are a number of downsides which made the game fall short of what I expected.

The core mechanics are mostly good, and building your first few hospitals is fun. The art is cute and the content is pretty funny sometimes. 

A few downsides which made me not recommend this game:
[list]
    [*]After a few levels of play you begin to notice that there is very little challenge to the game, and it becomes quite grind-y. 
    [*]'leveling up' rooms requires you to place high value items in them, which usually ends up with you just plastering every wall in your hospital with golden certificates. 
    [*]the training mechanic takes an ungodly amount of time and takes your training/trainee staff completely out of action, so you have to hire replacements for them while they train.
    [*]the game does not allow you to construct buildings of your own chosen dimensions. Instead, you place rooms inside buildings of fixed size. This sounds like a minor gripe but it can be very irritating if rooms have minimum size requirements or the given building is a weird shape.
[/list]

If you can get it at a cheap price, it's quite fun. But I wouldn't expect too much from it. It's quite limited in its scope.
Good stuff all around, Thank you guys.

Two Point Hospital is definitely entertaining and the various diseases and methods of treatment are hilarious. These alone warrant a positive review. While the maps are fairly repetitive, they each offer unique challenges to push you into designing your hospital a little bit different each time. You can also purchase a large variety of items to decorate / improve your hospital, allowing for a pretty good degree of customization.

There are some problems with how the game is played, however. The biggest issue is that in order to get a room to level 5, the game essentially forces you to make the least aesthetically pleasing design of all. The way I do it (and have seen others do it) is cover the walls in gold star posters. The way rooms must be designed sort of forces the player to do this and does not give any incentive to try anything creative in the rooms. This is unfortunate considering the multitude of items available to design your hospital. In the end, the only ones I ever used were gold star posters, fire extinguishers, and occasionally water fountains. I don't foresee this ever being addressed as it seems like they would need to overhaul the entire room prestige structure. If it were me, I would have given increased prestige value based on each unique item. Just a thought.

Very well done game. There is nothing new or very deep about it (compared to the Theme-Hospital), but the execution is close to perfect. It is satisfying, giving you opportunity to make strategic decisions, without forcing you into too much micromanagement. 
It's very enjoyable to play for a week or two, later it starts to be repetative.
A DLC or sequel should add a layer of complexity for larger hospitals to keep it challenging (maybe bigger role of competitors taking staff and patients?)
Can play this game for hours on end, there's a lot to do and it can be a good challenge
just like the original!

I used to play Theme Hospital (a lot!) and really missed playing the game. Now there is a way to relive the good ol' days with Two Point Hospital. No, it is not the same, but it comes close and it is fun to play too!

I loved Theme Hospital so much when it came out but there were a few flaws and this game totally fixes them. It's a joy to play and as customisable as you want to make it. Most unoriginal game I've ever played. If you played Theme Hospital, you have nothing to gain by buying this. If you didn't, head over to GoG and buy that instead. 

This is exactly the same game but with less charm. Map goals get more and more tedious as you progress and there's nothing to really keep you on your toes, just keep building the same rooms and filling the walls with the same decorations to increase the room "prestige" for... nothing, really. And to top it all off, half the map is locked and tacked on as DLC, which just smacks of petty greed given the only thing that really changes with each area is the shape of the foundations.

This game is very similar to Theme Hospital from the nineties.  The diseases are cute (.e.g "Light headedness" means your head was replaced by a light bulb).  There was thought put into the machines used to administer the cures.  I bet it was fun coming up with all the pun illnesses and cures!  

You have to hire the right staff and lay out the hospital well in order for your patients to have a good experience.  Get used to killing patients though as you must train your staff in order for them to be proficient!  There is a balance here between spending money wisely and growing too slowly that makes the game challenging.   Early on you might find yourself taking out loans to keep your head above water.  Take advantage of the feedback you can get in the game (and there's a lot) in order to become a lean, mean, patient-healing machine!

There are a couple of game mechanics I don't enjoy.  At one point you need to find aliens in your hospital.  The only way to find them is when their "disguise" malfunctions.  You can hear it but it can be hard to see.  It would be nice if there were a way to spot them without it.  Like having a flashlight of sorts that you can shine over patients and reveal aliens.  The same goes for the patients that get sick.  You have to be able to spot them and provide a shot to make them better.  There are two possible illnesses they can get.  One is easy to spot.  The other is extremely difficult.  It just got to the point where I didn't even try.  I just threw in the towel if it appears and took my lumps. 

The game, like all games of this genre, can wear thin.  You do the same things over and over.  Each hospital provides some challenges but the road to victory is paved the same way.  Still, it's enough fun for me to have played for many hours!  It was enjoyable and I recommended it highly for those who love simulation games!

Theme Hospital was always one of my all-time favourite games. I always wished for a modern version as increasingly more dodgy mods were the only way I could keep playing through to adulthood. Then along came Two Point Hospital..

First attempt at playing I hated it! It wasn't EXACTLY like Theme Hospital, the people looked funny and I wasn't familiar with the controls. Gave up after 20 minutes and forgot it. A few weeks later I decided to have a real go - and I'll never look back!

PROS
- Still as funny as ever! Background radio is great entertainment, as is just watching people do stupid things and interact with random items in your hospital.
- Manageable learning curve. Whilst I was already familiar with some game mechanics, there were a lot of new things to learn and the pace is well-balanced. 
- Controls - Camera panning is great (for PC players at least), and designing is easy with copy and pasting of rooms.
- Potential for growth. The world map can get bigger easily, and already has with multiple DLC from active and vocal developers. More achievements can be added, new illnesses, new items, the REMIX mode letting you play a new style of game.. Not just your standard 10 level game anymore!

CONS
- If I HAD to think of something negative, it would be that random negative events can be frustrating. The worst for me is when certain rivals visit your hospital they cause problems such as brainwashing patients and staff to be miserable or sabotaging your machinery. Not fun replacing my pharmacy mixer because a VIP I wasn't watching trashed it.. 
- Even the con can be a positive, makes the game a bit more challenging ;)

For any old-school Theme Hospital player, 10/10 would recommend. For your average simulation lover, would also 10/10 recommend. Enjoy the humour and the challenge, and just get sucked back in like I did!

This game is very much a spiritual successor to 'Theme Hospital' of yesteryear, and fulfils that role well. The humour is in the same dry British vein, the controls and UI are similar, and the overall gameplay is similar too. Thankfully modern improvements have been brought in to improve some things, but it still retains that nostalgic flavour. For those who have no idea what 'Theme Hospital' is, then think of a game where you build a hospital and cure patients of wacky ailments, all the while the game is poking its tongue out at you and the health care system. Quite charming. There is depth and detail to management of your hospital, so it's more involved than just shoving sick people into doctors and hoping the patients are cured, but not so micro-management-y that you need to tell your staff exactly what to do all the time. All in all, funny game.

A worthy successor to Theme Hospital, but take that with a grain of salt as it has all the bugs to go with it.  

Wish Steam would allow you to do a so-so recommendation as a yes or no answer doesn't always suffice...

Pros-  
Builds upon the fun of Theme Hospital and gives you more to laugh at as your patients are litterally shaken to pieces getting their treatment.  There are more diseases that the patients can catch and the cure is often worse then the disease....  Literally.
More stuff to put in the rooms and hallways
Staff appears in the hiring window faster so you can build up your tortur... errr... medical staff quicker
Several new moneymaking gadgets for patients to play around with or buy from are added while waiting for the docs to see them.
The rat shooting is back, though with hyperactive worms now (must be a trademark problem.)

Training, you don't have to wait to hire a consultant in the field that you want to train others in, just bring in a contractor to train them.

Cons- some are know to older players of the game....  I know I'm one of the old fogey's...

The ques are a pain in the butt...  It pretty much replicates the original, down to all the problems it had.  

This version doesn't seem to have copied the "experience" factor.  Patients have to go through all the diagnostics before the doc figures it out.  Used to have a gotcha factor in the old game where if a doc is exposed to a condition enough that they would figure it out and skip further diagnostics.  That used to cut down on the number of GP's needed, but now you need a ton of them just to keep your hallways walkable now.

Don't patients know how to sit anymore?  You'll have 1 or 2 patients in the que sitting down on the benches and chairs provided and the rest will be piled up in the middle of the hall.

The whine factor is much worse.  And I think it is a bug.  Built my janitors up to 3 per piece of hardware, and if you count plants it's pretty much 1:1.  But the same janitors will be called out over and over causing them to tire out then threaten to quit.  Just go to staffing, click on everyone that is tired and then send them to take a break.  If you notice, the ones that are the most tired/worn out will be the janitors and the assistants.  Both of them seem to be bugged no matter if you have far more then needed.

On the same note, the slide bars don't seem to want to send people on break properly.  The docs and nurses seem to work better, but they'll go en mass to the breakrooms no matter how rested or tired they are.

On shooting the worms, it is even worse then shooting the rats on the original.  Not the speed, but the aiming.  And god forbid that the hallway is crowded.  The game seems to decide if it will allow you to actually shoot no matter how you aim your mouse.  And the standards are always changing.  If the hallway is crowded, or you click near an item (and you don't even have to actually be close to it) the screen centers on that person or item.  If it is a person, it will then drag your screen around.  It used to do that in the original, but the tolerances were tighter even for an DOS based program.  No real excuse for updated programming.

And heat is back, with all the irritations that come with it.  Haven't the programmers heard of central heat and air?  Ducts would be a better modern fit as well as being easier to incorporate.  At least I haven't lost my touch with it...

The Clown emergency is bugged.  Every so often, it will give you the emergency and no one will show up even if you're built to the gills on clinics.  It is the only "emergency" bug I've noticed so far.

Training is back and it is faster.  The only thing is that once you train someone, you'll keep getting pop ups wanting to promote them.  You hire someone with the skills, they go for about a year before wanting to be promoted.  You train someone- they'll want promotions every couple months.  The other thing is, it doesn't always let you know when someone can be trained to a higher level.  You can train  6 people on psychology, then when you choose to have a class on psychology 2, only 4 (as an example as it varies) will show up as being trainable even though all 6 have training slots open and are still on staff.

Reputation is bugged or completely wonky.  Had a flowing hospital where lots of patients were being seen quickly and treated to the tune of 200k profit a month with 0% markup on prices.  Lots of seats, no real temp variances, room quality was 4 or above, plenty of things to do in the hall, and pretty quick service (ques of 4 or less.)  Employess were pretty happy, pay satisfaction was low but roughly 50%.  Yet, my rep plummeted over the course of a year till it hit 8 rep.  Patients kept coming, though slower (dropped me to about 50k profit.)  Then the rep went up as mysteriously as it dropped without doing anything.  All I was doing was going for the final star....

Build lots of toilets....  At least 1 room with 3 in every building.  I'd go with more but that would be a recommended minimum.  Docs and patients don't seem to like traveling between buildings to drop a load even if it is 4 steps between buildings.  This also seems to go for breakrooms for your staff.

Building limitations.  If the radiators came back, you know they just had to bring back the odd shape buildings.  Newer version not able to add onto buildings or construct them to the playes specs?

Death....  A fact of life.  Haven't reached the highest stages yet, but the variations of treatments for disease seems to have been left out of this version.  A cure for one is a death sentence for another.  It seems to have been replaced by upgrading machines, but that doesn't seem to have done anything from death striking randomly.  The ghosts are pretty funny when they're dustbustered up if you have a janitor trained in ghostbusting.

The awards ceremony.  An annoyance especially if you're in the middle of building a room.  Even clicking on it to close it brings up the "cancel the room" tab.  It's pretty easy to keep track of when it is going to strike, but still an annoyance.  On the same point, you can't look at messages or hire people when you're in the middle of a build.  It will do the same....

Research- more limited then it was before.  You can't disect people like before (as fas as I know of as I haven't finished yet,) you can't research subsets of a disease, and you're limited to researching the equipment and waste a lot of time getting a pitiful grant or tokens to buy "special items."  Another bug that I've been running into, and it is random so far, is that researchers (even though assigned to research as their only job) will disappear with the research incomplete and just walk the halls after taking a break.  This is with plenty of doctors to do everything else.  Haven't noticed anything wrong with assigning people to only working one room except for research.  Also, co-op research either isn't allowed or not allowed to work for me.  So it's basically one researcher per task.

Conclusion:

Worthy successor of Theme Hospital?  Yes....  It still has the same bad puns of the original, just more of them.  Worth $30?  Not unless you're a fanatic for the original.  It just seems they updated the programming to match the newer OS, added a few more actions, and gave you more stuff to play around with.    But there is still quite a bit of problems left from the original.  If I had been told it was just a mod for the original, I wouldn't discount it.  But it is still fun to play after all these years (and I still play Theme Hospital on a VM from the original disk I bought years ago in the bargin basket.)

Edit:  Should have said staff box instead of sliding bar.  My head was still stuck up the Theme hospital hole.  Unfortunately, you can't set priorities; just rooms for staff and clicking on individual items to repair in this game.  And pathing sucks the higher up you get in a map.

Super addictive management sim. Similar to others you've played (build up a "base", get some new toys, eventually start all over again on a new "map" with a new challenge). This one has a pretty good sense of humor. All the ailments are jokes and the announcements are usually kinda funny. Animations are cute. Soundtrack is mellow and pleasant and will definitely get stuck in your head. It's easy to lose yourself in this one for several hours. 

Despite all those good things, it doesn't feel like the most polished entry in this genre. It's difficult to explain to someone who hasn't played it but when up against the late-game environmental challenges for some maps (that routinely break all your equipment and trash your hospital), you'll find yourself restarting the same hospital several times just so you can research something expensive to unlock it for yourself, then you restart the entire level with that thing unlocked (because you basically have to run your current hospital deeply into debt just to finish researching this required tech in a reasonable amount of time). It gets aggravating in late-game.

I grew up playing Theme Hospital so I was excited to play this game as it's made by some of the same people. Unfortunately, I didn't enjoy it as much as I hoped.

This game reminds me of Cities: Skylines in that it has the potential to be great but it's majorly let down by a few things (the traffic system to name one in that case) which add too much friction to the gameplay.

While playing, I made a list of things I'd like to see changed or added to make the gameplay less repetitive and boring:
1. Add the ability to template rooms for re-use BETWEEN HOSPITALS. I know you can copy-and-paste rooms within the same hospital but having to recreate the same layout for every single room type every single time you move on to a new hospital is so tedious.
2. Add the ability to favourite items or duplicate existing items. I only ever use a handful of items normally (Bench, Yucca plant, Large Radiator, Fire Extinguisher, etc) but I have to scroll through a list of hundreds of items every time I want to deploy them.
3. Add a policy for bumping low-health patients to the top of all queues. It's so tedious clicking on each one and doing so manually.
4. Make the item stats more in-depth. For a while, I wasted a load of money buying the most expensive benches, plants, etc assuming that they provided more comfort, decoration, etc but, according to everyone online, this is simply not the case and it's just an aesthetic change.
5. Change the pricing system so that a percentage is used for NEW treatments too.
6. Add the option to disable certain notifications. I got so sick of being told that reducing prices would improve the hospital's reputation, for example, because I knew exactly what I was doing.
7. Add the option to market for GP doctors. I swear they're like gold dust in the hiring screen.
8. Add the option to increase salaries to certain happiness levels. This is easy in the beginning because you can just use the +1% button but, after new hires and training, that button causes the higher-paid staff to get overpaid.
9. Add the ability to assign janitors to areas, like in Rollercoaster Tycoon.
10. Allow time to pass on the training menu. Too often I was waiting for money to come in so that I could start the training course just in time then realised that time had paused but this doesn't happen on any other menu screens (hiring, etc).

The management aspects of this game get tedious quickly.  There's little in the way of interesting decision-making or creative problem solving.  I am a dozen hours into this game and already bored of it.  Maybe it gets better after a few more and the game opens up, but frankly this game isn't complex to warrant this long of an introductory stage.  

You have your basic diagnostic rooms that every hospital needs.  You add those until you are able to service the demand of patients then you build treatment rooms as new diseases are discovered, all while hiring staff to service the rooms as you expand.  There are multiple hospitals, basically levels, to play but every one pretty much plays out similarly while maybe having a disease that is unique to the area.  They could have easily made a single tutorial hospital that briefly showcased every disease and room available.  Then succeeding hospitals could have had interesting scenarios that upped the challenge.  However, it really seems like they are trying to pad out the content by making every room a grind to unlock, basically requiring you to restart a new hospital to unlock each one.

The game also suffers from a difficulty problem.  At no point was I ever in danger of running out of money.  I just hired staff as necessary, promoted them whenever it came up and built rooms as I needed.  I was rolling in dough, so in that sense it suffers from a Cities: Skylines-like lack of difficulty that makes strategic decisions feel rather arbitrary.  Unlike Cities: Skylines however, this game has none of the creative process of designing your own little city.  Designing your hospital is much more boring and you pretty much have a selection of rooms to choose from that you will ultimately end up building the same way every time... Draw out your rectangular room, usually by just matching the minimum tile requirements, add the necessary machines for the room, add some decorations to build up the "prestige level" of the room and boom, you're done.   Hospital layout seems to be completely irrelevant as well because patients will just wander the hospital willy-nilly while waiting for appointments.  

Finally, there's the meta level concept of your healthcare corporation, which owns all your hospitals.  This is probably the most compelling part of the game, building up each of your hospitals to bolster your share price, collect stars, and such, but ultimately, as I said, each hospital plays out the same so it again feels tedious.  Keep in mind I only played this game 12 hours.

The humor in this game is a miss for me as well.  A little too cornball with the diseases and treatments.  The radio announcer guy was just weird enough to pique my interest though.  

Overall, I'd grade this game a D, remedial time-waster at best.

Yeah, it's pretty fun. Like the sims, but  way more going on once you get to the later levels. I think the higher your reputation, then the waaay busier your hospital gets. Be sure to go to your financial policy and set auto-promotions and a "diagnosis threshold" so your GP offices don't get overflowed. And send patients home if you're too busy so that you're not full of ghosts and hiring too many janitors. Bathrooms and hand sanitizer is important.

Pretty much if you like games like Hospital Tycoon this will scratch the itch. As a few other reviewers have noted, the loop can get a bit repetitive as you rebuild the same rooms and train employees in the same skills over and over with each new hospital. You are a large company with many hospitals but you cannot transfer trained personnel to another AFAIK, and this gets pretty tedious by your fourth or fifth location. Still, I played a good 20+ hours and I'm maybe halfway through the campaign (I goofed off a little in sandbox, but not much yet). Even if I lay off a bit I've no doubt I'll come back to it later and have a great time again for a bit, rinse and repeat. 

So yeah, for the $12 or so I spent on the base game, it seems well worth the money. I've picked up the first two 'location' DLCs for half off as well but haven't touched 'em yet. At ~$22 all in for the many, many hours I expect I'm gonna get out of this, it'd seem crazy to not recommend to fans of the genre. If I weren't poor, I don't think I'd feel ripped off at full price either FWIW. Impulse purchase and I'm not disappointed at all.

Sega and Two Points Studio combine their efforts to make a game that all kinds can enjoy from the family to the obsessive Sims player and tackles the emergency setting of running a hospital in a fun clean way.  I took a fast look at the wonder of "Scrubs" game play and what I feel they need to do better as they grow.

What I initially enjoyed
Presentation: It's simplicity is really done well and thought out from layouts, spacing, colors, sound, controls , smart isometric use and clean voice overs that pull you right into the madness of managing this loony set of hospitals. Nice start.  
Humor: No its not over the top adult humor like the legendary show "Scrubs" did, but its cute innocent creative illnesses and cures are well done. From ghost vacuuming to head replacements. This is executed well without having to do bad tasteful things that offend those who may not enjoy glamorizing suffering, but will tickle your funny bone, once.  Plus
Micro Managing: It was the first thing I got into the true creating your own hospital world, hiring staffs, handling budgets and upgrading. You really feel the creative urge to do it your way and not a developer's must way. A fun plus
All Ages: I mean fun for all ages, my little one laughed and had a lot of fun, my middle one really took her time plotting every little creative decorative instinct in her and my oldest son enjoyed the business side of Two Point here. Its really fun for all ages. Your playing Hospital Sims. Great plus.
Support: This felt like a true full content game with tons of fun ideas and a lot of content. They are constantly adding, and inventing and that is always great from a developer who has learned from their mistakes. You can do your own music, compete with those on your friend's list without realizing it and excellent camera usage. Smart
Pause: Is your friend and trust me you will need it at times with quick action to avoid catastrophe. 
Blood: Though crude in its use. Those may take the brutal twisted nature of the cure machines to be over the top, but I did not find it grotesque or harsh for the squeamish. 

What I feel they need to improve
Colors: It's pastel blandness can make it hard for the eye impaired and there are so many functions that the hand impaired and handicap may find Two Point too much to handle. The game needs good contrasting tones and auto building options for those who cannot handle all the detail of placement in the room. An auto AI room with content maker as a secondary option would be wise to add.
Sim City: My little one, soon found herself vastly overwhelmed and players can easily lose control of all the micro managing that needs to be done in controlling not just multiple hospitals, but massive layouts with tons of content. Though you have tools in game to manage things in groups like most simulators do. The youth may find this game too much to handle. Many may love the tons of content, but some may find it too much.
Spacing: You sometimes feel, you just don't have enough space and can make bad placement decisions with too much that can clog personnel and cause buggy responses. 
Space Cadets: What I call the "Scrubs" space cadet moments when tasks are not executed because of AI conflict. A Janitor decides to take a break at full energy instead of getting that ghost, or your Psychologist at full training decides to leave a session for no reason at all. A patient suddenly dies even though your staff is at peak performance with no way to prolong that death sign. Small space cadet moments can turn off serious gamers. A caution from me. 
DLC: Watch the pricing on these mixed dlcs, a practice many developers need to stop. I can only caution on that.

My First Take: Two Point gives you a lot of bang for the buck. The time will fly with all you have to do and the old school simulator SIMS game gets the job done. The passion is clearly in the work and you will get a thrill in all the creative managing of a hospital. Two Point Studios did a masterful job with Two Point Hospital, perhaps too good as some of your monster hospital creations can get away from you in the end. You almost feel, well, I accomplish that, than winning at anything. It is a silly fun filled game that in time will build into a cult classic. If you love SIMS, simulation building games are your thing, then two point can be a lot of fun for the price of admission. I reserve the final thoughts once its all complete, for now see the video play above discussion to figure if the game play is for you before buying. My Grade 3.8 out of 5

This is an average game that will guarantee a couple of hours of enjoyment.  I certainly wouldn't pay full price. The game becomes repetitive after about 5 hours, and the levels don't really offer much aside from more space to build.  That being said, i think it would be a great value at a lower price point.  The 5-10 hours of novel gameplay are quite fun and worth spending $10-$15 on.  I wouldn't recommend buying this game at full price because it simply doesn't have the content to support a price that high.  You can pay for DLC to add bit more content, but I do not consider the DLC content into the value of the original product.

Initially I was really hesitant to try this game out - I don't play much Simulation Games but this game just kept sucking me in minute after minute. What a game - I don't understand how amazingly simple yet deep this title is, Definitely a buy.

[h1]This is a must have for management/simulator fans.[/h1]

If you like Sim City, Rim World, Prison Simulator, Startup Company and those type of games, you'll get your money's worth out of this. 
They do the little things right when it comes to game design and story progression. Typically I end up burning through these kind of games because I get bored with the repetitiveness. This game does a good job making you fully explore every aspect of the game, incentivizing exploring different play styles and building unique hospitals in order to progress other hospitals to their full potential. The models and animation looks a little quirkey (childish?) at first but you will quickly get over the style once you realize how in depth every aspect of the game is.

In other words I played like 20 hours of this crap non stop over the weekend and I still want to play more and have things to unlock.

I don't usually play these kinds of games but I got this on sale out of curiosity. It's a lot of fun, hilarious situations/illnesses, and very easy to learn and get used to. Unlocking a lot of things such as items and illnesses take time so there's always something new to look forward to. Nothing rushed and doesn't get boring easily. I recommend it if you're looking for something new to pass the time.

I was really looking forward to playing this game as the reviews are 'very positive'........ and i enjoy simulation and builder type games. Unfortunately however, the game becomes extremely repetitive after creating your third of fourth hospital. You will find yourself building the exact same rooms to meet demand in each hospital with barely any variation. If you're going to give us this much larger area to build on, give us something new and interesting to actually build, not just - you remember that room that you built in your last hospital? Well guess what, you might need two or three of them in this hospital.

Don't get me wrong, if you can get it on a deal, as i did, you may get a good few hours of fun and entertainment out of it - the characters are quite creative and well animated and the hospital announcement system can provide a laugh or two. There are definitely some people who have written positive reviews with hundreds of hours in this game so maybe you're one of those people who can suspend the boredom enough to play it forever.

All in all, not one that i can recommend. They have good building blocks there, but unfortunately all of the blocks are the same colour and every couple of hours they take your blocks away, give you new blocks and tell you to build it again, just slightly bigger.
